raw_text.19: this book is based on an premise suing the u s government for the atrocities caused by slavery and asking for reparations to be paid by all descendants the book begins with a chapter featuring a slave girl josephine bell in the late 1840's and early 1850's josephine is a house slave tending to the needs of the ill mistress of the house luanne bell who is best known then and in all the intervening years between then and the current day for her painting and particularly for her compassionate paintings of slaves trapped in an unhappy marriage luanne had selected josephine herself depends on her for care conversation and companionship and josephine's ability to do that is enhanced by learning to read and draw and paint in addition to caring for her mistress josephine helps her with her paintings and also paints for herself every moment she can even though it may seem that she is in a privileged position josephine has suffered from abuse from the master of the house and from watching her friends who are field slaves and she longs for freedom the book then moves to current time carolina lina sparrow and her law associates who have just been presented the challenge of the reparation suit the story jumps back and forth between the two times as information is revealed both from josephine's position and lina's research a subplot is lina's life with her artist father that contains a huge gap in lina's life lina knows only what her father has told of her mother that being that she was killed in an accident when lina was four years old lina has enhanced her shadowy memories with her own thoughts about her mother and a few photographs she has seen the weaving of these stories together along with those of several other characters reveal much about who josephine and lina are i enjoyed this book a lot and am having a little trouble letting it go while there are indications that several important parts of the story are going to be resolved it ends with leaving those details to the reader's imagination and i catch myself wanting to go back to the book and read the rest of the story
raw_text.20: 3 5 out of 5 stars lina is an attorney who measures her life in tenths of an hour a century and a half earlier josephine was a house slave with little to love in her life a slavery reparations lawsuit brings their stories together i did enjoy reading this historical fiction as always when i read about slavery or injustice of all types i am appalled at what we are capable of doing to one another however this story is more about human spirit than it is about anything else i liked some of the characters especially lina's father oscar some of the characters did not have the depth i would have liked and some parts of the story were a little too easily guessed the writing was interesting and competent no grating idiosyncrasies but also nothing to make it especially memorable it all adds up to a good story solid writing but not something that will find its way to my list of favorites i was given an advance reader's copy of the book for review and i am grateful for that

raw_text.24: good book while this book should have made me think primarily of freedom it made me consider words growing up in the south i know the words that bind josephine the slave these same words live as ghosts in the land still there but slowly evolving and changing with the environment we have the same words to get free in that we have to stay unfree... what changes the construct of the words the environment of the words the perception of the words the interpretation of the words recalling the 50's and 60's in the south where the officially free were still struggling what has changed there definitely is a sense of more freedom the emancipation proclamation was issued in 1863 but in 1963 there were still chains in all that freedom what the nation freed individuals still chained through actions defined and driven by words i look back at the words on signs and such colored whites only the emancipation proclamation separated it didn't free but we're getting closer i think it takes time for words to embrace their construct

raw_text.38: the housegirl is the juxtaposed story of a slave girl in 1850s virginia and a twenty something lawyer in 2004 josephine is a housegirl on a slave farm her main duties include taking care of her missus lu ann bell lu ann bell is an artist and painter who teaches josephine to paint read and write they seem to have an easy relationship as easy as it can get between a slave owner and the woman she enslaves that is lu ann becomes terribly ill and the story starts to take some dramatic turns meanwhile lina is a lawyer at a prestigious law firm who must deal with a class action reparations lawsuit representing african americans she sets out to do some research and runs across the story of josephine and lu ann bell could josephine actually have been the producer of some of the artwork sold as lu ann's the story of josephine is alluring with beautiful metaphorical language that sounds soothing if you're listening to the book being read aloud which i did with this one then enters lina and the stories read as if they were written separately and then linked somehow the symmetry between the two stories doesn't seem to work some information is thrown in and you think there will be a link but turns out there isn't one lina's character seems unsure her law firm and their twenty five year old partner trackers uninteresting lots of african american history here not one smithsonian museum to catalog slavery in america pretty interesting to see that mentioned in this novel though there is one just now being built and set to launch in 2014 though the legal posturing seems unconvincing in some parts the dialogue between the law partners and lawyers gives a lot of information about a possible reparations lawsuit as a result of the impact of slavery on the economic setback of african americans the rounds family and the virginian underground railroad fascinating story

raw_text.67: i've read a lot of books recently with split timelines but this is the first where the time conceit of two different eras had basically no bearing whatsoever on each other josephine the house girl of the title should've been the focus of the story but we never really learned anything about her beyond the one week of her life that was actually told here for a book about slavery there was surprisingly little insight into slavery and how it affected those caught up in or trying to escape from it over to lina's modern story and her participation in the reparation lawsuit if the author wanted to make a point early on about the forgotten faces of slavery two and a half pages of literally just names is not the right way to go about it all that does is have your reader quickly page forward resulting in not one of those names registering as they're skipped by the use of time measurements was also ineffective yes overpriced lawyers charge for every penny of their time but that's one trait that makes them so disliked by the general public to have lina note her efforts in six minute increments only made her seem petty callous and disinterested in the actual history behind the case yes at the end when she stopped noting time increments it was intended to be because she realized there was more to life than marking time to charge a client for that's clear enough to the reader but it wasn't enough to redeem lina into a likable character however there was one redeeming feature and i almost gave this three stars because of it those were the archival letters from dot and caleb this is how the tale should've been told the letters were a consistent narrative allowing the reader to see the true emotional struggles with which the letter writer was struggling unfortunately the letters made up a very small part of the overall book and so since the majority was spent between a very unsatisfying tale from josephine so little from her why did the author even bother probably because she was the only lead character in the book who was black and this is nominally a slavery story so of course it wouldn't be pc not to have a black protagonist and bland lina beyond her aforementioned unlikable character there was no point to the storyline involving her mother whatsoever i must give the house girl but two stars
raw_text.68: we need so many more books about slavery this peculiar institution that enslaved everyone who touched it and continues to reverberate in our history it's legacy is so pervasive that we do everything not to deal with it ms conklin adds one more book to the narrative of confronting our history however the problem for many non white writers is they cannot enter the experience of the slave the hopelessness the fear the drudgery the longings the rage and the courage to go on in the face of certain death the slave characters remain lifeless mere vessels to illustrate a point the book does a better job of talking about how the white characters are also enslaved the planter and his barren sickly wife but they too are archetypes the premise of the modern day storyline is ridiculous but does continue the theme of how this history traps us the up and coming african american lawyer wanting to please his white superiors the biracial descendant denying his history and the corporation denying history to protect their investment all things that are happening today's

raw_text.79: i did not have high expectations for the house girl after reading the cover describing how the novel moves between josephine a slave in virginia in 1852 and lina a young lawyer in 2004 working on a case regarding reparations for the descendants of slaves while i thought this would be a cliched and overwrought historical drama i was pleasantly surprised the novel does have some flaws but overall it is engrossing and not as predictable as i anticipated conklin a debut author with degrees in history and law weaves together the many threads of her stories with the use of epistolary chapters and third person narrated chapters perhaps my biggest issue with the house girl is that josephine rarely speaks for herself though she is the subject of not only the title but also the many people writing and researching about her life conklin raises some interesting points without daring to answer them leaving the reader with a sense of incompleteness upon finishing despite these minor qualms i would recommend this for fans of historical fiction especially fiction focusing on women along the same lines of books like the help or alias grace

book travels between past and present to tell these two stories until they finally connect and become one lina is working on what could be a history making lawsuit to award reparations to african americans for pain and suffering experienced by their ancestors due to slavery and she needs to find a descendant of slaves to agree to become the main plaintiff of the case through her artist father she learns that a collection of paintings attributed to a southern woman who died in 1852 may have actually been painted by her slave josephine lina then tries to find a descendant of josephine's to help in her lawsuit what she learns about josephine and about her own life and her mother and father lead her to leave the path she thought she always wanted josephine lived at bell creek her entire life and some would have considered her life to be easier than those of other slaves her owners mister and missus bell kept her as a house girl where she tended to the needs of her ill missus her misses lu anne bell was a painter and she allowed josephine to paint as well josephine decided to run to try to escape to freedom on the same day she learns that her missus is dying her experiences in her tragic life come to light in the present and lina finds her plaintiff and so much more this book is an important reminder of the horrors and inhumanity that were such a huge part of the united states from it's very beginning it brings up some good points concerning the lack of an apology given to the descendants of slaves the lack of a museum of slavery that should be among the many museums that make up the smithsonian the fact that while slavery is no longer legal there are still huge differences between what white people and black people earn the jobs they are given and the opportunities they have the book is also extremely well written and seamlessly ties together the stories of these two women

raw_text.173: i'm not a fan of dual time period novels many authors have to stretch to make the historical and present day narratives mesh or add a fantasy element tara conklin pulls off this trick with skill and finesse i was fully invested in both her main characters the artist slave josephine and the modern day lawyer salary slave lina although their stories parallel with missing mothers unrealized potential and overlap with mysteries it's always obvious that josephine's life is tragic and lina deals with what we call first world problems both make life changing choices but josephine's are visceral and dangerous conklin provides a well paced poignant story with suspense detailed settings and interesting characters my only complaint is a plot twist involving some too convenient epistolary evidence which i can't explain without spoilers a small complaint compared to the overall effort which brings us a wonderful tale addressing a difficult subject highly recommended

raw_text.191: an engaging work of fiction with excellent research done by the author particularly with regard to the underground railroad ms conklin captures the spirit of what it was possibly like for one young black teenager with intelligence and creativity to be caught in the resin of slavery the book is really the story of two women both minorities living some 150 years apart josephine is a young girl serving as a house slave to a white woman on a failing plantation near lynnhurst va augusta county in 1852 when the novel begins seventeen year old josephine bell decides to run from the failing tobacco farm where she is a slave and nurse to her ailing mistress the aspiring artist lu anne bell carolina lina sparrow is an ambitious first year associate in an elite law firm located in new york city in 2004 when her story begins in the second chapter of the book lisa is given a difficult highly sensitive assignment that could make her career she must find the "perfect plaintiff" to lead a historic class action lawsuit worth trillions of dollars in reparations for descendants of american slaves it is through her father the well known artist oscar sparrow that lina discovers josephine bell and a controversy roiling the art world are the paintings long ascribed to lu anne bell really the work of her house slave josephine a descendant of josephine's would be the perfect face for the reparations lawsuit--if lina can find one lisa does excellent research and finds a 'trail' for the runaway girl through old letters and plantation records during the process lina finds herself questioning her own family history and the secrets that her father has never revealed how did lina's mother die and why will he never speak about her the author takes us back and forth from antebellum virginia and modern day new york in a suspenseful and heartbreaking tale of art and history love and secrets exploring what it means to repair a wrong and asking whether truth is sometimes more important than justice

raw_text.199: review first published on my blog http memoriesfrombooks blogspot com the house girl is two parallel stories two women in two different time periods and two different situations yet their stories belong together in this book it is 2004 and lina sparrow is a young lawyer trying to establish herself in her firm and get on the partner track she is assigned to a class action lawsuit that looks to get reparations for families and descendants of american slaves her job is to find a lead plaintiff to represent the class for the lawsuit an individual who can be the face of the lawsuit in her research she discovers a controversy in the art world a claim that the work of renowned southern artist lu anne bell is actually the work of her house girl a young slave by the name of josephine lina sets out to discover josephine's story and hopefully a descendant who could be part of the lawsuit the book tells lina's story and josephine's story lina's story is that of her career this lawsuit and of her relationship with her parents her mother who died when she was a child and her father who himself is an artist and who has never spoken of her mother with lina at least not until now it is a story of the impact of this on lina and her journey of self discovery josephine's story is the story of the life of a slave on a plantation in virginia in 1852 it is the story of the horrors and losses that life entailed it is the story of a quest for freedom and all those who either helped or hindered that quest a number of convenient some may say too convenient coincidences draw the two stories together however that did not hinder my enjoyment of the book the stories are beautifully told and i found myself feeling for both lina and josephine and drawn into both their lives a beautiful debut novel i look forward to reading more from tara conklin

raw_text.255: this review will go live on the blog 11 25goodreads' awards broke me i have no discipline whatsoever when it comes to the library i can usually tell ahead of time what my reading schedule looks like for the week and what reviews need to be written so i tend to know what wiggle room i have for library books more often than not i grab all the books and wind up taking the majority back unread because i borrowed too many when the voting was open i basically used to nominees as my own personal recommendations there were so many wonderful books i had missed out on this year i immediately requested a handful from my library and the house girl was at the top of my stack have you ever come across a book that felt as though the author wrote it with you in mind that this book was written for you the house girl was that book for me it featured so many of my favorite things in novels dual narratives different eras art alternating between the present day 2004 and the 1850s the house girl tells the tale of josephine bell a slave whose artwork had been credited to her mistress lu anne bell lina sparrow is a young lawyer hoping to work her way up through the ranks long hours and a good track record have won her the approval of her boss but she's looking for that one case that'll make her career that case comes in the form of a lawsuits seeking reparations for descendants of slaves lina's tasked with finding the 'perfect plaintiff ' one person who will able to represent the millions as she's working the case her research brings her to josephine's story and she soon finds herself immersed in this young woman's life and the night she made the decision to run i absolutely loved the house girl while reading i couldn't help but compare it to two other books i equally adored the girl you left behind by jojo moyes while the stories were different both books dealt with dual narratives timelines and art and the art forger by b a shapiro for the art obvs both books rank among my favorites the art forger was one of my top reads of 2012 and have been recommended multiple times over i can easily see the house girl following suit already i've told numerous people about it and can't wait for more people to read this wonderful book while i am a huge fan of dual narratives i tend to prefer one storyline over the other and that holds true with the house girl i was so caught up in josephine's story that i found myself quickly reading lina's chapters in order to get back to the 1800s that's not to say lina was any less interesting i enjoyed her story but i never found myself as invested in her relationship with her father dealing with her mother's absence as i was in josephine's life my favorite parts of lina's chapters were the scenes that dealt with the case and therefore josephine the insight into josephine's world her ache for freedom the whippings that were just another part of life the realization that her son was alive were heartbreaking and i couldn't tear myself away the house girl is a dangerous book in that i could only read it at home when i was able to devote large blocks of time to reading this definitely is not the type of novel that can be read in small doses a chapter here and there the moment i finished one chapter i needed to keep reading the ending played out different than i had hoped particularly lina's story but it didn't detract from the rest of the novel don't be surprised if the house girl makes an appearance on my top reads of 2013 list

raw_text.257: the house girlsource goodreads comi am so excited first of all i finished grading all of my essays and book projects i sat down and just kept going and this is the third read a long type event i've successfully completed this year i usually get behind or don't start at all everyone's picking really good books too i just finished the house girl by tara conklin for katie's read a long at words for worms if you'd like to join in there's still time she will post the discussion at the end of march there are a few things i liked about this story first is the dual narrative told between slave josephine bell in the mid 1800s and lawyer lina swallow in the present day post 9 11 as a slave josephine's story is probably one you've heard before but no less tragic because of it lina is a lawyer working on a precedent setting case dealing with reparation of slavery where she discovers josephine's history as the two women's stories unfold they not only give insight to themselves but also to each other which is the other piece of this story i enjoyed the characters are all searching and neither time nor place interferes with the familiar story human existence has played out over the centuries your past your present and what you hope for in the future all pieces we replay in our minds or search for anywhere we think possible this similarity despite time binds the characters together and affects lina in a drastic way and for those of you who love how recent stories have included art or music as centers to their stories the house girl's characters and events center in part around artwork from the pre civil war years and the question as to who is the real artist

raw_text.263: my review is based on the soft back edition of this book which i received free from the publisher as an "advance readers edition" in exchange for the promise that i would write a review unlike many books where it takes several chapters before you are drawn into the story i was immediately captivated by this book the primary message in the book for me was the comparison between the hopes and dreams of two girls one was a modern day smart young white female lawyer raised by a single father who thought she knew who she was and what she wanted but found that true satisfaction laid elsewhere the other girl was a young gifted black girl raised as a "thing" on a virginia plantation who had never been beyond the gates of the virginia plantation but had an inner desire to be "free" even while having no concept of what being free would actually consist of surprisingly or maybe not so surprisingly these two women had much in common there were a multitude of the examples of how horribly the slaves were treated during those days - i thank god that this era of slavery is behind us there were also hints at the various ways people of today are actually enslaved by controlling things and people in addition the novel explored the pros and cons of the question of whether we americans in 2012 still owe the black people "back pay" for the contributions made by their forefathers in building this great country we all live in the two primary characters were very well developed and i could relate to both of them unfortunately i never was able to dive into the mind of some members of the supporting cast for instance it would have been interesting to know what really drove the plantation owner i concluded that a series of failures had made him a bitter and brutal person and i think his reactions were sadly true to life when our dreams fall apart but i wished i had been able to explore some of his mental processes the book was an easy read with a somewhat simple plot but hidden within the tapestry of the plot are several diverse threads that provide insights into the different ways that we humans are wired by god to live and think i think it would be a great book discussion group pick there are many ares fertile for discussion
raw_text.264: this is a beautiful story following the lives of two woman linked through art history and personal mysteries the story moves between antebellum virginia and a modern day new york the truth of one with lead to the truth of the other it is full of heartbreak and loss but don't be discouraged the truth leads to justice this was a short book about 370 page in paper back but electronically only about 150 font size does make a difference i think i read this book in two evenings i could not put this book down and the writing was so easy to read i loved conklin's style it was smooth and idiomatic conklin did a wonderful job of describing both virginia and new york with just enough details to guide my imagination but not so many the i had no creative freedom the story line flows and like i said i kept coming back and couldn't put down i would definitely recommend this book as a light read maybe for a weekend trip something light to keep you entertained and interested but not so long that you couldn't finish it on your days off to read my full review see my blog http adventuresofabibliophile blogs

raw_text.324: the book concentrates on a case about reparations for the ancestors of slaves this is an investigation into the lost hopes and dreams of nameless thousands of people and the consideration of whether or not they are entitled to any kind of recognition monetary or otherwise on the surface it would seem that the company sponsoring this law suit is interested in getting money from the families who wronged the slaves and who prospered from their efforts in order to better the situation of the black population today descendants of slaves by memorializing them enhancing their opportunities and thereby improving their economic future in the end the reader will wonder what truly motivated the firm seeking the law suit personal greed or altruism two stories lives side by side in this book separated by more than a century connected by two important themes one is freedom and the other is justice all of the characters are seeking freedom in some way although some efforts are more intense are about life and death and some perhaps are about saving one's soul or self in the search for truth and introspection the search for justice in life and in death in personal and public life in the legal and criminal world is evident throughout when secrets are revealed the way is opened for life changing events the two themes one of greed and the need for personal gain over all else and the other its counterpart compassion and the care and consideration of others constantly oppose each other as the book moves on the reader will witness the pain caused by the one and the salvation caused by the other the book will quietly expose the subtle current day racism that still exists in both the white and the black community in 1852 josephine bell was a young teenage slave on the bell tobacco farm a decaying homestead beset by bad luck the farm is descending into a state of neglect and less productivity and the slaves are being sold off josephine most likely of mixed race lives in the main house as "the house girl" and therefore has a bit better life than most of the dwindling number of slaves on the property but she is still owned and is a prisoner there because of a depraved society driven by greed she was a proud young girl who had dreams of freedom and on more than one occasion tried to escape the first time she was defeated in her attempt though she reached safety she was in an advanced state of pregnancy and was forced to return and deliver a child that very same night she was told the child did not survive she was only 14 years of age and she still continued to dream of escape we learn of josephine's story through carolina sparrow the daughter of a famous artist she is a litigator assigned by her law firm to find a living plaintiff that can be traced back to a slave that has been wronged while pursuing the investigation she discovers a link between the slave owning family of the prominent artist lu anne bell and their slave josephine who was their house girl and who was also an artist sometimes permitted to paint by her seriously ill mistress but more often asked to complete her mistress's paintings or correct and improve them whose paintings are they the slave's or her mistress's the reader is privy to correspondence between two sisters in a family that operates an "underground railroad" and these letters were a highlight of the book in dorothea's letters to her sister we learn first hand about the danger her family faced in the endeavor to help the slaves and the surprising betrayals that follow their efforts we witness the danger and fear of the escaping slaves the trauma and the tragedies as well as the successes it would be a cold person who remains unaffected by the plight of these persecuted people one half of the tale is the tenderly told story although a repugnant part of our history of the plight of the slave josephine bell and others who suffered the same fate and harm as she did captured and enslaved often raped beaten murdered separated from their families treated as sub humans and the other is the hardscrabble story of upward mobility in the form of lawyer carolina sparrow her fellow workers her law firm and their clients the corporations that line their pockets although lina is an important part of the story for me josephine's story overshadowed hers during her investigation lina's artist father conveniently remembers a case in the art world he recently read about which might help her and conveniently there is a showing of the work of the artist in question and a controversy developing about the slave who might actually deserve credit for the paintings in the course of the investigation she also meets people who know or know of her father and they too are willing to help her then she happens on a possible relative of a slave by chance and she is attracted to him he is jasper battle a man of mixed race heavily tattooed a musician who seems unfocused and without a future at first glance but she learns there is another deeper side of him to which she is drawn then there is the "piece de resistance" the story about her mother for me all of these serendipitous moments were contrived and a bit too coincidental to be credible also i found some of the parts about lina to be tedious especially when she read off names and sometimes when she ruminated about her research then there is probably a hidden political message in this book complete with a mention of cheney and iraq but it is not heavy handed and is not distracting from the overall message it is a very sad story about a very shameful time of our history it is another in the genre so popular today that tries to illuminate the plight of the slave and the continuing struggle for civil rights all readers will be forced to look inside themselves and wonder how slavery could ever have existed how one human being could treat another so brutally and cruelly simply because it was lucrative to do so how could there have been no moral conscience to stop this how could it have taken so long to end the practice of owning a human being and treating "it" as less than human with its minor shortcomings it is nevertheless a well told story and it is a really good read which will open the mind of the reader and make the reader think about how it might be possible to right the wrongs of yesterday which are still quietly in existence today and stop the forward momentum of the greed which has captured the mind of the country

folk artist whose paintings are thought to actually be the work of her house girl josephine lina sets out to do genealogical research to determine if josephine had any descendants josephine's story josephine vows the book review the house girl by tara conklinthe house girl by tara conklin william morrow 384 pages $25 99 ttara conklin knows how to open a story "mister hit josephine with the palm of his hand across her left cheek and it was then she knew she would run " conklin writes in her passionate and politically charged debut the house girl reading the novel's opening line i feel the sting of the blow just as josephine does "today was the last day there would be no others " josephine vows the urge hits me to help her escape but i cannot aid her in flight i am just a reader after all and just like that conklin has her audience transfixed josephine's well being is of utmost concern when was the last time you read a story like that a story that made you actually care about what happened to one of its characters to such an extent that you bit your fingernails to the quick and let the world pass you by until you knew the fate of the protagonist conklin's novel is that tale a book that will keep readers up all night just to learn what becomes of josephine who is for me the heart of the house girl the house girl is a remarkable story that successfully intertwines the lives of two very different women separated by circumstances and by the passage of time in 2004 lina sparrow is a young driven first year associate at a prestigious new york city law firm she is given a high profile assignment to find the perfect plaintiff in an unprecedented historic lawsuit seeking reparations for the descendants of african american slaves trillions of dollars are at stake not to mention lina's reputation as she sets out to find a picture perfect candidate for the class action suit in 1852 josephine is a house slave in virginia at the tender age of seventeen she serves the bell family owners of a tobacco plantation josephine has already escaped once before and paid a very high price for running away despite physical punishment and the emotional toll that enslavement has inflicted upon her body and her psyche josephine is determined to escape to the north she seeks only to be her own mistress these two disparate storylines intersect when lina discusses the case with her father oscar a famous artist who gives her a lead the art world oscar says is abuzz over a controversy surrounding the paintings of lu anne bell an antebellum artist who is well known for works that featured her slaves art historians and collectors however question the authenticity of the artworks they do not believe belle painted a number of the canvases many believe her house slave josephine was the actual artist you can see the wheels turning inside lina's head when she hears the story josephine's descendant lina believes will be the perfect plaintiff the question is what happened to josephine did she escape did she have any children lina sets out on a quest and travels to what remains of the bell property in virginia now home to an archive there she painstakingly combs through letters plantation records receipts and diaries in hopes of discovering josephine's fate curiously lina's dogged pursuit changes her own life josephine's journey acts as the catalyst lina needs to question her own identity and her history because conklin writes the story with such immediacy we feel as if we have tagged along with lina on her exploration the fates of both "house" girls matter deeply to us the house girl carries enormous appeal as a crossover novel conklin combines mystery historical fiction and art history with a little romance the real strength of the house girl lies in conklin's remarkable ability to make the past come alive accurately and acutely josephine's world is beautifully and painfully rendered and the horrifying tragedies her character endures are entirely plausible conklin provides a stunning glimpse into josephine's life and readers will never forget this young courageous slave girl conklin leaves us with a provocative and potentially controversial topic slavery reparations who should be compensated who is a rightful descendant and who is not marie claire magazine calls the house girl "the book club book of 2013 " and i wholeheartedly agree conklin has created two extraordinary unforgettable women in josephine and lina it is josephine however who will steal your heart and not let go you will want to spirit her away but you are powerless until the very last page conklin's historical debut is a poignant masterpiece

raw_text.406: the house girl is the debut novel from tara conklin i love it when i find a new author as it always feels like a world that i am yet to explore it holds so much promise and possibility and i was left slightly disappointed by this effort the story is told in two narratives that of josephine a 17 yr old house slave in 1850's virginia and lina a class action lawyer in 2004 new york their stories become intertwined when lina starts working on a retribution case for a big client and whilst looking for the perfect plaintiff lina discovers that josephine may actually be the true artist of the famous works of her owner the opening chapter belonged to josephine and was immediately captivating she is planning to run from her master and it is not for the first time we learn a little about what her life is like day today and the how she is treated by the people that she works for we feel that she has some genuine affection for her mistress and a lot of pity lina is a high powered lawyer with serious issues with her parents i really wanted to like lina but i struggled she seems rude and petulant and although she seems very skilled at research she has failed to research her mothers whereabouts her character just didn't seem real to me overall i enjoyed the book as i have a natural interest in this period and situation but i have read better books addressing this issue

raw_text.416: wow just wow a recent book that's been getting rave reviews and that's being compared to "the help" is "the house girl" set in both present day new york and 19th century antebellum virginia it follows the story of 17 year old slave josephine bell and her artist mistress lu anne bell we're also introduced to a determined present day lawyer lina sparrow who is up for the trial of a lifetime in her attempt to find the perfect plaintiff for a multi million dollar lawsuit in reparations for the descendants of american slaves in her research lina stumbles upon josephine bell's story and the big question everyone wants to know is this did lu anne bell create art or did her slave filled with impeccable historical scholarship and multi layered character development this is an important and fascinating read i believe this book has that same magic effect "the help" has had for so many readers it also calls up some nagging questions that need to be answered for instance how many generations does it take to repair wrongs done to a people group are there current repercussions for descendents of slaves today that the american people are not aware of how would the us government count the cost of so many unnamed lives over 246 years of american history this book grabbed me and wouldn't let me go i've been recommending it everywhere and the plot is a great conversation starter too

raw_text.440: the house girl by tara conklinjosephine is a 17 year old slave in anti bellum virginia while lina is a twenty something up and coming lawyer in present day nyc the lives of these two become entwined when a wealthy black client of lina's law firm starts a "slave reparations" law suit that becomes entangled with an art dealer's contention that josephine is the true artist and not her widely acclaimed mistress both life in a high powered law firm and life in the slave owning south are presented believably lina and josephine are both sympathetic and well drawn characters the story line for both is engaging while the sub plot involving lina's mother is rather thin and too neatly concluded the artistic element is a link for the two stories book groups will have a variety of subjects to discuss some very superficial and entertaining and others quite serious and profound race relations now and then permeate both stories the question "who is caucasian and who is black " may form the body of the discussion the value of a piece of art and how the artist's name recognition determines price is another point for discussion motherless children and how they and their families cope could form another topic

raw_text.476: in the house girl by tara conklin we are told the story in two separate women's voices in the present day the protagonist is lina sparrow a young attorney working on a case that involves reparations for slavery in the storyline from the past 1852 we learn about josephine bell a house slave who was owned by the bell family i downloaded this book weeks ago when it was offered as an amazon special i didn't start reading it until my book club decided to read it it was fairly easy to read but it wasn't the type of book that demanded that i read it i only read it on my lunch hours and it was something i could easily set aside and go back to later i read other books while i was reading it it didn't fully engage me perhaps it was the way the story was told - jumping back and forth from past to present but i didn't feel much attachment to either character josephine is owned by the bell family and her mistress is not well she has been kind to josephine at times over the years and has taught her to read and write she has also taught her how to draw and paint mrs bell is an artist and josephine often finishes her artwork when she is unable in the present day the artwork is the center of the story there is controversy over whether or not mrs bell had in fact created the artwork herself or whether it was done by someone else the story had promise but it didn't quite play out the way i had hoped it would i thought for a while that it might be a courtroom drama type story and the forensics of the artwork itself would be discussed i like legal dramas and i was hoping it might develop into one trying to focus on two different characters left the story fractured i felt the author gave both characters short shrift i didn't particularly care about lina or her father so those parts of the story dragged for me i also did not like the ending of the story at all i would not personally recommend it but it has a number of glowing reviews on both amazon and goodreads

raw_text.508: i liked this book i wasn't thrilled with the choice because we tend to steer away from 'political' discussions in our book club it seemed to me that reparations for slavery would make for a charged conversation but that wasn't the main focus probably because it wasn't the main focus in the book either it was a way to get the story going i thought both of the stories interesting and the way ms conklin intertwined them was creative the story of josephine seemed very realistic and i kept hoping to hear of her escape the story set in the current day didn't seem as realistic it was a great story though and i'm glad there was a relatively happy ending for that character i will say that some of the descriptions used seemed endless i know that the author was trying to show the vast differences between the 1850s and today but some of these could have been shortened considerably i enjoyed reading more about the underground railroad it made me begin doing some research to read some additional books about that subject i would recommend this book to anyone who would like a short fairly easy read that you can pick up and put down as needed maybe when you're busy or at the beach i look forward to seeing what else ms conklin writes
raw_text.509: the house girl is a very interesting and enlightening book it is not my favorite by tara conklin but it does have many qualities and opens up many emotions regarding slavery and family life the story goes back and forth between josephine a 17 year old house slave in virginia in the mid 1800's and lina a new york lawyer who was raised by her father lives in brooklyn with him he is an artist and is working on a case where her client is looking for reparation for all slaves lina also gets involved in researching an artist who happens to be the woman who josephine served during the book lina meets jasper a librarian by day musician by night who may be a descendant of josephine also the case she is working on has her questioning her choice of career thoughts about her mother and just life in general she is involved in josephine's story by reading old letters and doing research regarding the artist josephine's story is just very sad however she does leave legacies of her own which shows how fighting for what you need and want can be successful for your family she seems like a wonderful beautiful person inside and out and for me she touches lina and influences lina not to waste her life very good and heartfelt read

raw_text.531: i enjoyed the book very much finding it to be a page turner that pulled me in and caused me to care very much about the outcomes for all of the characters the parts of the narrative that take place in the past in the 1860's when slavery was still a reality but abolitionists were growing in strength and number were compelling and horrifying the story line in modern day new york wasn't quite as strong but i still found lina and her father oscar to be likeable and engaging the plot covers multiple stories taking place in both timeframes and includes a bit of a mystery what keeps this novel from getting higher marks is that the author tried to tell too many stories at once which kept her from going quite deep enough into any of them the result is that the past and the present aren't quite woven together in a way that makes connections between josephine the house girl and lina who uncovers her history nonetheless it was an interesting story and i would recommend it as a lighter read

raw_text.543: this book had the potential to be a good story but never quite made it there for me in fact i ended up being so distracted and irritated by the author's errors that it was hard for me to even care about the characters or what became of them the author wrote well about being a lawyer in the north but i got the feeling she has never visited virginia and the areas she used as the setting for the main part of her story i would recommend that she do a little more research before using actual locations in her writing and then taking such license with details otherwise just use a fictional county or town so local readers are not taken aback charlotte county virginia is not 45 minutes from richmond and certainly not on a major interstate where you would cross 5 lanes of traffic to get to the median the town the author calls stanton is indeed pronounced that way but spelled staunton i know this doesn't seem like a big deal but when i find errors like these throughout the book it just makes the whole thing seem distorted and fake

raw_text.552: what a remarkable book in addition to being spellbound by the story i was also completely awed by the author's ability to create or re create worlds and to populate them with very real people people with their own history so many topics were part of this book but not in a trite or stereotypical way slavery race intellectual theft underground railroad reparations and more at first i worried that i'd be unable to keep track of the two main characters josephine a 17 year old house slave on an impoverished tobacco farm in virginia in 1852 she seemed to be more of a lady's maid to missus lu lu anne belle the other main character was lina a brilliant young lawyer living in brooklyn with her renowned artist father oscar sparrow in the early 21st century the story itself was so absorbing that i had no difficulty in keeping each young woman's background clear in my mind the story twists and turns oddly bringing the two young women together in a way this was a thoroughly enjoyable read do not pick this up unless you have time to devote to reading it otherwise your other tasks will remain undone

raw_text.560: tara conklin intertwines the story of two women josephine bell a virginia house slave who in 1853 is trying desperately to escape to freedom and lina sparrow a new york attorney looking for a plaintiff to serve as lead plaintiff in a class action suit in 2004 to compel the payment of reparations for descendants of slaves the story is hung together by the discovery of some artwork that is thought to have been painted by josephine bell although heretofore attributed to her white owner the slave story is by far the more compelling we read of harsh treatment unsuccessful escapes and finally her trip on the underground railroad the characters are well drawn believable and the story hangs together beautifully the reader is emotionally drawn into the life of josephine given insight into the extreme conditions slaves endured both in captivity in the south and throughout the ordeal of the escapees lina's story on the other hand is a bit sparse i found it difficult to relate to this young woman who seems to have no backbone in her job whose researching skills are lacking and who seems to be on the receiving end of several fortuitous happenings i couldn't quite figure out if the plaintiff she was pursuing was also meant to be a romantic interest and i found the whole reparations story a wee stretch as did the plaintiff the story of josephine and her paintings carried the book the platform of the reparations case was quite unsteady and the ending really left me hanging overall the book is still worth reading if for no other reason than for the clear picture of slave life and the hopelessness of their situation reparations may be called for i just wish the author had made a better case for them and found a more convincing plaintiff and built a more persuasive case

raw_text.579: when i first started reading the house girl by tara conklin i had a little trouble getting into the novel set in the mid 1800's and alternately in 2004 the book traces the intersecting lives of josephine bell a slave in antebellum virginia and carolina sparrow a young lawyer with artist parents in new york city i really enjoyed josephine's perspective but it took some time for me to warm up a bit to lina's character and story the two main characters are as different as can be with lives that would normally have no connection but sometimes lives intertwine in the least expected ways drudging through her first year at a law firm lina is intent on making it to each new goal however soul sucking it may be but when her boss throws her a new and unique case lina's world begins to open up as she dives into a massive reparations case for slavery in the united states as she researches her case searching for a lone plaintiff to represent the many lina discovers a new controversy brewing on the art of a luanne bell not being her own but that of her house girl josephine from here things begin to get interesting as lina delves deeper on a hunt for the truth i enjoyed most parts of this novel and was pleasantly surprised with the twists in the ending although i found lina's ending to be flat and it all was a bit rushed also there were too many parts of the plot that turned out just right in the nick of time not like real life at all while josephine 's story drew me in i never really liked lina or really got to know her i suppose she is getting to know herself in the novel but i wanted more of a connection with her story and i never felt i really got below the surface there was a lot to explore that was not in addition the section of letters got to be monotonous and would have benefited from being broken up a bit to keep interest i really enjoyed her writing which was smooth and flowed nicely a bit heavy on descriptions in some places but a great first novel i liked it but i look forward to reading her next novel

raw_text.601: the house girl is a frustrating missed opportunity of a novel which lacked direction and suspense the premise of the novel is good and the subject matter is certainly worth investigating the complete and utter lack of acknowledgement for the contribution slavery towards the advancement of america and other nations in modern society was absolutely astounding to me conklin also does a pretty good job of looking at how art is a medium for emotional release through the complex lives of the characters sadly the writing style just wasn't for me there was a significant lack of tension with coincidence following coincidence and the plot advancing in a way that was too simple and linear the main character lina is an absolute flake who is thoroughly loathsome the passages of description also lacked variety with words like sliver and dark popping up time and time again the novel also relies heavily on the use of letters written by the characters which are all written in the same style despite the character who wrote them they also become very wearisome as the plot advances through massive infodumps that felt like they would never end a worthy message for sure but the writing isn't strong enough to deliver it

raw_text.612: it's hard to believe that this is a debut novel tara conklin has beautifully written an emotional story of a young woman slave in virginia in 1852 and skillfully connects that story to a young woman an attorney living in present day new york city she brings history to life with josephine's story and we see the cruelties of slavery the desire for freedom and the courageous fight for it i love the alternating narratives of josephine and lina and how lina's story helps unfold the story of josephine the artist the writing is so good that you can almost see the paintings as they are described and almost feel what the characters feel i have read a number of books recently which use the mechanism of alternating narratives of past and present and i really like it when the stories truly connect in an important way the author has done just that i was so taken with josephine and i found lina's story captivating as well josephine's story will break your heart but what lina does to insure that josephine's story is told is ultimately uplifting

raw_text.616: the house girl switches frequently between the present day career minded new york city lawyer named lina and a slave on a southern plantation in the 1985s named josephine lina begins to research artwork that was produced on the plantation as part of a slavery retribution case she is handling with her knowledge of art due to her upbringing lina begins to research if a slave was most likely the true creator of the masterpieces lina then searches for the descendants of the slave josephine among the present day u s population this book had a really slow start the author likes to describe scenes in detail including inserting sentences seemingly at random as if the character is scanning a room taking inventory i must admit i literally nodded off a few times as the book swam in the details thankfully i stuck with the book the storyline picked up after about 100 pages the characters began to develop and the book truly improved to be good historical fiction a book must be accurate and believable a few of the plot twists in the house girl were very coincidental down to the fact that lina had such a impressive background in art due to her upbringing and she was able to use her art knowledge as a high powered lawyer the tracking down descendants idea was also a bit tedious and the findings a bit too coincidental and fictional as a debut novel though this really is a good book overall the characters are interesting although i did like the slave josephine as a lead character much more than i liked lina i do hope tara conklin writes more stories with the same amount of historical research but with a lot fewer detailed descriptions ftc disclosure lavish bookshelf received this product complimentary from the publisher on behalf of tlc book tours in exchange for an honest review the opinions in this review are solely the opinion of the author lavish bookshelf was not required to provide a positive review and did not receive any further compensation
raw_text.617: this review does contain a few spoilers i believe none are detrimental to reading the book i really enjoyed this book it was a refreshing read for me a deviation from young adult it was eye opening about the lack of realistic awareness about slavery today more than anything it was relaxing to read my heart rate didn't change very much while i read i love a book where you become completely involved with the characters i have nearly nothing in common with lina who lives in the same time period as me and even less in common with josephine i felt for them yet i was not forced to put myself in their shoes and analyze what i would do in a similar situation this also applies to the authors of letters that you read with the narrator the letters are written the way you would expect their authors to write each person has a different realistic voice to begin with lina as i already said i do not have much in common with her she is a young lawyer at a fairly prestigious law firm in new york i don't know much about law firms but i believe the industry is accurately portrayed in this book lina keeps odd and strenuous hours in order to fulfil the wishes of her superiors and give herself the best opportunity for further success however unlike some of her colleagues she works with passion and devotes her heart to each case at least those that the reader hears about when she is assigned to the apparition case she does not merely look to find a suitable plaintiff she latches onto the idea of a josephine bell descendant as the "perfect plaintiff" and pursues it to completion throughout the book she is also struggling with difficult family situation for most of her life it has been just her and her dad oscar an artist at times she appears to be close to him but missing a mother in her life divides them during her childhood oscar refused to discuss her mother with her lina does not really understand her father they still live together in her childhood home but do not speak frequently when oscar devotes his new show to pictures of her mother it affects her deeply emotionally unanswered questions continue to haunt her what i liked most about lina was her ability to find moments of enjoyment in her stressful life she is struggling to meet crazy deadlines and still accepts invitations on the spur of the moment it was interesting to me to see how people don't always structure their lives every time she met with someone or did something impulsive i thought "you have a job and a deadline to meet " she was okay with letting herself forget her job for a moment for once when reading a book the character did something i would never consider and i understood why the alternation between josephine's story and lina's was refreshing they were woven together perfectly to keep the reader guessing josephine was a slave in the mid 1800s she was a house slave for lu anne bell a women afflicted with a tumor in comparison to other slaves missus lu treats josephine well and while he is harsher so does mister bell the part of the story the reader hears from josephine's perspective consists of only the day she decides to run yet in that day the reader learns so much about her life this part of the story fits nicely with the part that comes from lina's research and the reader does learn her whole story without mentioning details i will say that i agree with lina about the sense of loss she felt when she learned josephine's complete story the story addresses a subject that remains sensitive even in the twentieth century although not as prevalent as earlier in history race is still an important characteristic in society today people are not blind to skin color but it must be admitted that racial oppression in severely limited opinions may be mixed on the apparitions' case lina works on in the book there will always be questions regarding compensation for descendants of slavery however as stated by garrison how it would be determined who is eligible jasper who is described as "too white " had african american ancestry lina states that "the damage is immeasurable " this is all too true beginning with slavery from the beginning of the country and extending to the civil rights movement and further african americans have to say the least been treated horribly this book addresses conflicts between black and white but is not solely about that i don't think tara conklin wrote this book to give her opinion on compensation for descendants it is more meant to raise awareness about the history that is lost to many people today on page 60 lina asks herself these questions in reference to the slaves "why didn't lina know their names why hadn't she studied their histories where was the monument where was the museum what had they wished for worked for and loved " these could not be truer we really don't hear much from reading other reviews i can see that other people are upset about the lack of resolution in lina's family relationship while a satisfying conclusion would not hurt the book i can see why the author left it out the book was not really just about lina's life

raw_text.659: i had high hopes for this book i usually like stories that span generations and this one alternating viewpoints between a slave girl in the mid 1800s and a novice nyc lawyer in 2004 seemed promising carolina sparrow the contemporary lawyer is charged with finding a descendant of the house girl josephine in order to settle a reparations lawsuit i did enjoy josephine's story probably because of the historical aspect but much was left unsaid in my opinion on the other hand too much was going on in lina's storyline several simultaneous plots that i didn't really care about mostly because i didn't care for lina i found her to be shallow and whiny and disconnected i hated the way the author finally solved the conflict which was a meandering bridge to nowhere the long narrative explanatory letter conveniently falling into lina's hands was amateurish and disappointing
raw_text.660: it took me a while to get into this book but it was worth keeping on with it the story intertwines the lives of josephine bell a house girl slave in virginia in the 1800s and carolina lina sparrow an attorney and daughter of a well known artist in present day new york city josephine bell is rumored to be the true artist behind a series of works by the acclaimed artist luanne bell and when a show opens in new york lina happens to meet someone who claims to be her descendant at the show's opening which is exciting for lina who has just been assigned a reparations case at her law firm which needs a descendant from a slave to be the face of the case the book goes back and forth providing details on josephine's life and then also details about the modern day life of lina lina is also dealing with her father's sudden interest in a show devoted to his wife and lina's mother who was killed in a car crash when lina was small the story is told in a way that weaves together the themes of family truth work values and makes the reader anxious to see it all resolved my biggest complaint with this book was that like many other newer books the ending seemed rushed you go through a very long detailed story and then it seems that all of a sudden in the last 20 pages everything is rushed along and the book is over i keep feeling that the author tired of the story or the editor did major chopping but i find it frustrating having said that this is a good read

raw_text.718: in this split narrative tale dealing with slavery and the legacy of slavery tara conklin has created a well written and interesting story i wasn't a massive fan of the house girl but i found it to be worth reading and would probably recommend it to other readers depending on the reader though the central character in this book is josephine a slave girl a good portion of the book is narrated from josephine's perspective covering one very specific day in 1852 the rest of the book takes place in the present where lina a lawyer is trying to find out what happened after josephine disappeared from public record in 1852 hoping to find some of josephine's descendents i generally have a lot of trouble with the split narrative style of approaching historical fiction it doesn't work for me since generally speaking the real story is what happened in the past while the present day characters are simply uncovering the real story so to my mind the present day story becomes unnecessary as all it does is add a framework to the real story that's basically how i felt about the house girl lina's sections which take up the majority of the book were only interesting when they pertained to josephine i think that conklin could have possibly managed to tell the story just as effectively if it had all been narrated in the past without jumping forward to the future sure the basic structure of the book would have to be changed quite a bit and some of the impact in certain areas would be lost but it could be regained in other areas probably all that really depends on personal taste however lina who is really the main character of the book even if the focus isn't on her was still interesting and sympathetic she has a bit of a backstory concerning her dead mother and artist father and though at times it felt entirely irrelevant i think without that side plot lina would not have presented as fully developed writing wise the house girl was well done the sections on law and art and history all seemed legitimate and the story had a nice flow to it i can't say that conklin's prose is my favorite thing ever but it wasn't bad at all so overall the house girl is a good book it didn't blow me away exactly but i liked it and was entertained the conclusion was satisfying and the characters were ones i could take an interest in though it's not a civil war book this would probably appeal to fans of those types of stories reviews u0026amp more at respiring thoughts

raw_text.721: this was really a wonderful book i read it for one of my f2f book groups the story moves back and forth between the past when a young slave girl called josephine is trying to decide if she wants to try running again now that she knows her missus is dying soon and the present where lina sparrow an attorney is being asked to begin preparing a brief for a class action lawsuit seeking reparations for the descendants of american slaves lina's parents are both artists but her mother died a number of years ago and she was raised by her father interwoven into her legal assignment there is also an artistic argument in progress because josephine's missus was luanne bell a noted painter of portraits of the various slaves who worked on her farm over the years there has been more and more evidence to support the idea that josephine actually painted the portraits rather than luanne as we hear about josephine's life we learn her back story and discover that she was indeed an accomplished artist and it falls to present day lina to not only find one of josephine's descendants but to make that descendant the designated plaintiff in the class action suit i thought this story was seamless and coming from a debut author i will be looking forward to seeing what ms conklin tackles next an interesting premise and a compelling read full of wonderful historical detail

raw_text.765: i took me a long time to finish this book because i kept finding excuses not to read it i didn't enjoy it and had to force myself to finish the premise is a really good one i've never even thought of a slave owner taking credit for the artistic talent of one of their slaves it makes perfect sense and i was really looking forward to exploring the idea the fact that an attorney could sue for reparations 150 years later was fascinating to me who would pay who was at fault since those who lied about the origin of the art have been dead for generations that all showed promise my biggest problem was with lina i didn't like her at all and found the idea that she was in the dark about her mother ridiculous she is a grown woman an attorney and has been called a great researcher and investigator i don't want to spoil anything here but the mystery surrounding her mother's death was a big part of my disappointment with this book let's put aside lina's ability to look into the matter herself we find that grace her mother was a fairly well known artist in her own right lina runs into people who knew her every single instance of this made me more frustrated ask a question so you don't want to investigate ok ask a damn question or two i understand that the reason conklin wrote the story alternating between lina's and josephine's povs was so that we would have a reason to question josephine's art i feel the story could have been told just as well without lina without the back and forth a simple narrative of josephine's life with perhaps a prologue or afterward explaining the controversy surrounding the art today would have been much easier to read there have been many many plots that i feel are wasted in a bad writer's hands i would never encourage plagiarism but sometimes i really wish a better writer could be given a turn at an idea

raw_text.784: i chose this book based on the review by one of my friends and i am glad i read it the chapters go back and forth between josephine a house slave in virginia in 1852 and lina an attorney in new york in 2004 i normally don't like this technique but it was handled so well by the author that i felt it added to the book lina has been assigned a class action law suit requesting reparations for slavery as she searches for a suitable descendant to be the face of the lawsuit she finds that paintings attributed to josephine's mistress might have been painted by josephine the controversy surrounding the identity of the artist rocks the art world my friend found the chapters of the book that describe josephine's life to be the most interesting i enjoyed lina's chapters more although parts of her personal story could have been omitted since they didn't add to the book at first i thought this was going to be the typical slave book with the slave being beaten and mistreated on every page it was more interesting than that because josephine had an unusual relationship with her mistress although it was illegal josephine's mistress had secretly taught her to read her mistress was a painter and she allowed josephine to paint alongside her part of what bothered me about the controversy was that josephine's mistress did complete some paintings although they were apparently not as good as josephine's the impression left by the book was that she did not paint anything much of the book was sad and the lives of the main characters were sad so it is not a feel good book but it was interesting reading i am going to recommend it to my book discussion group as i feel there is plenty of fodder for discussion

raw_text.842: although i found the house girl interesting enough to finish i felt that the execution of this story didn't live up to the hype the book's title and first chapter chronicle the personal narrative of josephine - a young female slave in antebellum virginia - and then the book sets up a corresponding tale of lina a modern day lawyer researching the slave girl's story in preparation for a historic lawsuit chapters continue back and forth between 19th century josephine and 21st century lina providing first person perspective for each woman's life but less than a third of the way in lina's story takes primary focus and josephine is no longer a speaker in the tale instead she becomes the subject of other's conversations and that is the problem with the house girl without josephine's voice the book falls flat and i simply wanted to find out what happened to her as quickly as possible so i could leave all other characters behind as i read the final paragraph of the house girl i found myself wishing that lina and josephine's stories had been told in separate books each character was interesting enough on her own but the author's attempt to link the two women through a single plot line came across as forced and losing josephine's perspective in her own tale was just lazy writing as if the author found it simpler easier to forgo historical fiction in favor of a modern tale for a writer as evocative as tara conklin this is truly a shame and it's a shame for me as a reader for it was josephine who interested me most so when i concluded the book i felt i'd been cheated out of hearing her tale

raw_text.849: the house girl by tara conklin follows an enslaved house girl josephine and young lawyer lina alternating chapters their stories are juxtaposed against one another the events leading up to josephine's escape from slavery in 1800's virginia and the the events leading up to an escape of sorts for modern day new york city attorney lina as she seeks to find a descendant of josephine as potential plaintiff in a class action lawsuit against the u s government for reparations josephine tends to an ailing barren woman and her aging husband on a virginia plantation nearing it's demise the field hands including the loving couple who raised josephine as their own until she was moved into the slave owner's house are aging and no new slave purchases are being made josephine makes these and other observations as she spends time between the house and the slave quarters and captures images of her beloved friends and the plantation with paint and canvas her mistress paints to pass the time and allows josephine paint and materials to create her own works of art the author does a decent job of conveying the harsh realities of slavery and what a young slave girl's inner world might have been like as she worked up her resolve to run lina is a bright young lawyer and daughter of a famous artist her search for a plaintiff for her case leads her to an art showing of paintings believed to have been painted by the house girl josephine but with no proof credit for the works are given to the mistress of the plantation it's at the art showing that lina decides she would find josephine's descendants losing her mother as a toddler and having only fragments of memories and her father's stories of her mother lina's mother is a mystery to her she learns from friends of her mother's that she looks very much like her dark hair olive skin latino heritage maybe she wondered because her mother named her carolina pronounced caro lee na even though they are an english speaking family eventually she begins to see that she has been deliberately kept in the dark about the details of her mother's life by her father's design while piecing together joesphine's past lina finds herself also piecing together her own when the reparations case came up i braced myself tara conklin the author is not a black person frankly i wasn't sure how she would handle the subject i was relieved as i read about the powerful black business man behind the lawsuit and his desire not to win the case but to force the country to have the conversation he desired acknowledgement of the hard work that slaves did to build this country and wanted the government to apologize and to pay up not with checks in the mail to every brown citizen but in monuments and community enrichment programs and a wall listing every name of every slave who died building the wealth that gave some of america's wealthiest families their riches he wanted to open the books he wanted a reckoning he made his motives clear to lina and her partner in an awesome bit of dialogue early on in the book that got me excited after that i was like okay tara let's see what you got here this book is beautifully written every character is richly developed there's a side story woven in about a family that helps on the underground railroad that is told almost completely in letters of correspondence that lina finds in archives and it had me turning pages so hard then there was one single unsent letter from the archives near the end of the book that spans about fifty pages that gave me so much life y'all the descriptions of the artwork in this book were so vivid that i feel like i'd recognize them if i ran across them it would be so cool if an artist were to create the paintings in this book and hold a real exhibit in new york city i can't imagine such a thing has never happened before if it hasn't let's hope an adventurous artists runs across my suggestion while i'm on the topic of making this book live and breathe with lina's story set in modern day new york city and josephine's in the antebellum south this book begs for a screenplay with amazing flashbacks in the right hands it could be an amazing film
raw_text.850: this was a hard book to get into there's a lot of background required at the beginning which made it seem a bit burdensome that being said the author is telling two stories so i had to take that into consideration one of my hobbies is genealogy so i was pleasantly surprised when i realized that it was the basis for this story the book tells the story of josephine bell a slave in virginia in the mid 1800 and a dispute over the authorship of pieces of art in 2004 lina is an attorney working for a law firm that has been hired to file suit for reparations for descendants of slaves josephine's wants to run the sordid world of slavery is told from her point of view how this one slave girl finds a way to make a place in 2004 is exciting or at least for me i wish genealogy was really this easy but it's nice to see a back story unfold and this was a good one during this quest for another person's family lina is discovering new pieces of her own and really starts coming into herself can't remember what made me decide to reach this book but i'm glad i did i would definitely recommend it others
