raw_text.862: i really enjoyed house girl by tara conklin the subject matter reparation for blacks african americans is one that i've always been interested in but this is the first time i'm aware that it's ever been taken on in a novel conklin wrote parrallel stories one that transported us back to the 1800 when slavery was still alive and well the other during modern day the transitions were seamless and it was easy to flashback or move forward without getting lose i must admit i'm generally pissed and upset when i read about slavery especially the horrors of it all as far as my ancestors were concerned and conklin didn't disappoint i felt a range of emotions actually rage as i read the stories of josephine lewis boo lula and all the others who came before them or experienced the same cruelty i'm not sure i know of any other group of people who were tramautized and treated as poorly as black folks in america who have not been paid reparations to which i say why not and for how long do we have to wait actually why do black folks always have to wait thankfully i'm not waiting as i don't believe at least during my lifetime that the us will ever make good on this matter house girl was engaging informative and enlightening i listened to the audiobook which was 14 hours long and finished it in two days because it was such a compelling read i highly recommend house girl to those who enjoy historical fiction and books about strong women of color as well as book clubs as this is a book that will make for a great discussion and one that you will probably think about long after you've read my only disappointment was the ending i felt like the author punked out since it was fictional i believe a more unpredictable ending could have been written in this case it would have been okay to take creative license to explore and travel a different road

raw_text.878: 4 7 2013 why was this novel so disappointing it has some interesting characters and wonderful scenes and it reads easily and enjoyably i loved lu anne bell josephine's mistress in the historical story and in the modern day story i loved oscar sparrow and porter scales conklin does a great job evoking the stress and absurdity of the life of a new york city corporate lawyer measuring one's billable hours in 6 minute increments vying for attention in every possible way forcing logic and reason on ridiculous situations for the sake of money and she manages to convey the brutal hopelessness of the life of a virginia slave of the 1840s pretty succinctly still that wasn't enough the biggest problem i think is the difficulty of joining the two narratives believably the appearance of the perfect plaintiff and the finding of the long lost letter solving the central mystery of the novel both novels really are wildly improbable it was too much of a stretch to make it work almost as frustrating are the tenuous parallels conklin tries to draw between the two stories the lost mother the secrets that are revealed to each heroine the circuitous route to true love what do they add up to i could never quite make them work never figure out how the motifs of each story reflected or added meaning to that motif in the other or maybe i didn't feel like trying almost as bad i think conklin will with practice and good editing be a great writer there are flashes here images that jumped out at me characters portrayed in two quick but perfect lines scenes that flowed with a lovely rhythm but much of the writing is rather workaday just getting the reader to the next piece of information at times i'd think does she really need to tell me this detail or include this random character or show off her research so extensively editing as usual it seems would have helped here

raw_text.880: the house girl is told from two points of view in two different time periods lina sparrow is an ambitious young lawyer working on a historic class action lawsuit seeking reparations for the descendants of american slaves in 2004 josephine is a seventeen year old house slave who tends to the mistress of a virginia tobacco farm in 1852 tara conklin does a wonderful job of tying these two women together through the art of the slave girl lina's father is a renowned artist and her mother has been dead for twenty years through her father she discovers a controversy rocking the art world art historians now suspect the paintings of lu anne bell were really the work of josephine the house girl a descendant of josephine's would be the perfect person for the lawsuit if lina can locate one lina convinces her boss that she needs to travel to virginia to research the background on the bell farm and discover information about josephine there she meets a musician who turns out to possibly be the great great great great grandson when she returns with the proof the law office has decided to drop the reparations plan now lina rethinks her future in the firm and learns from her father that her mother didn't die but left her father and her with this new knowledge that her mother wants to reunite with lina the possibility of a new life is offered to the woman who wanted nothing else but make partner in the law firm this is cleverly conceived and written giving the reader insight into the horrors of slavery

raw_text.907: the house girl tells the story of two women lina sparrow in the present who is working on a reparations case for the descendants of slaves josephine in the past who is a house girl for lu anne bell the mistress on a tobacco plantation lu anne is an artist but there's some speculation and controversy in the present that josephine might have been the real artist lina's job of finding a suitable plaintiff leads her to dig into josephine's story and discover secrets of not only josephine's life but her own i loved this book it was well written and extremely interesting i enjoyed both parts of the story but i think i enjoyed the one that takes place in the past a little more mostly for reasons i explain below the art and the whole the art world were particularly enthralling to me i don't know a lot about art but i found it captivating nevertheless to present this story the author jumps back and forth between the past 1852 and the present day 2004 secrets were uncovered and the details unfolded roughly at the same time in the story showing the symmetry between them a perfect format for this type of story both of the major women characters were strong determined and very appealing i especially loved josephine's determination to get away i really enjoyed the letters dot wrote to her sister i've seen letters used many times in books and quite frankly i was a bit tired of it i really wasn't looking forward to reading them however these were so well done i felt like i was reading a piece of history they had me totally hooked a couple of things about the story bothered me a little first when lina was looking for a descendent of josephine she stumbled upon one a little too readily something like that could have and perhaps should have taken years second the reparations case wrapped up a little too quickly perhaps this happens in real life but it felt rushed to me because of these two things i didn't love the present day story as much as i could have highly recommended i'd definitely read another book by this author for more information about this book please visit the harpercollins website i'd like to thank those nice people at william morrow for this review copy the house girl by tara conklin william morrow harpercollins (c)2013 isbn 9780062207395 advance reader's edition 368p this review can also be seen on my blog daisy's book journal

raw_text.989: ahh another place that requires a half star this is a strong 3 5 stars for me it took me a while to get drawn into this book i was skeptical about the slavery reparations lawsuit that serves as a catalyst for lina sparrow's search and i feared another slave narrative however about half way through the book i realized i was in masterful hands conklin created vivid worlds and engaging characters in both 1852 and 2004 she created characters who i wanted to know for whom i rooted and about whom i cared she never settled for the trite or obvious plot points and brought the narratives to effective and satisfying closure i loved the focus on female artists and the questions of creativity love and relationships i think this novel would make a wonderful book club read because of the variety of complex themes involved and the many points through which readers can enter book the house girl is a care fully crafted exploration of identity gender slavery and familial relationships that i very much enjoyed
raw_text.990: the house girl tells two stories one is set in the 1800's and features a house girl josephine the other set in more modern time 2004 features lina sparrow a lawyer working on a reparations case i found the contrast of their two stories interesting and the novel highly readable however lina felt flat as a character in many respects and josephine was also often opaque in someways i found dorothea rounds harper one of the more intriguing characters in the book probably because we came to know her through her letters since i typically love character studies and or those books that can put me in a different place or time and feel like i am living and breathing it this novel was a short term pleasure vs one that earned a spot on a more permanent shelf

raw_text.1001: somewhere between three and four stars it's easy to tick off the flaws of this book the huge coincidence that lies in the plotting linking the 1850 story to the present day story for example or the passive nature of lina the echo of josephine not knowing or even seeming to care about her family or the last chapter a letter written by caleb harper who comes out of the blue and answers all our questions the idea that a billion dollar reparations case would be placed in the hands of two first year associates is a little far fetched too still it's an engrossing story once you get past the bothersome plot outlines it's nicely written the parallels between josephine and lina are neat and the underlying idea that much of what we believe are the achievements of america had their genesis in black labor black culture and black steadfastness is profound i'd happily read another tara conklin book think she's probably just getting her sea legs as a writer

raw_text.1011: i enjoyed this book because of its story about a young slave girl who dreams of running her complicated relationships with her missus her friends and people who are no longer around were really interesting her inner thoughts and questions about what it means to be free and what freedom is worth were also really interesting i was not nearly as interested in the present day story so my main complaint with the book is that i didn't enough of the title character and too much of lina i liked lina and i was somewhat interested in her story but juxtaposed with the house girl lina's job woes and romantic interests seemed petty and simpering it was hard to care i was especially annoyed when 3 4 of the way through the book lina is about to run and we cut to lina's love life with the totally forgettable love interest it was too late in the game to care about that all i wanted was to know what happened to josephine furthermore conklin sets up this mystery about lina's mother that is never really resolved there was a secret yes that we learned but the mystery of who her mother was and where she came from lead me and perhaps others to believe that there was something there related to josephine's story maybe the two women being artists was supposed to be significant and interesting but i didn't find that it added anything to either story overall i enjoyed the historical story but there wasn't enough of it

raw_text.1017: in 1852 17 year old josephine bell made the decision that she would run north to escape her life as a slave at bell manor josephine's day to day life was better than that of most slaves but that was only because of missus luann her missus had secretly taught her to read and allowed josephine to share luann's own love of painting despite all that josephine knew it was time to go master bell was making it a little dangerous for josephine to stay at bell manor in 2004 new york city lina sparrow hopes the new case she has been asked to work will be the one jump starts her law career and allows her to move away from clients whose names all end in llc she is to begin working on a precedent setting class action lawsuit worth millions in reparations for descendents of american slaves as she begins her research in hopes of finding a living descendent willing to act as lead plaintiff she stumbles upon josephine's story i'm not sure if the writing tool has been around for a long time or if by happenstance i am just picking up more books using the method but many authors lately are making use of the dual sometimes triple time line for some it succeeds and for others not so much in house girl it definitely adds to the story i would have found either story fascinating as a stand alone whether it were josephine's or lina's but ms conklin weaves them together beautifully allowing the reader to slowly see the parallels i was interested enough to check out the two websites the author lists in her acknowledgements and can safely say house girl is well researched historical fiction

raw_text.1028: i really enjoyed this novel great writing compelling story telling and an intricate and lovely structure helped make an almost unbelievable story and one of the main characters in the book acknowledges the incredible luck she has absolutely unforgettable a summation of the story two smart young women are connected by art and a search for justice although separated by time one is josephine bell a house slave owned by an aspiring but lackluster artist middle aged woman in virginia just prior to the civil war is a perceptive smart and talented young woman with dreams and hopes she does dare to realize despite the tremendous obstacles of her day the other is carolina sparrow a young new york lawyer who lives with her artist father and who lost her mother at an early age smart and intuitive lina is given a difficult and important case by her boss at the firm where she works involving reparations for the years of slavery endured by african americans she must find a face for the case a descendant of a slave chapters alternate between the women's very disparate and not so lives and stories interspersed by old letters that hold clues to long forgotten events when i finished reading this novel i thought to myself it really is just too good to be true but in this case the end truly justifies the means i was completely brought into the story by ms conklin's evocative imagery and storytelling the motif of birds throughout the novel especially their sounds and the freedom they represent are beautifully and delicately placed and i loved that as a bird lover watcher it caught my attention right from the first time i saw the cover which i hope they keep this is a novel written by a white woman about a very difficult subject slavery as well as the reparations apologies by the us government that might could be awarded to descendants of slaves at some future time ms conklin has an amazing cv so i'm not surprised she was able to write such an amazing story and she is also a lawyer don't even start to compare this novel to something like the help which i also enjoyed or gone with the wind just a totally different kind of novel altogether this book is not about an era we can hardly fathom anymore ms conklin places you back in mrs bell's bedroom with josephine as her closest companion and confidant yet the fear of the master and the yearning for freedom is palpable it is not some long distant memory it is today right now as you are reading and lina's story learning who she is and who her mother was is also a struggle for freedom and independence yet somehow these two disparate times and places antebellum virginia and contemporary new york city meld together it becomes a story about relationships that we can't understand even though we are part of them it is all about the mystery of being human our rights and freedoms being upheld and celebrated compare this novel with chris cleave's little bee little bee the character is very much like josephine and lina yearning searching finding resolution while not perfect and certainly not always timely can be achieved an inspiring first novel

raw_text.1057: i picked up this book because my own southern heritage drives me to read stories that might shed light on the truths of slavery in america especially when they are stories about women i dug into this book with enthusiasm on a friend's recommendation and was a little taken aback when the art studio appeared in the 1850s virginia home you see i'm also a painter oh neat thought i it's also a book about an artist these are all my favorite themes all rolled into one but alas i can only suspend disbelief for so long for one thing southern women did not paint not even as a little creative hobby why because paint materials were absolutely not available perhaps if missus lu had been written as a very well connected worldly northerner who could have conceivably had ultramarine blue powder shipped to her by a source located in philadelphia or new york maybe in the book american painters on technique the colonial period to 1860 researchers lance mayer and gay myers discuss the techniques and materials that were available to artists in america from 1830 1860 and after flipping through a book like that it becomes eminently clear why we have no famous painters from the antebellum south this was a place for farmers and merchants not painters and sculptors also please don't get me started on why the slave girl would not have been permitted --at all--to touch the painting supplies should they have been available it would have been a stretch for slaveholders of that time to entertain the idea that josephine might have possessed of the talents or gifts we humans might enjoy this was by all accounts a dark place and time--not without its moments of love and happiness surely--but not the rosy picture that conklin conjures in this very very fictional book and there lies the shame of it

raw_text.1061: i really enjoyed this book which was told through characters living in nearly present day new york and 1852 virginia in new york we meet lina a young ambitious lawyer working for a practice that is developing a case worth trillions in reparations for the descendants of american slaves she has to find the perfect plaintiff to make this case in virgina we meet josephine a house slave who longs to escape her situation though she has been taught to read by her mistress and been given the opportunity to paint and draw which she has a great talent in those are the bare bones of the story line there are depths to the characters that we get to explore through their relationships the uncovering of their histories and all the supporting characters from lina's successful artist dad and the memory of her absent mother to the pivotal assistants in the underground railroad and slavery itself as other reviews have said i'd love to know 'then what ' when it come's to lina at the end of the story so i'd be all for another book that follows her into the next leg of her journey

that the house girl was very promising at the beginning there are two separate story lines involving a runaway slave named josephine and a young attorney named carolina lina sparrow who works for a corporate law office in new york city lina's story takes place in 2004 and josephine's tale begins in 1852 in a small town in virginia lina is assigned to work on an unusual and possibly precedent setting case involving reparations for the descendants of slaves using a list with the names of many slaves she must track down some of the descendants a task that proves to be very difficult if not impossible the book alternates between modern day new york and antebellum small town virginia where josephine works as a house girl for the bell family although she is a slave she is treated better than most of the slaves who work on the farm her mistress missus lu teaches her to read and to paint josephine's artistic ability far eclipses that of missus lu lina lives in a comfortable brownstone apartment with her widowed father oscar oscar has never remarried since the tragic death of his wife when lina was only four because lina was so young when her mother passed away she remembers little and has a hard time sorting her memories from the few details she was told the stories of the two women lina and josephine begin to converge when one of oscar's friends an art gallery owner puts on a exhibit featuring the works of lu anne bell lu anne died in 1852 her talent as an artist was recognized posthumously however some controversy has arisen over whether she actually painted some of the works she is credited with some experts believe that her slave josephine might really have painted some if not most of them after lina finds out about the paintings she wonders if she might have found a promising lead that could help her case the point where the wheels came off the wagon pun intended was when lina begins reading a biography written about a famous female abolitionist and suffragist who was a contemporary of josephine's the biography contains letters written by the subject's sister dorothea whose family lived near the bell farm dorothea accidentally found out that her father was involved in covert activities on behalf of the underground railroad helping runaway slaves to escape to the north her father makes dorothea promise not to tell anyone about it the first thing that blabbermouth dorothea does is write a letter to her newly married sister detailing all of the secret activities in which her father is involved she doesn't even bother to encode the letters i wondered why she didn't arouse suspicion on the part of the post master or whoever was handling the letters in the small town where she lived because of the sheer number of letters she sent to one person over a short period of time dorothea said that she sealed her letters with wax but anyone could have broken the seal and read the contents then i wondered why her sister hadn't burned the letters after she read them if they contained such incriminating details why had the letters survived for over 100 years furthermore dorothea confides in a young boy whom the family has taken in after his mother was murdered in my opinion it would have been more believable if dorothea had recorded the events in her diary instead of sending the letters to her sister but that's the route the author chose some other readers have also mentioned the unusually large number of coincidences in the novel i agree with them in a nutshell i started off with high expectations i'll finish the book since i am reading it for a book group but i really wish the author hadn't introduced the character of dorothea certainly the family's efforts to help the runaway slaves were admirable and would have been even more so if dorothea had just kept her mouth shut more

raw_text.1187: as seen on my blog 4 5 starsi am in awe and completely humbled by the wealth of knowledge that people are able to accumulate in a lifetime in not even half a lifetime i love that could win it had heart an endless stream of emotion it had moments that stopped your breath and more times than not gripped your heart so tight you feared you would never recover set in alternating chapters of the 1800's and present day the house girl wove a tale surrounding an injustice a mystery a loss and eventually the realization of many truths josephine bell and carolina sparrow were beautifully dynamic characters both of them were immersed in a world that held true to their standards their laws it was through both of these characters that tara conklin really shone her knowledge raw_text.1198: an advance copy of the book was provided by william morrow harper collins through goodreads giveawaythe house girl is about two lives that intertwine through many years lina is a present day lawyer who is assigned to the case of a lifetime she must find a plaintiff in a lawsuit trying to award descendants of slaves their reparations in her research she finds josephine josephine is a house slave in 1852 that desperately wants to be free she tried once to runaway and is now ready to try again josephine's life will impact lina's in ways that seem impossible i thought that this book was gonna blow me away i thought i was definitely giving a 5 star rating but sadly that wasn't the case i really loved josephine's story her voice spoke to me and got me invested in her struggle as a slave that craves freedom her relationships with her masters and fellow slaves were intriguing and unique i was rooting for her story to be a happy one and in a sense it was i didn't like lina for most of the book i understood that she was the catalyst for digging deeper into josephine's history but lina's own story was kinda uninteresting the secrecy about her mother was the high point of her chapters it paralleled nicely with the mystery of view spoiler what happened to josephine's baby hide spoiler finally towards the end of the book i grew to like lina and the characters around her like her father and the potential plaintiff jasper at the end of the book josephine was finding peace with her life while lina's life was finally seeming to begin the only issues i had with this book was were the letters that lina finds researching josephine they take up pages at a time without a break in between or from some input to what lina thinks about it i found myself skimming those parts even though they're essential to the overall story i don't know why but that's the only thing that bothered me
raw_text.1199: i did not want to put this book down i love how it went back and forth from the slave girl to the present girl looking for her good characters and well written i highly recommend this book
raw_text.1200: i just finished the house girl by tara conklin i liked this book and will recommend it to others i like the style of dedicating a chapter to one or several characters each character telling her story in her own words every once in a while i had to stop to get reacquainted with the speaker and where i was in time but that was a minor distraction there was good character development and all the characters had a distinct voice the backdrop of a lawsuit for reparations for descendants of american slave drove the modern story a short time line to get the paperwork submitted for the lawsuit pushed the story forward at a quick pace i was a bit disappointed in the ending for 2 reasons the long letter basically explaining the josephine bell part of the story seemed like a cop out it tied everything together the way an ending should but it seemed like taking the easy way out the rest to the book was well researched and then there was a summary in place of data i also thought the ending was predictable i didn't think it was a bad ending just that i saw it coming it also reinforced my dislike of mega money grubbing law firms not really part of the story like i said earlier the book had its short comings but overall i did like the book and will recommend it to anyone interested
raw_text.1201: i felt annoyed by this book the law suite was impossible and ridiculous it was like the author started the first half of the book thinking it was a great idea and then through her own research realized it was never going to pan out instead of re writing the whole story she simply used one of her characters to explain why the law suit wasn't going to work and from that point on in the book the author had to change her perspective and create a new reason for the modern day side of the story to be relevant the side of the book that featured the plantation slave girl was interesting but extremely repetitive the author forced us to re read the slave girl's life story over and over again each time adding a tiny bit of something new i felt like the author started writing the first chapter and never stopped she'd keep going until she hit a snag and instead of going back to change the book she just stopped that theme and continued on with a different a different one this book was compared to the help and was suppose to be on of the to read books of the year i'd have to disagree with both statements

raw_text.1228: i am so glad someone had recommended this book for our book club it is historical fiction written from the perspective of the main character josephine bell who was a house slave in virginia josephine was not just a house girl though she was an accomplished artist whose identity as such was snatched away from her what she and others endured during this extremely ugly time in american history ranks right up there with other major atrocities that human beings have suffered since the beginning of time i came to realize that slavery here in our own country has been covered up to some degree and one wonders just how many stories will lie uncovered forever how many families were broken and scattered with often no record of their mere existence adding in the aspect of genealogy truly had me thinking about all those beautiful god created human beings whose genealogy may forever and always be lost i've been my own family historian and genealogist for the last 20 plus years but had never given lost slaves much thought in that regard i certainly will from this point forward such sadness to contemplate my heartfelt thanks to ms conklin for her in depth research and for drawing on her own life experience to bring forth such a wonderful story

raw_text.1236: what could a white present day lawyer have in common with a black escaped slave from the 19th century in tara conklin's debut novel the house girl the two female protagonists--separated by centuries locations and skin color--seem at first to be opposites and yet as their stories unfold we see how similar these two women's journeys actually are both are determined by art by the respective houses in which they were raised and by a sense that they don't fully know themselves--because of the lies they've believed this expansive narrative is a high wire act which conklin executes with ease and panache the chapters alternate point of view from josephine the house slave to lina the type a lawyer in an ever tightening weave until the women's lives intertwine and lina in her search for justice discovers the truth if you like historical fiction mysteries and gorgeous writing you'll want to get your hands on the house girl just out in paperback last month

raw_text.1268: also posted at my blogthis is another novel set up with the two timeline style that seems to be popular especially for historical fiction in this case the past is 1852 and focuses on josephine a seventeen year old house slave at the bell estate who decides to run the modern day piece follows carolina lina sparrow first year associate at a corporate law firm in new york her mother is dead and her father is an artist that has finally found success after 20 years of not talking about her mother her father is finally ready to discuss her with lina and his latest show focuses entirely on portrayals of her mother grace at this same time she gets a huge case focusing on slavery and reparations their client runs a large business and his connections tell him the government is ready to issue an apology so he wants to capitalize on this opportunity given her connection to the art world lina hears about josephine bell and lu ann bell after years of lauding lu ann as a great artist that captured the reality of slavery with portraits of plantation life experts have started to believe that it was josephine's hand behind the brush rather than mistress bell's so far so good given that the case and the mother issues came up at the same time i expected the novel to find a connection between josephine and lina and for it to turn out that her mother is a descendant of josephine while predictable i would have had no issue with this development and enjoyed the way the threads connected however this isn't where the novel went so while i initially liked lina her story was quickly dragged down by too many plot points josephine's story was engaging but it quickly got drowned out with all of lina's issues basically i don't think the two plot lines worked together lina is in charge of finding a plaintiff to put a face to the victims of slavery and while she quickly sees how josephine and misidentified art would be a great angle her intense focus on this one aspect basically makes her look like an incompetent lawyer if the case had been about ownership of the art rather than slave reparations her intense focus on josephine to the exclusion of everything and every one else would have made sense if there was a connection between josephine and lina through her mother i would have believed it instead she is obsessed with finding a descendant that may not exist early in the novel she meets a man jasper who believes he is in the possession of josephine's work passed down as a family heirloom so lina's goal is to find the connection between jasper and josephine except that jasper doesn't identify as black and has tatoos and piercings none of these are a problem but when you are looking for the poster child for the past victims of slavery that's not exactly going to be what people are going to expect have you heard of the media lina you might want to make a statement about post racial america but it won't work in a case about reparations for slavery basically lina's blindness to the fact that jasper isn't the perfect plaintiff she's looking for or even close to a good one made her seem like an incompetent idiot she may be good at research but common sense sorely lacking as i said i enjoyed josephine and her story but the novel got bogged down by lina a large part of the gap is closed with a letter that explains everything that happens and while it was nice to get that narrative closure i would have preferred it if those chapters had continued to be told from josephine's perspective instead of discovering a document that spells everything out for lina i would have preferred if lina just had the bare bones so that i as the reader could have continued to hear more of josephine's voice i think i'm just frustrated because the novel started out promising before it irritated me and since lina's mother didn't tie into the josephine part of the story that whole plot point just seemed like a waste of time the cover is pretty gorgeous though
raw_text.1269: loved how in depth each of the characters is this book these characters have so many moving parts so many individual stories and yet none of them are superfluous as so often is the case when writers try to work in multiple narratives each of the stories is essential to the characters and their legacies yet can also stand strongly alone probably a result of the way conklin wrote the book first as a single short story then multiple short stories and finally a novel i also didn't feel that the reconciliation of the separate stories was forced or tied up too neatly with a pretty little bow it wasn't a pure fairy tale ending josephine bell's past might have been made more clear but the future for lina jasper oscar grace the legacy of josephine bell still contained many unknowns

raw_text.1279: while rereading my thoughts it does appear that i didn't enjoy this book i must say that these characters and this story will stick with me for quite a while i think the fact that i've edited this review more than once is testament to that thoughts on art on authorship on family and relationships on commercialization or bureaucratization of racism and reparations cases life and death loss written word connections lost and found etc there really is a lot to unpack in this little book and a lot i wish that had been unpacked or unpacked differently i'll begin by honestly saying i wish in the acknowledgments the author had not only listed her sources but paid homage to or acknowledged those people enslaved during the time in which this novel takes place i went into this book hesitant a white author writing about slavery in fiction makes me hold my breath especially when almost half the novel seems to come from the perspective of the woman the house girl who was enslaved with a white author a white perspective i couldn't help constantly wondering did she soften the house girl's treatment to soften our image of slavery is there an element of white guilt or even romanticization suffice to say i do feel that those worries aside i believe the author treated this topic with great reverence and the narrative of josephine the house girl was very beautifully written the circumstances of josephine's art and the politics involved in shining a light on rightful authorship were very compelling and reflect the indictment on many white people in power who are so hesitant to give credit to someone other while still attempting a facade of acceptance and compassion while the writing at times felt forced and the narrative at times was difficult to sew together many many people tell the story in this novel i must say the layers of narrative on the conceptual level are quite brilliant and i found the overarching story very compelling i do feel perhaps too much was crammed in here but i do think there's a smartness to its execution and a certain humanity in some of the characters at times the plot had elements that appeared almost unbelievable and i found myself wanting lina to simply get over herself when it came to her parents a twenty something year old lawyer still living with her dad unable to bear his going on dates with other women unable to bear thinking of her late mom as having had any flaws i found myself saying wait what more than once and the amount of letters in the book almost drove me batty overall i appreciated this book and enjoyed many elements but i am glad to put it down

raw_text.1326: originally posted at http olduvaireads wordpress com 201 for josephine there existed no greater joy than this the faint pepper smell of the homemade paper the gritty charcoal dust misting the space around her fingers her fingers moving faster than her kind could determine where to draw this line that shadow the picture emerging from her in a rush as though no distance existed between the paper and her mind's eye they inhabited the same interior space the same intimate world that belonged to her and her alone the house girl is the story of two women separated by a century and a half 1852 - 2004 and race the two interwoven tales hardly ever do i read a book told from just one perspective these days depict the contrasting lives of a slave girl and a modern day corporate grunt josephine has decided that today is the day a "gathering of disparate desires that before had been scattered" and that "today was the last day there would be no others "she is determined to leave to leave behind her missus lu to run run run and in modern day new york city lina sparrow first year litigation associate is assigned a new case a lawsuit for reparations on behalf of descendants of slaves lina at first takes on this new case just like any other she has worked on but when her artist father tells about about a controversy in the art world involving josephine the house girl of celebrated southern painter lu anne bell she is intrigued and believes they have made their case josephine's tale is one of uncertainty where to run when to go how far can she make it her own life as house girl is neither here nor there "she was just like the horse the chicken or cow something to be fed and housed to do what it was born and raised to do josephine was not of one world or the other neither the house nor the fields this she could not explain to them not even to lottie or winton that she belonged nowhere "and in a sense so is lina's story behind that confident exterior lies a young woman who longs to know what her mother was like as her father has refused for years to say anything about her "instead lina recalled only a vanishing an absence an ache "a woman who has buried herself in her work and for what "his words evoked in lina a combination of indignation and shame gone was her excited buzz and in its place a creeping nausea lina stood there in front of him motionless waiting for him to raise his eyes again so she could - what defend herself argue with him no she couldn't those kinds of exchanges didn't happen at clifton at least no between a partner and a first year associate she marveled at dan's poise the unapologetic exercise of his presumed right to be an ass "but something in the reparations lawsuit in josephine's story lights a fire in her and she throws herself into the research haunted by the paintings that she's seen attributed to lu anne bell such as one of children which "hit lina with a force she wasn't expecting in a way her father's paintings never had her reaction here was emotional not intellectual and for once she wanted to leave it at that without searching for clues to analyze references to dissect she couldn't explain why this boy's enigmatic face captivated her nor did she want to explain it looking was enough" and the reader unravels josephine's story alongside lina as she travels to virginia to locate evidence of josephine's descendant uncovering letters and documents that mention the house girl who in the only photograph of her is shown with "hands clasped before her the fingers tensely intertwined as though one hand pulled the other from a turbulent sea her eyes were fogged as if in motion perhaps she had looked beyond the photographer perhaps she had contemplated the road ahead "the house girl is the story of two women but josephine's tale is the far more compelling one whereas lina's first world problems sometimes just got in the way plus if she could research her way to josephine bell and her descendants couldn't she have found out more about her own mother lina's research also seemed a little too fruitful - open a notebook and all the right information jumps out at her sure i understand that there is a need to speed that part of the story along but as a former research assistant and journalist and graduate student who had once upon a time combed my way through various documents in the british library just pencils no pens listened to recorded interviews and read transcripts at the national archives of singapore made myself half blind flipping through microfilms at the national library of singapore i know how tedious research can be searching for that right interview for that right newspaper article that very page in that old book to find that one sentence that puts the "a" as in "aaaaahhhhh" - a big sigh of relief or the "ha " as in "hahahahahaha" - a sign of impending insanity back in "aha " so to be given what two weeks to find a plaintiff to comb through historical documents to find a descendant now that is well i wouldn't say impossible but just highly unlikely however this probably wouldn't be too big a deal for most readers it's probably just me so for me the book was more about josephine and a little about wishing there were less of lina perhaps it might have worked better as two separate books instead of two interwoven stories still despite its a terribly feminine cover the kind that induces me to not pick up a book it was a good read dramatic at parts with a variety of written forms - art essays historical letters - utilized to keep the narrative moving

raw_text.1339: the house girl relays the stories of two women josephine the house girl of the novel's title living about a decade before the outbreak of the civil war and lina a lawyer living in modern times working to find a plaintiff for a slave reparations class action lawsuit josephine is despite her station an accomplished artist with access to materials because her owner lu anne is also an artist though far less gifted lina is incidentally the daughter of two artists though her mother has been dead since lina was a very young child the two stories intersect when lina discovers that art attributed to lu ann was really created by josephine and that josephine has a living descendant who would make the ideal plaintiff for her lawsuit there's a lot going on in the house girl and if you can swallow some necessary but altogether too neat plot twists it's entertaining reading even if it stops short of being deeply satisfying josephine's story naturally illuminates the inhumanity of slavery and the extraordinary risks taken and sacrifices made by slaves who attempted escape but the novel is also concerned with freedom and identity and asks how we can love without losing ourselves josephine's story is a more compelling exploration of these themes and questions lina's long dead mother is more than lina herself the stronger parallel to josephine because lina's mother too is grappling with how to love without losing one's self thus the most interesting bits of lina's story were those that really belonged to her mother

raw_text.1432: in 2004 lina sparrow is a young lawyer chasing the typical lawyer dream of making partner she's just been put on a case that could make her name legendary a lawsuit against big name companies that might have benefited from the unpaid work of slaves seeking reparations for their descendants her main assignment on this case is to find a lead plaintiff through her research we learn about the life of josephine bell a house slave of a famous painter lu anne bell whose paintings are now being questioned as to whether or not lu anne was actually the artist or whether they were actually made by her slave josephine a big part of the house girl is made up of letters i was doubtful that i would be interested and oftentimes in the beginning wondered why conklin needed to include so much well by the end i was really glad for them and it was an effective way to gain information about the past in some ways this reminded me of the help though i think i liked the help better

raw_text.1436: when i read fiction i can excuse and overlook a lot of things and just read for the enjoyment of the story but when it comes to historical fiction i have higher expectations i realize some things have to be fictionalized in order to fill in the blanks there is only so much that can be derived from historical facts and records it just seemed like there were too many coincidences and convenient circumstances that were a little far fetched view spoiler from the time caleb met josephine through the ending which explained how she came to have descendents and what happened to her paintings and that sealed letter from caleb to joseph that had been hidden away all those years that was a bit over the top hide spoiler that being said i did like the book and enjoyed both the modern and the historical stories as they switched back and forth throughout the book the story was interesting and i had to keep reading to find out what happened to josephine the author did research and accurately portray many historical details it provided an interesting look at the life of slaves and their owners even though i felt some parts were far fetched and too convenient it still provided an interesting account of josephine's life as you can probably tell of the two stories modern and historical the historical was my favorite my rating 3 1 2 stars

raw_text.1438: this is tara conklin's debut novel though i find it reads more as that of a seasoned author two women from very different times are the protagonists josephine is the house girl of the title which is a nice way of saying that she is a slave who works in the house she is close with the mistress of the house who is very ill lina's story unfolds in present time where she is an up and coming attorney she is assigned to work on a case involving slave reparations josephine's story is far more compelling than that of lina's which makes sense josephine's life is never her own it doesn't matter whether or not she has feelings about anything or if she's tired or if she has an injury the work is there and she must do it she must take anything that is thrown at her without complaint i can't even begin to imagine what it was like to live that life but i think conklin is able to paint a realistic picture lina lives with her father a famous artist her mother was killed in an accident when lina was a toddler lina is her job she doesn't have room for anything in her life that doesn't involve making partner by the time she's thirty lina's story can't match up to josephine's of course it's kind of like how the academy awards the actress who allows herself to be made into the ugly duckling the swan cannot compete with that fine unless you are the black swan no pun intended i was glad to read more about the case for and against slave reparations first of all i can't imagine viewing another person as property i don't view my cat as property but i am not sure that reparations should be paid don't get me wrong i realize that so much of america was built on the backs of slaves however there is no one alive today who owned slaves or who was a slave i know for a fact that my family never owned slaves though at the time that part of the family lived in maryland and kentucky they were poor in doing some further reading apparently only 1 4 of southern whites owned slaves and surprisingly enough there were slaves in the northern states at one time too while i wish that the practice of slavery had never existed it was interesting to read that the culture from which the slaves came also kept slaves not to mention there's also indentured servitude so many people came to america as indentured servants and were often not released after the cost had been repaid and let's not forget the native americans many of whom were enslaved when the europeans arrived i'm not forgetting what the jews suffered at the hands of the nazis just trying to keep this discussion to the american history if there are reparations to be paid well probably everyone is owed something some interesting tidbits from the books what about the whole idea that there is no loss garrison said if you look at the numbers the african american population of the u s is in a far better economic position today than if they'd stayed in africa you could easily argue that the transatlantic slave trade brought them to this country which then gave their descendants the opportunity to take advantage of america's economic success i mean isn't any wrong done back then negated by the objectively better position we find ourselves in today as compared to the people who stayed in africa africans themselves kept slaves garrison said it was part of the culture chieftains of one tribe gladly handed over prisoners from an enemy tribe to the european traders and what about no retroactive application of law did a more firmly rooted legal principle even exist you couldn't penalize someone for doing something that was legal at the time they did it that's arbitrariness at its worst that's what stalin did truth was multilayered shifting it was different for everyone each personal history carved unique from the same weighty block of time and flesh i really enjoyed the book i made note of the sources conklin used and look forward to reading some of them highly recommend

raw_text.1445: i reviewed this book for www luxuryreading com weaving back and forth between 1852 virginia and modern new york the house girl presents a bitter sweet story of determination truth and the search for freedom in all its guises alternating between lina's and josephine's voices as well as letters of those working with the underground railroad to assist slaves like josephine in their desperate flight to freedom the story is at once both inspiring and utterly heartbreaking josephine's story line is by far the most interesting and is a true testament to the horrible depravities of slavery as well as the glimmers of hope that can emerge when people shed their fears and do what is right regardless of what consequences it might bring while i enjoyed seeing the similarities between lina and josephine - determined and strong women who both lost their mothers early in life - lina's progression and story line fell somewhat flat for me the constant lawyer talk about billable hours became grating after a while and i had a hard time really sympathizing with her next to josephine's unbelievably beautiful story it was hard to feel for lina and i kept rushing to get back to josephine's story however this might be an unfair statement as i found josephine's story so fascinating it would have taken a lot to not have me rushing to get back to it all in all the house girl is a beautiful story and offers up so much for discussion no matter your personal feelings towards the subjects discussed any reader would be hard pressed to not feel compassion and sadness for this dark mark on american history while i won't say that the story wraps up in a pretty happy bow i will say that it leaves off with the feeling of hope for a better future if one is willing to let go of the past and fight for the future they want it is only by facing the truth regardless of what that might be that contentment can be found with the house girl ms conklin makes the reader face all of these facts head on and does a wonderful job in doing so

raw_text.1459: i enjoyed the back and forth between the two storylines lina in 2004 new york and josephine in 1852 virginia this book was at its best when it stuck to the historical matters rather than lina's personal conflicts and problems at work the concept of josephine being the real artist and her white owner taking credit was one that rang true and sounded entirely feasible the concept of a midwife running off and leaving her patient alone and dying did not from a genealogical point of view it was an interesting search for josephine one that went better than a real life search and i am terribly glad that the hippie chick librarian didn't end up being lina's mother because i thought the author was setting it up for that the ending is somewhat open leaving the reader to imagine what happens next
raw_text.1460: i very much enjoyed the house girl tara conklin has previously published short fiction but this is her first novel i think conklin is a great story teller and did a good job of fully utilizing her background in both history and law to really draw me into the book the book is categorized as historical fiction and it also has a legal slant it is the story of two young women who share many similarities and grew up 150 years apart josephine was born in virginia in about 1835 born a black slave who worked "inside" her mistress's home - hence the title "the house girl " lina is the other young women in the story - living in new york city at a much later time in herstory a recent graduate and first year law employee at one of the more prestigious law firms in new york city the story is about both of their lives - two strong women with special talents and good intellects both growing up without mothers from a very young age they lived very different lives at very different times - one of privilege one of servitude one when slavery was legal one when it was no longer openly legal and yet both women shared very important characteristics big dreams and fierce determination the house girl is categorized as historical fiction and you will definitely gain a better understanding of the norm of cruelty injustices class structure and inequalities during this period of history for this alone the book is worth reading however there is also much mystery and suspense in the story along with romance psychology and philosophy the book provides a lot of information on slavery and the underground railroad system in particularl which began in the southern u s states and continued north to the northern u s states and canada conkin definitely piqued my interest in learning more particularly since several exits to the freedom trail that the slaves risked their lives for are so close to where i live there is also a parallel story about the dog eat dog climb to the top the client is right - no matter the ethics of an elite global law firm and in the end "what is really important in life" and "what is it all about " depending on the person and the situation freedom has many different permutations - all equally important to specific individuals the house girl was a page turner that was touching and had a soul tara conklin is a great story teller and the house girl is well worth reading

raw_text.1462: this book shared many similarities with the invention of wings which i read recently both deal with slavery but this book incorporates a contemporary story line to balance the historical narrative in some ways i found this an easier book to read than the invention of wings these things were the highlights for me 1 i loved the way we saw characters both through the historical narrative and through the lens of contemporary scholarship one character who was anything but a feminist and abolitionist had been canonized as an artist whose art revealed her sympathies towards slaves as the reader we knew this to be false because we'd met the character she wasn't who art historian thought she was 2 point #1 reminded me of how well we love story and that we create stories to satisfy our longings sometimes the stories we accept as truth are fiction this made me want to examine what seemingly small and insignificant stories i may be weaving in my own life 3 i liked seeing both lina and josephine move toward selfhood a member of my book club pointed out how this book was as much about self discovery as anything else she was right and it made me appreciate getting to go along for the journey with the characters if you're in the mood for a book that will whisk you away to another time and make you think this is a great choice clearly any book involving slavery is not an easy read but this is a worthwhile one

raw_text.1478: this book was astounding i started reading it one afternoon and could not put it down tara conklin portrays two very different time periods but links the two young women josephine and lina beautifully josephine a 17 year old house slave who is contemplating running from her masters is the mirror image of lina a twenty something lawyer in new york running from her past lina is researching the life of josephine as part of a national reparation case and in her search she uncovers truths about herself the narration switches between the two women josephine in the mid 1800s to lina in the present day the time periods are drastically different but the themes of love loss and searching for home and freedom echo with both characters this book would appeal to readers of historical fiction as well as lawyer fic the teen appeal is there there is a good balance between historical facts and current events however it may be too slow for some teens or not appealing to male readers as the protagonists are both female there is not a lot of 'action ' no dramatic dash for freedom or courtroom scene it is a cerebral book with much of the events taking place in the characters thoughts or read in letters from the past it is well researched and draws up questions of race family and heritage and would be a good book club selection good for the adult fiction collection maybe not for the young adult an excellent debut an excellent read

venerated artist who captured life as a slave on a plantation in the deep south lina also happens to be the daughter of an artist of two artists really one of which died when she was still quite young we know that these two lives will intersect somehow and the author does a great job weaving a compelling story i've always had a fascination with this ugly part of our nation's history perhaps because my own family lore consists of stories of quakers along the underground railroad with hidden compartments behind fireplaces and the like it is easier to stomach something so terribly terribly wrong if you believe your people were the good guys and put their own lives at risk to help another soul in all a good read quick and uncomplicated would recommend as a good summer read or book club book it is the perfect book when you don't want anything to deep or hard but also don't really want to go all in for trashy romances or mysteries i wished in the end that less time was spent crafting a good book and that the author had just let josephine tell her story but the context in which she sets it is compelling and is probably more consumable

raw_text.1573: lina is a lawyer who thinks that she wants to climb the corporate ladder to a partnership she works long stressful hours and thinks that she is doing what she wants lina's father is a well known artist who has raised lina alone since her mother died quite young he has refused to tell lina anything about her mother until he decides to do a show of paintings about his late wife the two have an interesting but close relationship lina is given an assignment to find a descendant of a slave willing to start a lawsuit for restitution through her father she learns about a slave who she thinks might have a story she could use josephine was a house slave a hand maid to a well known artist josephine herself is a talented artist though well treated by her mistress josephine is abused by the master she wants to run but hasn't gotten to fulfill her wish yet the novel switches rapidly between the two stories but the changes do not seem to be jarring the story moves forward at breakneck speed and drags the reader along for a great ride the characters are well drawn and intriguing sometimes the side stories seem a little superfluous and get a little boring the letters that wrap up the great mystery of the story are long and needed to be edited and then there is the matter of the convenient coincidences that make the story move quickly toward the ending over all i loved this book and enjoyed reading it i highly recommend it

raw_text.1582: this has been on my list for a while and the premise sounded so appealing it is a split story with alternating chapters between josephine the slave house girl and lina modern day power attorney the idea of a reparations case for slavery is absurd for many reasons and conklin does a decent job of arguing some of them but interesting and could be thought provoking unfortunately conklin's execution is just horrible the story is wordy and over wrought the characters are not really compelling the subplot twists are unnecessary and add nothing but distraction why does jasper need to be a love interest what is the benefit of grace oscar mess and convenient ways for conklin to move her main plot forward the librarian in virginia helps lina simply because she is oscar's daughter i was also annoyed at her technique of telling josephine's first runaway story through a series of just remembered moments josephine has not forgotten these details she would brood over them every day i could see that conklin was attempting to weave a feminist argument parallels between josephine and grace and lina dorothea's desire to be taken seriously and lina's frustration with dan not listening to her ideas but instead the book just felt cluttered i was not overcome with sympathy for the slave girl who had her art usurped by the missus instead i was thinking about warhol's usurpation of his art interns and modern artist practice of having studio assistants do much of the painting yes a modern studio assistant has a much better life than a slave housegirl i'm not arguing that they are equal in any way here but the modern studio assistant especially the ones who have to sign away any rights to claim they assisted on the work leaves the relationship with essentially no credits and nothing to show for their efforts ultimately it felt like a shallow assessment of a serious topic and a hodgepodge of random threads that all tie together nicely at the end if you have nothing else to read and are locked in a room it's probably better than staring at the wall if you have any other choices i would prioritize with this on bottom

raw_text.1585: a decent first novel of tara conklin the house girl centers around a mid nineteenth century house slave named josephine who may or may not be the actual artist behind a series of paintings thought to be painted by miss lu the wife of a tobacco plantation owner in present day carolina an associate of a high powered law firm is tasked to find a slave descendant who could be the face of a reparations suit against the government on the issue of slavery carolina focuses on josephine since art is very near and dear to her heart as her estranged parents are both artists as well while solving the mystery of josephine's family line she solves the mystery of her own parentage i didn't love this book but i didn't hate it either i could tell it was a first novel that there were too many coincidences and the story rushed a lot of the story was told through letters which was nice but some went on too long there were some unnecessary bits like long lists of names that ultimately didn't matter to the story and other areas that i thought could be expanded i do hope conklin will write more i think there is talent there but needs some polishing

raw_text.1639: i won an arc of this book from a goodreads giveaway listed by william morrow the house girl tells two stories and both were equally engaging for me first there is josephine a slave on the bell plantation in virginia in 1852 she has no family and her masters "missus" luanne bell and "mister" robert bell brought her up from the slave cottages when she was young to be a house girl she has decided to run away but she has tried and failed once before so she is determined this time will be different lina sparrow works for a major law firm in nyc that has been asked to assist a client with a historical reparations claim for descendants of slaves at the same time another legal issue emerges concerning a collection of paintings that have been attributed to luanne bell for years - an art critic comes forward to announce that the artist was josephine not her master lina searches for the truth about josephine trying to track down her descendants to see if they will be the plaintiffs in the reparations case conklin explores several questions that frame the stories of both women how can a person make her life worthwhile what happens to children who grow up without their mothers what are our obligations towards others in our lives i found her consideration of these issues from both josephine and lina's perspective to be interesting and honest conklin did a great job making both women realistic josephine has spent her life looking after the ailing luanne who has given her opportunities to paint and taught her to read but luanne is still josephine's captor josephine struggles between feelings of pity for the sickly woman who has shown her kindness and hatred for the missus who controls every minute of her days for lina's entire life her father has refused to speak about the accident that killed her mother now her father is ready to talk but lina is not sure she is ready to hear what he has to say i thought this book was excellent especially for a debut novel and i would definitely read another book by conklin

raw_text.1651: i received this book through the goodreads giveaway program artistic talent and skill are gifts given to chosen people and are not based on skin color or social standing as the historical novel house girl by tara conklin so beautifully illustrates josephine is a virginia tobacco plantation slave who dreams of freedom while in contemporary times lina sparrow an attorney and daughter of an artist is beginning work on a slave reparations case as these two lives separated by time and sorrow merge the story of josephine and her mistress lu anne bell a famous artist begins to unravel - who is the truly gifted painter - was it really the young slave girl as lina researches josephine's story she learns many truths about herself slavery art and life a beautifully written book that combines historical facts such as the underground railroad along with rich details about plantation life for both slave and master it is at heart a story of women reaching for more - wanting more and looking for their places in life - while trying to understand who they really are and what freedom actually means author conklin writes a seamless narrative of two worlds separated by hundreds of years that provide the reader with a depth of emotion that will linger long after the last page is read

raw_text.1680: i was truly looking forward to this book which shifted among two stories one takes place in 1852 and tells of a 17 year old house slave who may or may not be an artist and the other in 2004 about a young corporate lawyer conducting research for a potential slave reparation case there were so many glaring issues with this work that i am stunned it has been rated as well as it has been first it is incredibly week structurally a true storyteller doesn't need to rely on found letters a strategy used twice to provide plot driving exposition and while the epistolary form certainly has been used effectively here it is a cheap way for the protagonists to quickly find all the answers she needs thoroughly and neatly i teach u s history and work with many primary documents including journals and letters and i find it highly unlikely that an abolitionist family would write out directly to one another exactly how they are saving various runaway slaves so it is basically a plot convenience to help move the protagonist in the right direction in fact most of the plot is based on lucky coincidences which makes it so incredibly unbelievable the history doesn't ring true either slaves would not be invited to rest in their owners' bed a character wouldn't say that their money was as green as anyone else's in 1852 when greenbacks didn't come out until the 1860s the list goes on and on if the author was going to write a work of historical fiction effectively well the history has to be incredibly accurate and believable the reader never gets carried into the soul of either story neither the slave josephine nor the attorney lina become living breathing characters there is little emotional investment for the reader which left me cold i wouldn't be able to recommend this book to anyone unfortunately a huge disappointment for a story that could've been great

raw_text.1693: the house girl tells two stories from two time periods lina a 20 something lawyer in modern day new york city and josephine a slave in 1850s virginia lina gets a case for which she does some historical research stumbles upon josephine's art related story through her artist father becomes attached to the story and somewhere in there struggles with the backstory of her dead mother also an artist the story had all the right subject matter to get my attention let alone a character who shares my name however conklin does so much telling and not enough showing and halfway through the book i still felt no emotional connection to the main characters it wasn't until the end of the book when i finally met a character whose narrative grabbed me that of caleb harper before that i sympathized with josephine but did not feel her true level of desperation veiled behind imagery of her entrapment and the exhibition of lu ann bell's struggle i knew her desperation and fear were there but i never felt them i wasn't in josephine's shoes i was looking over her shoulder as for lina i heard her story but didn't understand why i should care where was her conflict with her mother lina doesn't really know how to feel about her long gone mother but that doesn't mean the reader shouldn't have felt a bit of it been given clearer clues to the conflict there lina's character was dry as a bone throughout her growing passion for someone else's history i finally connected with her slightly felt what she felt when she was reading caleb harper's letter however i give all that credit to caleb harper's awesome characterization why couldn't we have at least met him earlier or why couldn't lina have had his strength of conflict and josephine his feeling of desperation i took away very little from this incredibly slow read and probably would tell a fellow reader to take it or leave it

raw_text.1730: solid 3 5 stars so i'm very torn between giving it 3 and 4 stars i was skeptical at the idea of the two narratives but i found myself drawn in by the story and it kept me engaged i was much more interested in josephine's storyline and i say this as an attorney myself and even in the mini stories that we get by way of various letters fortunately lina is likeable enough if a little bland compared to some of the other characters and she has her own drama and troubles to weather i would read a book only about josephine i'm not sure i'd read one only about lina even though i find the legal question legitimately fascinating my main problem with this book is definitely the series of coincidences that give lina exactly the information she needs at exactly the time she needs it from her father first picking up the copy of the times containing the bell painting controversy to well the various letters i won't say more than that things fall into place a little too neatly for lina admittedly she works hard researching and eventually traveling but i had a hard time buying all these too convenient pieces of paper that find their way to her similarly i find lina's big personal reveal to be oddly timed to coincide with everything else happening in the book it felt unnecessary the story does bow a little under the weight of some of the prose but it didn't bother me much there were some nice touches for example while lina is sitting in the partner's office she sees a window cleaner working on the building it's mostly inconsequential but i've had that experience and somehow it really grounded the scene
raw_text.1731: it is 1852 when we first meet seventeen year old josephine on page 3 of tara conklin's the house girl as she's on the receiving end of a blow from her master and she vows to leave and never come back never mind that she has nowhere to go never mind that she'll be punished for it she has to go in 2004 lina sparrow is pulled into her boss' office and told she has a new case -- one that's very high profile with a very tight timeline and as she starts digging into the case she finds that there's so much to learn -- about history about life and about love well you can't really learn about life without also learning about love can you or vice versa tara conklin weaves a fine setting for this tale of two women in two very different lifetimes i enjoyed reading josephine's story even though it wasn't a pretty or easy one i admired her for her pluck and her courage in a time when neither are an asset to a woman and definitely not when you're a slave at least not in the eyes of anyone other than josephine as it is it takes her long enough to get around to actually doing that i was despairing that she ever would and even as she's getting ready to leave she's worrying about her mistress' health as for lina i thought she was a bit wishy washy -- for a lawyer that is she lets her boss walk all over her then she lets her co worker get the better of her she's angsty over her father's paintings of her mother and his possibly new ish relationship about the only time she's tough is when she's tracing down leads to josephine and towards the end of the book -- and i was glad to see it too tara conklin made her characters seem real to me yes even when i complain about them and i enjoyed the story she's woven around them the house girl would make a fine book club read if one does book clubs drey's rating pick it up

raw_text.1737: the house girl is primarily about lina sparrow and her search for a descendant of an american slave to act as defendant in a lawsuit her company is bringing against the us government for reparations for all of slavery lina believes she has found the perfect backstory in josephine bell a house girl who may or may not have painted the works of art that made her mistress famous now she just needs to verify that it really was josephine who created the paintings and sketches and find a living descendant of hers piece of cake meanwhile lina's father has decided to come to terms with the loss of lina's mother with his own art show and lina's own family history may not be what it seems alternating between current day new york and 1850s virginia conklin slowly weaves these disparate story lines together into a tapestry full of adventure mystery and tragedy ultimately however i find myself facing the problem the majority of the current characters in the house girl face an inability to feel beyond the surface of things conklin's language is lovely and picturesque but i'm left feeling that my interaction with the house girl like lina's initial contact with a potential love interest has left a tingle with an unfulfilled promise of more full review here http ennleesreadingcorner wordpress
