raw_text.1772: i thoroughly enjoyed this book ironically for some of the reasons others did not i read several reviews that critiqued conklin's use of lengthy detail of unsubstantial things i found conklin's lengthy detail smart for example during a scene she may digress to describe a particular piece of furniture only to further relate this piece of furniture to a flashback of one of the main characters giving her readers a broader sense of the characters and how they came to be conklin also did an excellent job giving readers just enough new information each chapter to end each chapter wanting to know more conklin achieved this suspense in her dual narration by beginning the novel with a conflict on both ends for josephine the 17 year old house slave whose narration begins in 1852 virginia conklin's readers learn immediately that josephine has been slapped by her master and feels a strong urge to run chapter 2 jumps to a 2004 young lawyer lina who lives with her widowed father who seems to harbor a secret about her mother grace's death while it seemed insignificant at first by the end of the novel the reader can see why conklin chose to begin lina's story with her trashing a brief only to quickly begin a new reparations case that eventually links to josephine in much the same way the reparations case is put on hold leaving all of lina's time sensitive work described throughout the novel as futile while the two stories of lina and josephine obviously connect i appreciate how conklin uses the knowledge lina gleans from researching josephine to change lina's character for the better in the beginning we see lina as a hardworking lawyer who is recently single and still living with her estranged father additionally she struggles to face the reality of her mother's supposed death avoiding the situation altogether with her time consuming workload however it's her workload and what she learns of josephine's life and determination to run that ultimately inspires lina to leave the dissatisfying law firm for which she works move out of her father's house pursue her love interest with of course one of josephine's descendants and finally seek the truth about her mother if it wasn't for roughly a 40 50 page letter near the end of the novel written by caleb harper the man who helped josephine escape bell creek i would have easily given the house girl a 5 star rating unfortunately of all the perspectives and voices portrayed in this novel i found caleb's the least entertaining leaving me desperate to return to lina's and josephine's narration at the letter's conclusion there were only 20 short pages left in the novel leaving me a bit dissatisfied with the amount of time conklin devoted to caleb overall i would recommend this novel to anyone who enjoys dual narration dynamic characters and a story of a runaway slave and a modern day lawyer that comes full circle

the book would have been better for trying to evoke those names and that weight by focusing on the case instead of lina the lawyer character and if it had more thoroughly interrogated the stanmore foundation and others like it that use the south's history as a source of profit and whitewashing were i her editor this would be a very different book i think we have evidence that white authors can write convincing and evocative books about race but they need to try harder not to constantly try and insert white people at the center of these stories especially when the impulse is to prove not all white people

raw_text.1789: after having read three books on slavery in a row and several dual narrative books in the last couple weeks i had pretty low expectations for this one and then was pleasantly surprised this is a debut novel but the writing is strong the characters rounded and for once i don't think the dual narrative was a big mistake since i'm usually pretty critical about those i tried to figure out what exactly is making this one work for me a couple things stand out to me first of all the narratives are separated by 150 years so it's not the case of a younger character meeting an older one in the present and learning about their past which always feels hokey to me the two female protagonists of the narratives are not related and have no family connection which is rare in dual narratives and which i like as that connection often feels fake to me the past narrative that of josephine takes place over the course of a single day as a result the reader doesn't find out what happens to her until the present narrative when lina the present narrative protagonist has to track her down for a job in a very believable manner lina doesn't make huge discoveries about her own life and beliefs based on what she discovers about josephine there's no cliched omg we're just the same and went through all the same things moment although lina's search does illuminate her life in a different manner this change in her character is also due to events that are happening to her outside of this search and to top it all off the ending is enthralling and contains some unexpected events in both women's lives so because we don't know much about josephine from her narrative lina's narrative takes on a greater importance giving both narratives more equal weight i think that might be key to managing the dual narrative plotline overall then i enjoyed this book and would recommend it to others

raw_text.1797: conklin is yet another lawyer turned novelist which makes me once more contemplate law school as a way to get my writer ly career going this is a complex novel that develops slowly but not ponderously threaded with various plot lines that knit together neatly and some deep painful emotions handled without melodrama opening in 1852 virginia slave josephine bell decides to runaway from the plantation where she is kept her sick mistress fading away like the collapsing farm where she lives in 2004 lina sparrow a young lawyer at a cut throat corporate law firm is assigned to work on a class action lawsuit for reparations for the descendants of slaves tasked with finding the perfect photogenic plaintiff to represent the case the past and present meet when lina learns of josephine bell through her artist father a talented artist josephine's art work has been mis attributed to her owner and a controversial showing of the art provides lina with her possible plaintiff the novel alternates view points mostly between josephine and lina but after half the book with the characters who interacted with josephine and i didn't mind the shift until near the end when we learn about josephine through written records of those with her i didn't like that 'barrier' that came up between me and her so to speak but i was grateful to learn what happened to her conklin's writing style is clear balancing emotion and action and she changes up the narrative style not just with the alternating povs but by sharing the 'source documents' lina reads with the reader we can have our own emotional responses separate of lina's and i appreciated that most importantly tackling the issue of reparations in a book like this this isn't a john grishom novel and making it real without preachy is key and conklin nailed it i say this as someone who strongly believes we need to have a national conversation about reparations a la south africa's truth u0026amp reconciliation movement i think conklin presents some shocking upsetting and emotionally raw themes and stories in a way that resonates without minimizing and creates a rather provocative frame both from the reparations angle and the art authentication angle it's daring and i love that conklin went there in short this is a winner of a historical novel a fascinating angle for a civil war era historical novel and with the subplot around art authentication i think those who enjoyed the art forger might dig this one

raw_text.1831: historical fiction is one of my favorite genres and books like the house girl make me want to read more the story alternates between present day 2004 new york city and an 1852 virginia tobacco farm lina sparrow a nyc attorney and daughter of famous artist oscar sparrow has recently learned that the historical paintings of southern plantation mistress luanne bell are suspected of having been created by her house slave josephine as lina works on what could be a historical slavery reparations case she becomes determined to find a direct descendant of josephine bell tara conklin weaves the story together by alternating narratives between lina and josephine adding twists from a few critical players along the way as i read the book i couldn't help but feel that familiar twinge of discomfort and anger when the author described the treatment and conditions of slaves in the 1800's i found myself getting caught up in the storyline of josephine and becoming especially concerned with her outcome the chapters that were devoted to josephine went quickly but i lost interest when we were back in lina's world i would have liked to see the author develop the subplot of lina's deceased mother a little earlier in the book it seemed like she kind of teased us with the suspense of it throughout the book and then ran out of time to really bring the idea to a conclusion but overall i really enjoyed this book and love the idea of a house slave being responsible for renowned works of art it made me think about how many other stories and truths in our culture have been lost to history

raw_text.1840: spoiler alert during the period of legalized slavery in america slave owners justified their heinous practices by believing that africans and their descendants were less than human while they could conceive of the enslaved people taking care of the white sons and daughters they could not conceive of the enslaved having rational thought insightful opinions or artistic creative abilities this book tells the story of enslaved josephine bell a very talented artist who chooses to escape her enslavement literally and figuratively this was an interesting book because it shared a new perspective on the life of an enslaved woman i also appreciated that although missus treated josephine a little better than her enslaved counterparts it did not cloud josephine's judgment or keep her from realizing that her freedom to have her own thoughts and spend time the way she wanted was better than serving missus i like how the writer takes us into josephine's head as she comes to the realization that she needs to escape the plantation i was saddened by how her life ended but perhaps that lends to josephine's choice to take her life into her own hands the present day scenes were ok but i really had no feeling for any of the present day characters the fact that lina's mom didn't die but rather ran away is a bit contrived as is the fact that lina gets on her 'white' horse and saves the legacy of josephine or perhaps i'm just jaded to the 'white hope' stories that are always written lina the white lawyer wants to save the legacy of josephine more so than the african american attorney who is all about making it very cliched instead of having some gray area in between i enjoyed the writing style which for me was a bit lyrical she painted the story in her telling of it

raw_text.1842: this book is written in an interesting style as it flips back and forth between the modern day world of lina a young lawyer and that of josephine bell a seventeen year old slave girl i immediately began to wonder if there might be a connection between these two characters lina works for a large legal firm and is working on a case designed to acknowledge the evils of slavery and in some way find a way to pay back todays african american citizens by setting up scholarships etc after seeing companies who benefited from using slave labor she needed to find one perfect person to use as a descendant of such a slave she happened upon a descendant of josephine bell's after attending an art lecture the twists and turns in the plot that follow paint an vivid picture of both life on a withering virginia farm and the life of a struggling young lawyer i enjoyed reading this book and will certainly look for others written by this author
raw_text.1844: i wasn't sure if i was going to enjoy this book with all the buzz going on about another book about a mistreated forgotten slave and a lot of talk about race relations etc among me and my friends i wasn't sure that i wanted to immerse myself in a book about a slave josephine who just wants to escape her existence as a house slave and whose talent as an artist is commandeered by her ailing mistress but i got sucked into the narrative told from two different points in history josephine telling her side of the story and lina a brash young new york attorney who has been assigned the task of finding a lead plaintiff for a civil rights reparations for the descendants of slaves case lina daughter of a famous artist who is about to launch an exhibit of work that comes from a place of his own darkness and secrets is drawn to the scandalous story that the artwork attributed to a 19th century artist might actually be the work of that artist's slave you guessed it josephine the author does a great job of taking the reader back and forth in time prose and characters by telling this story in two different voices as a reader you root for lina as her search takes her closer and closer to the truth you grieve for and with josephine as you discover the true ills and hurts inherent in the whole system and mechanism of slavery as an african american woman reading this book again opened my eyes to the horrors of what my ancestors went through again as i read the book i wonder what my life would have been like if i'd been born during the times in which josephine lived would i have accepted my position as a slave or would i have longed for and taken the steps necessary no matter how brutal or dangerous to secure my freedom and yes there is anger as i read about how the owners of the slaves in the book treated the slaves that were in their care as someone who works in the legal profession i appreciated the author's attention to detail and the accurate portrayal of the life of a young associate held to the demands of an unyielding narcissistic partner whose main concern is the wants demands and needs of the client i also appreciate her subtle references to billable hours this was a great book and i would recommend it to art lovers people interested in our country's past history of slavery and readers who enjoy legal thrillers

raw_text.1898: if i had to choose a single word to characterize this book it would be repentance in a duo of intertwined tales one taking place in the 1840s and 1850s and one taking place in 2004 we see various characters seeking to make amends but not always in the most obvious ways on its face the 21st century story focuses on a proposed court case to claim reparations for 250 years of slavery but that is really just an introduction to our main character lina who tries throughout the novel to make up for not being enough not daughter enough not artist enough not cutthroat enough an attorney and in addition we have her father who has painted an exhibition's worth of work in apology to lina's mother the 19th century story is the tale of josephine a slave and artist whose history lina tracks in the hopes of finding a descendent to serve as the face of the reparations case josephine's life is a horror to anyone in the modern age but instead of falling back on one of the tropes of pure hatred or pure forgiveness conklin gifts her with a complex mixture of emotions we experience her pity and affection combined with hatred for her ailing mistress and love and disdain for the couple who all but raised her and refuse to run josephine has very little for which to apologize and it is her mistress and a later revealed narrator who seek her forgiveness i found this novel a captivating blend of history and legal maneuvering the characters were beautifully flawed lina puts her foot in her mouth repeatedly and misinterprets people's intentions and motivations and almost universally likeable lina's artist father is temperamental and sometimes distracted but he raised her on his own with obvious love and attention josephine is a basically good person who experiences anger and bitterness which she locks away for the sake of survival even people who have had questionable relationships in the past with lina's parents are nuanced and neither wholly good nor bad in the end nearly everyone in this book is trying to right a wrong in some way which makes it easy to appreciate their very human flaws and the story itself is interesting and kept my attention to the end

raw_text.1946: i love reading novels that focus on strong independent women house girl has two such women carolina lina sparrow is a first year law associate working on an extremely interesting but difficult assignment josephine bell is a house girl and a slave each of these women has a story to share lina's story takes us to new york city circa 2004 and josephine's takes us to lynnhurst virginia circa 1852 their link to each other is a law suit asking for trillions of dollars in reparations for descendants of american slaves josephine bell was one of those slaves i bought house girl because it contains much of the subject matter that for me makes up an interesting read we have a women with a family secret a glimpse into the world of art and a legal investigation plus we also have a storyline that jumps back in time to antebellum virginia how could i not buy this book tara conklin has taken the subject of slavery and approached it in a very different manner her novel had me totally intrigued right from the get go house girl is conklin's first novel and i have to say that she did an excellent job of creating this tale she took two separate stories connected the dots and brought them together to make one very enjoyable read i loved how the chapters jumped back and forth in time one chapter would have me strolling down the streets of new york while the next would bring me to the middle of an 1850's tobacco plantation each time period was filled with unique and endearing characters josephine of course was one of my favorites i was not bored for one minute well done tara i'm happy to give you five stars

raw_text.1991: this book told a story from 4 points of view the slave girl josephine the lawyer on a reparations case lina the female abolitionist and a man who sunk down to the bottom only to redeem himself because of the slave girl i found the story riveting to the point that at times i forgot i was reading a novel this story was powerful and yet gently moving i could place myself in the characters shoes as the story progressed i rooted for the lawyer to find her voice and make a stand knowing what the slave girl would be running to was heart breaking even though i did not know the full extent to what danger she was running to as we all know slavery was hard the fact that this slave the house girl had some freedoms that others enslaved did not have but those freedoms did not make her feel that she needed to be bonded to her owners in her heart of hearts she knew she needed to get away from the plantation the story tells what became of 3 of the 4 voices that tell the story the last one left me wondering what's next not a disappointing what's next but a hopeful what's next i thoroughly enjoyed this book and would recommend it to everyone
raw_text.1992: josephine is a house girl who lives at a foundering plantation with the mister and missus and a few other slaves once josephine decides that she is going escape to freedom nothing diverts her from that goal and nothing can bring her back to the southern plantation where she was abused josephine has allowed herself to forget a devastating past that begins to resurface once she makes the final decision that she will run she can't help but remember the first time she ran and the subsequent consequences lina is on partner track at a prestigious law firm when she is placed on a big project for a very special client her personal and professional lives merge when she first hears about josephine bell a slave that might have been the true artist of paintings previously attributed to her white plantation owner already familiar with the art world dives into the mystery involving the long ago events while investigating josephine and her descendants lina stumbles upon a personal issue that rocks her world the chapters of this book alternate between josephine and lina's point of view at times we get to see through other characters but it is primarily josephine and lina telling the story this format worked because the titles were clear at the beginning of each chapter and the stories are quite separate they could have been separate books i am grateful that this wasn't a depressing read it can be uncomfortable reading about certain issues but this one doesn't focus on the physical cruelty of slavery but instead focuses on the issue of identity and the fact that the harm of slavery goes much further than manual labor and punishments friends and i have previously discussed this issue and i was quite satisfied with how well it was done here i wasn't quite connected to josephine bell but i felt moderately connected to lina i was enthralled with this book from beginning to end the writing is great though it is connected to a tough subject ms conklin does a great job weaving a story that is much bigger than the idea of slavery

raw_text.1994: what an incredible book set simultaneously in 1850s virginia and new york city 2004 and telling the stories of slave girl josephine and lawyer lina this may be the best dual period book i've ever read debut author tara conklin weaves two separate stories together like a beautiful tapestry the past and the present blended artfully and skillfully this is a story about art and the power of brushstrokes to heal broken hearts from different worlds different time periods it's a story about interpretation of facts of feelings of the heart a story about truth about lies about freedom about hopes and dreams and wishes and failings and triumphs and heartbreak about justice about evil i can't say enough about this debut novel that had me flipping pages at a frantic pace conklin created a rollercoaster of emotional tension revealing chapter by chapter the threads gently connecting one story to the other the parallels often uncanny and enthralling and the characters as they sometimes made bad or dangerous decisions had me biting at my nails part epistolary part historical and part contemporary this story of a young ambitious lawyer who finds herself assigned to a groundbreaking reparations case for descendants of american slaves takes on personal meaning she never could have expected in many ways this story felt like a russian nesting doll in its complexity stories within stories within stories all compelling and revealing and perhaps one of my favorite things about this literary gem it offers a sensory feast the passages are lyrical beautiful and often evoke frightening palpable images transporting the reader to antebellum virginia and bustling manhattan just a few examples of the sights sounds and imagery you might expect that pull you right into the narrative standing shoulder to shoulder with the characters "the air hung heavy over the road and the dry yellowed grass began to shimmer as it did in the hottest part of the day the sun casting it to buckle and bend josephine's heart knocked hard against her chest and she felt a snaking poison in her blood that worked with the heat upon her muscles and her mind like a drug of dismay "or ... "he grinned at her his mouth a graveyard of dark space and gray stone " - this haunting description of a young slave boy affixed to a yoke in a field somehow - and i'm not sure how she did it - conklin pieces together an intricate puzzle of the past and present and doesn't for a moment decrease the tension of the beautiful narrative highly recommend

raw_text.2076: this is a historical fiction novel with two narratives the first narrative is set during the late 1840s and early 1850s and tells the story of josephine a house girl living on a plantation in virginia the other narrative is set during modern times and tells the story of a young attorney working on a class action lawsuit for the reparation of descendents of slaves the author switches back and forth between the two narratives and the narratives are related to each other so the book flows well i love novels where the point of view changes so that is part of the reason i enjoyed this book there is a element of mystery in each of the stories and there are some twists and turns that occur throughout the book which made it engaging since the book deals with the subject of slavery it is obviously a heavy topic but i think it's important to reflect upon and consider this sad aspect of our country's history at the end of the book in the author's note the author states that there are no national museums dedicated to slavery no national monuments memorializing american slaves and no easy ways to track african american ancestry it was kind of startling to read that i hope that changes some day

back in 1852 i was enthralled it's a horrifically sad time in america's history but conklin did the era justice with her writing she acknowledged the abuse suffered by the plantation slaves and she discussed the role of the underground railroad i enjoyed that she was willing to discuss some harsh truths and i loved getting inside of the mind and heart of josephine josephine a favorite name of mine btw was so conflicted over her role on the plantation and i hurt for her she missed being around those she considered family yet she appreciated her role in the home she both loved and despised raw_text.2088: this book has a lot to like two very different alternating chapter storylines one historic fiction and the other modern research quest these are some of my favorite things i liked the ending of each storyline generally speaking and felt that the author did a commendable job making the two stories seem totally unique from each other her narration feels different for each and it was fun to feel pulled back into each story after a chapter apart i did feel that parts of the book needed better editing in particular caleb's letter at the end and parts of lina's story at the beginning the dual story format really helped engage my interest when i otherwise might have struggled to keep reading because although the story is good it does move slowly in these parts i loved the final chapter for josephine of course she dies because her story is set in the 1850's but it was lovely to envision her finally free and at peace in a heaven like her own world transformed and made beautiful i found it satisfying and sensible that lina quit her job at the end of her story but was a little confused by the revelation that her mother did not die instead she just abandoned her family i'm still unsure what this element was meant to add to the story and it did seem contrived and unnecessary

raw_text.2120: what do we choose to remember and what do we choose to forget this is a question that must grappled with as we acknowledged memory's affect on history's long presumed "absolute truth" history's dependance on story telling and human memory has long been highlighted in the old adage "history is written by the victor" which questions its ability to be absolute and true like personal memory all history or "collective memory" has gaps some of these gaps are purposeful exclusions that exercise power or politics some are more subconscious reactions to emotional pressures like trauma regardless we live with these gaps and create our own "prosthetic memories" through our experience reading and understanding of history as it is presented to us today tara conklin's the house girl explores this idea of memory history and its problematic gaps read the full review https myhappycoincidence wordpress

raw_text.2123: the house girl is yet another novel that juxtaposes a contemporary story with a linked plotline from the past it is a tricky balancing act for the author to ensure that both stories are of equal interest lina sparrow is a first year litigation associate in a high powered new york city law firm although 24 and attractive she doesn't have much of a personal life since her law firm career demands so much of her time she still lives with her father oscar who is a well known artist josephine bell seventeen in 1852 and serving as a house slave in lynnhurst virginia is also an artist her master missus lu sometimes allows her to paint with her in her studio now that missus is feeling poorly she even asks josephine to help complete her own paintings because her hand has become too unsteady as the story opens lina's "mentor partner" at clifton u0026amp harp daniel oliphant iii pulls her into a big new case brought by a wealthy african american client ron dresser dresser wants to sue for reparations on behalf of the ancestors of slaves claiming that trillions of dollars in unpaid wages resulted in unjust enrichment for private companies benefiting from slave labor before the passage of the thirteenth amendment lina's assignment is per dan to "get ourselves a great lead plaintiff i want something stirring a new angle something compelling and don't forget photogenic - these people will be on tv they'll be in the papers they'll be giving interviews we need some great people lina some great stories " the lawsuit provides an excuse for lina to read about and share with us the history of slave exploitation of labor thanks to her artist dad lina discovers the slave josephine as a potential source for a "colorful" angle if only she can find a descendant a series of very unlikely and improbable developments enable her to learn many details that not only advance her case but also allow her to locate the perfect plaintiff everything gets wrapped up in the end but not neatly and even somewhat bizarrely discussion in many ways josephine's story is infinitely more interesting than lina's but i don't have a sense of how historically realistic josephine's story may have been nor how authentic her voice seems on the other hand lina's account of life in a top ranked competitive law firm rings very true i laughed out loud at lina's comparison of law firm time to casino time and at the way she thought of everything she did in six minute intervals but some of the coincidences and dei ex machina in the story strained credulity and some of lina's actions seemed markedly inconsistent with her character portrayal evaluation the intertwined stories of this book are definitely compelling even if there are some plausibility issues especially in the lina sections of the book rating 3 5 5

raw_text.2125: this review has been hidden because it contains spoilers to view it click here both story lines of the house girl the slave josephine in 1852 and the attorney lina in 2004 are compelling and well drawn both women are strong and admirable well worth following for the bulk of this story i was caught up and enthralled and planning to give it five stars then it became utterly unrealistic i've been doing family history research for almost thirty years and let me assure you that one never finds long narrative documents that answer all of one's questions never as both story lines of the house girl the slave josephine in 1852 and the attorney lina in 2004 are compelling and well drawn both women are strong and admirable well worth following for the bulk of this story i was caught up and enthralled and planning to give it five stars then it became utterly unrealistic i've been doing family history research for almost thirty years and let me assure you that one never finds long narrative documents that answer all of one's questions never as in never never first they simply don't exist people told their stories to loved ones they don't write them down in great detail and in the rare times they did the documents almost never survive intact most generations don't see the value in them and just throw them away the odds of finding several such narratives are astronomical small enough to be zero or close enough the odds of finding them fast within a two week timeline absurd i finished the story because i wanted to know how it ended and i thought the events themselves worked really well the ending was inevitable and would have been deeply satisfying if it hadn't been been handed to lina in such a neat easy package more

raw_text.2167: the house girl by tara conklin was an enjoyable read although it confronts heavy subjects i was not overly disturbed by the story it portrays the struggles of a slave and of those who tried to escape slavery by the underground railroad system i was more intrigued than pained when i read it--which by the way is often a good thing this book is a time slip going from the story of josephine an escaping slave girl whose art work eventually becomes well known but mistakenly attributed to her virginia mistress to the story of the lawyer who is working on a monetary reparations case for the descendants of slaves the huge law firm that lina works for needs a plaintiff a single descendant for whom they could argue for the harm done to that person as the actual descendant of a slave it is easy to follow the logic of the harm done to josephine the loss of what she might have done had she not been living under the shackles of slavery josephine was proven to be the artist of the remarkable artwork for which her mistress became well known and therefore the reader can see that had she lived a long full life she might have been fully recognized for her work in her own lifetime i was just as intrigued by the story of lina and her search for the truth of josephine's life and for the descendant for whom the law firm would fight for reparations the way that conklin manages to interweave josephine's life so long ago with lina's present life fascinates me lina's own unrest and desire for more than the corporate lawyer's life is the most interesting part of the story--at least for me although i love the past story she presents the integrating the two stories is something conklin does so very well although lina's story is not the author's own i sense the tension of the analytical life lina is leading with the artistic life she admires as one that conklin has also struggled with when she left a corporate law office to write her novel the house girl with this aspect of the story she creates much of the tension needed to make this a good book and time slip novels are a personal favorite i recognize that is difficult to do plausible stories in this venue but yet when one works i love it i think it is the idea of the past affecting the present that i love an idea that is of course well established a storyline that weaves the two together makes the idea tangible in an obvious way and probably explains my own penchant for them

raw_text.2214: i enjoyed this book and although there were issues with plot and character development i really couldn't put it down the story has two narrators lina a young nyc big firm lawyer researching a brief for a lawsuit on behalf of former slaves seeking billions of dollars in reparation for unpaid work and josephine a young slave woman plotting her escape from a virginia plantation more than a hundred and fifty years earlier although very different i felt both voices rang true lina's experience of billing her time in 6 minutes increments brought back memories from my days at a big toronto firm turns out the author is a former lawyer herself now full time novelist lucky her and that certainly explains the realistic law firm atmosphere she created josephine's story also contained powerful images that i won't soon forget especially the story she tells of a slave boy she encounters on her escape route he is shackled unable to move but is laughing probably deliriously and asks her to scratch his itchy ripped up back with a stick tara conklin does a good job of weaving together the two women's stories while elements of lina's research seem farfetched the coincidences and strokes of luck just keep on coming it contained all sorts of interesting at least to me characters involved in the abolitionist movement and the underground railroad as lina uncovers more and more of josephine's story her own story and especially her past and the absence of her mother starts becomes clearer but not that clear the reader is definitely left wanting at lina's own lack of questioning about her life art is a huge theme in the book josephine is an artist whose work had been attributed to missus bell the lady of the house where she was enslaved lina's father is an artist her dead mother is an artist the young man lina meets tries to make her lead plaintiff is a musician although surrounded by artists lina has no artistic leanings--she does law and that's seemingly all that one dimensional aspect of lina is perhaps why at the end of the day she is not developed enough as a character for the reader to deeply care about her story nevertheless house girl is an enjoyable read with good energy created by the back and forth between narrators and the fascinating back story of the underground railroad

raw_text.2218: this story alternates between the ante bellum south and present day nyc and it reminds me of the physick book of deliverance dane with its strong female characters separated by nearly 200 years and a plot that alternates between past and present both lina a nyc lawyer and josephine a 17 year old slave enthrall the reader with their struggle to fit in to a society that dictates their status while they also try to break free from their restraints even minor characters such as lina's mom and lu anne bell demonstrate the plight of women who are forced to live a life not of their choosing and whose quest for freedom always seems beyond their grasp and if they win that hard fought freedom society too often unfairly judges them i thought deliverance dane was a great read but this book offers even more with so many threads that weave an intricate story that begs the reader to consider a plethora of moral issues that span centuries art history law ethnicity family obligations family secrets and identity are just some of the threads that weave an exquisite tapestry of a story turn the tapestry over to see the underside of knots and and how all the threads connect and that is what makes this story so fascinating this is a debut novel and if this is any indication of what author tara conklin is capable of i cannot wait to read what she writes next

raw_text.2246: especially intriguing for me because josephine bell the house girl lived in charlotte county virginia just 60 some miles southwest of richmond though it doesn't seem from all our research that our virginia ancestors were wealthy enough to have a 'house girl' nonetheless it gives a picture of the times and the roles of the slaves the slaves with slightly more privilege and the male and female masters in the early 1850's lina sparrow an attorney is trying to track down a current day plaintiff for a case around the true artist whose paintings have been attributed to luanne bell the wife of a plantation owner the book captures well both the slight privilege of the house girl living as she does in the master's house and in particular the 'charge' of the master's wife luanne it is privilege in that she can learn to read and has more freedom but it is always a circumscribed freedom compounded by being raped by the master with no recourse but escape the interweaving of the story of lina's search back in time with the unfolding of josephine's story made for an intriguing read lina has to do old fashioned genealogy research to try to track josephine from when she vanishes from the record in 1852 and her descendents she goes to afrifind the largest and seemingly most professional of the fee charging services the geneologist who answers the phone tells her farm records can be very hard to find the woman explained they're scattered across the state in local historical societies community centers that kind of thing or at the old lantation houses themselves there are also some relevant documents in the archives of the virginia historical society though it looks like there's not a lot available online pages 128 129 exactly what i've tried albeit as yet to now avail for our henrico county ancestors

lu i call them selfish virginia slave owners and i was always hoping to turn the page and find their rotten plantation burned to the ground or some other misfortune to befell them all of this takes place around 1852 mister was a pretty lousy southern tobacco farmer who lost most of his families grand wealth and mistreated his slaves missus lu was of a different sort she kind of took pity on josephine i suspect that because the missus was childless she did have a somewhat civil and motherly way with the young josephine who had been with the bells since she was a small child her own mother having passed away missus lu in her twisted affectionate way sometimes allowed josephine to paint with her and as the missus became ill josephine often finished the paintings that her missus began josephine enjoyed these moments of freedom she was a natural and gifted painter josephine was also strong willed and determined to one day paint and walk the streets as a freed woman living her life as she pleased her time her own running away was all she thought of now a breeze came up and pushed at josephine's back as she walked the path run it whispered run josephine had tried before to run one night some years ago she had been no more than a child then twelve maybe thirteen years old with no understanding of the dangers or the true northward route or the way the shadows played tricks on haunted by the memory of lina's mother grace who passed away suddenly when lina was 4 they do not speak of grace but grace is always there pain separating father and daughter lina submerges herself in billable hours and a monumental slave reparations case and a disputed claim of art work from the stanmore foundation which owns the rights to bell creek and the art work of lu anne bell or was lu anne bell the actual artist could it have been her house girl josephine lina is left to unravel the mystery of bell creek and it's descendants can she uncover the truth and set josephine the house girl free at last while josephine's story is entertaining lina's portion of the story is just downright b o r i n g i simply didn't care about her lina is brood ish and appears to be very lonely does this chick have any friends i don't know i just couldn't get in to her i think she needed to cut her father some slack lina wasn't a very likeable gal i know that this subject matter is not a feel good topic but it would be a bit more believable for the protagonist to go to such great lengths to find truth and justice if she had a bigger soul lina left me feeling chilled to say the least i hope conklin gives her next characters more emotional depth and doesn't try to hurry the end along so quick neat and tidy again i liked the house girl i just didn't really like the house girl and i raw_text.2263: if i could give half stars this might be a 3 5 but i really enjoyed this book this is a good read and for what i understand is a debut novel from this author i am very impressed the book is told from the perspective of two voices lina a modern caucasian attorney who works at an upscale law firm most of her work is corporate lina's father is well regarded artist her mother she has been told died in a freak car accident when she was very young josephine a southern slave who is a house girl was fortunate in that the missus educated her and provided her with access to paints pencils and other art supplies missus is a would be artist and in the future her work would become highly collectible lina's law firm is given the opportunity to pursue a 'slave reparations' case which is to be funded by a wealthy client lina's search leads her on a hunt to find a suitable lead plaintiff for their case it must be a person whose forebears were slaves she embarks on what will become a life changing journey that will uncover the truth about not only her own life but about those who are closest to her she will uncover truths about her own life as well that of the house girl josephine i think that ms conklin was very successful in intertwining these two seemingly disparate stories generally i think that the pacing and plot lines flowed easily and kept my attention there were a few places that i felt were a bit slower paced but even these areas kept my attention and did not feel the need to skim these pages i am looking forward to reading more from this gifted author

raw_text.2307: where to start i did enjoy this novel very much especially the sections that pertained to josephine i really liked her character and was moved by her story she was a slave but had been chosen as a house girl for luanne bell her life was seemingly full of contradictions even though she was a slave she lived a different life as a house girl even getting to paint and express herself though the credit for her much of her work was given to luanne i am not sure she was looking for credit for her work she was looking for a new life lina on the other hand seemed if not content with her life at least in a place that she wasn't ready to stir the pot she still lived with her father and yet was an associate in a big law firm her mother had been killed when she was just a little girl and i think this was part of the reason that she still lived with her father it was in that house that she could remember what little she did about her mother there was a mystery surrounding her death because her father never really wanted to talk about it with her so being so young when she died she didn't really know what happened as she starts to research josephine's life and to see her struggles a series of events in her own life seem to awaken her need for a change as well i think it was learning about josephine and how she never gave up to be free makes her realize she has just been drifting along in her own life waiting for something to happen rather than going out and finding it she starts to see the people in her father's and mother's previous life in a new light questioning what she thought to be the truth forces a confrontation with her father that was far too long in happening filled with interesting characters to me this book explores how relationships with family and others have an influence on our lives and the choices that we make would josephine have done the same things had she not been a house girl would her life have been different is she would not have been close to lu anne bell and lina if her father would have shared things about her mother when she was younger how would that have influenced lina's choices in life and would her father have been able to let things go earlier than he did i think this book would be a great choice for a book club read as there are so many things you could discuss and explore

raw_text.2352: the house girl is tara conklin's debut novel it's received a lot of great reviews while i didn't actually read any of the reviews before i read house girl i think the reviews set me up to expect more than i received the novel is set in two different time periods 1852 pre civil war virginia and set in new york city circa 2004 in present day or 2004 lawyer lina is on the hunt for a descendant of a slave for a special lawsuit for her firm her paper trail leads her to josephine a virginian house slave who might have been the original to works attributed to her owner the chapters switch between the two eras and the two heroines of the story we learn about josephine's life from her point of view albeit in bits and pieces as well as from the clues that lina discovers in the end lina discovers more about herself on this journey than she expected while the story of josephine's life is fascinating i felt that lina was the true protagonist of the novel as lina learns more about josephine we readers are also fed little breadcrumbs read the rest of the review here http www fromlefttowrite com book r

raw_text.2355: conklin's first novel is a winner it reminded me of jodi piccoult's writing in some ways the book alternates between present day new york city where lina is a rising star in a law firm and antebellum virginia where josephine is a house slave on a small plantation owned by robert bell and his ailing wife lina's boss assigns her to work on a historic lawsuit seeking reparations for the descendants of african american slaves meantime we read about josephine's life tending to lu anne bell her mistress and promising artist missus lu teaches josephine to read and write and also allows her to paint on occasion josephine's first attempt at fleeing fails but she works up her courage to try again about 4 years later lina meanwhile needs to find a plaintiff for the lawsuit which leads her to research slavery and through her artist father oscar's connections the debate about lu anne bell's paintings and whether some were indeed done by her house slave the two storylines intersect steadily and cleverly

raw_text.2369: i picked up tara conklin's the house girl at our library's wonderful book sale after having previously seen it labeled a book club pick at target i really enjoyed the kitchen house and this looked like it might be similar told from the point of view of two women living one hundred and fifty years apart this book is about the lives and losses of slaves in the antebellum south and the reverberations of those actions still felt today in 2004 lina sparrow is a lawyer in new york city building a lawsuit seeking reparations for the descendants of former slaves she comes across the story of a young slave who may or may not be the actual artist behind some of the time's most beloved portraits in 1852 josephine is that young woman and she is desperate for escape from her terrible conditions in the short term painting provides a kind of salve for her pains but it isn't long before running is her only option while i did enjoy this book i was disappointed that it wasn't more readable it was very slow and some of the story lines felt unfocused i love a good historical novel and this one contained plenty of research i also felt that just when i became invested in many of the characters their stories abruptly ended this was at times frustrating i know that an author is not always going to make the decisions i would like her to make but ms conklin seemed to consistently take characters in a direction i did not like that is completely subjective on my part and i fully admit it but i feel i must include it in my review i am interested in reading more books of this time period exploring slavery and the underground railroad do you have any suggestions for me check out more of my reviews at smartgirlsread http smartgirlsread blogspot com

raw_text.2374: as i began reading this book i thought to myself this is going to be great and then i finished it and i thought well that ending was not so great this book relates the stories of several people but primarily carolina sparrow and josephine bell in 2004 carolina is a associate attorney on the fast track to firm partner and in 1852 josephine bell is the house slave of an unsuccessful tobacco farmer and his sickly wife their stories touch as carolina researches whether or not josephine is the true artist behind the paintings that for so long have been attributed to her mistress to fully explain why i didn't like the book would give away the ending i can say that i was fascinated by the two main characters i loved the history and the art and the slow unraveling and connecting of each thread that built this story the problem for me was really how the author chose to end her tale i wasn't expecting a happily ever after ending in fact some of my own predictions were definitely on the sad side of things but i was really disappointed in the actual ending it really comes down to my own personal feelings and has very little to do with the skill or ability of ms conklin as a writer so i guess i'd say give it a try but you might not like the ending also there is some swearing including f words the story obviously deals with slavery and the abuse of slaves for example master impregnating slave but these scenes are handled sensitively and while difficult advance the story rather than being used only to shock and disturb

raw_text.2377: the house girl by tara conklinchallenges read for goodreads ebook historical fictionbook cover simple pretty very much the way josephine would be this was a fabulous story a story of a slave out of the tobacco fields in virginia who wanted nothing more than to be free at any cost a brave girl who could tell us a story of plantation life as she saw it through drawing and painting the story flows painlessly from present day to late 1840's we meet josephine a house girl to missus lu on what had once been a large and prosperous tobacco plantation the missus has given josephine exposure to her own studio where josephine can blossom into quite an accomplished artist tragedy occurs both die in separate incidents and it is assumed that the paintings found were the accomplishments of the missus the buyers of the plantation showcase those works as those of missus lu enter present day and lina up and coming attorney in a large firm slated for partner who has a reparations suit dropped in her lap her research brings her into josephine's extraordinary short life and begins to reveal the truth could those paintings truly be the work of josephine beautifully woven story although the core is josephine it is the story of lina's own battles guess you'll just have to read it for yourself

raw_text.2381: the house girl tells the stories of two women in two time periods josephina a talented artist u0026amp house slave of 17 in virginia in 1852 and lina a present day ambitious young attorney in nyc i was particularity caught up josephina's slavery story during the period when the underground railroad was running that historical piece of the south portrayed a strong u0026amp determined girl who faces a very difficult life and from that pain comes her beautiful drawings lina begins to research the authenticity of these drawings search for justice and in her own life faces issues in corporate america balancing family work u0026amp social life that are relevant today the author makes a good comparison between the two protagonists one thing being that they both overcome the lack of mothers in their lives 'what is the price of freedom' is a good discussion question which covers both time periods the ending especially for lina came bit too quickly it leaves a lot of unanswered questions about her sometimes the author just wants readers to imagine it on their own overall i really enjoyed this historical debut novel

raw_text.2409: there's always been conversations around the legacy of slavery reparations and the contributions of african americans in the building of this country the house girl touches a little on those subjects through the eyes of josephine an enslaved woman in 1852 virginia and lina the daughter of a prominent artist and a young lawyer in current day manhattan lina has a chance to secure her future with a prominent law firm by taking on a class action case that seeks reparations for the descendants of slaves while looking for a example to serve as the foundation for the lawsuit she comes across a controversy in the art world that questions whether the work of famous 19th century artist lu anne bell was really painted by her or by her house slave josephine conklin has the story unfold by going back and forth between the voices of josephine and lina we experience the isolation of both women from the people around them along with their respective quests for freedom josephine's in a literal sense and lina's from the silence surrounding her mother's disappearance from her life a thought provoking and impressive debut
raw_text.2410: basically this is the story of two women born 150 years apart whose lives intersect josephine bell is a 17 year old slave on a poor west virginian plantation who has reached the brink and has decided she must run despite having nowhere to go lina sparrow is an up and coming lawyer who has been given a possibly historic case to work and must find a direct descendent of a slave through lina's artist father she finds out about the controversy surrounding the artwork of lu anne bell wife of a plantation owner did she create her artwork or did her house girl josephine lina ends up trying to find out the truth and in the process uncovers secrets about her own family as well as josephine's this was a good book not fantastic but i would certainly recommend it not surprisingly i found josephine to be the stronger character there were a few weak parts i found caleb harper's letter way more descriptive than is believable lina is a lawyer yet has never searched for any answers about her mother's death but overall it was an interesting read it would probably be of interest to anyone who enjoyed the help

raw_text.2439: the house girl is ms conklin's first novel according to her it was selected from a slush pile for publication makes me wonder what other incredible stories we are missing that are sitting in editor's slush piles since i hate reviews that give a complete synopsis of the book rendering reading the book no longer necessary and i hate the ubiquitous spoiler alert inserted throughout a review even more i will attempt to convey what i like about this book without doing either reading the back of the book the premise is unique and intriquing a law firm takes a slavery reparations case and is seeking contemporary slave descendants at plaintiffs ms conklin employees a creative narrative pov alternating between a present day character and a slave character part of the story is told through letters the author shows amazing mastery of the language she creates a narrative prose the takes the reader to the inner world of the characters and poetically describes thier environments often when narrative gives way to prose the story will lose substance the house girl never loses substance there is not a wasted word the story has the precise balance of plot and character the inner workings of the character are conveyed in sync with events and movement in the plot the actions of the characters never seem forced or contrived to move plot along likewise characters never seem out of place in the story line and evolution of the story with plot moving along despite them i wavered between giving this one 4 or 5 stars i like to reserve 5 stars for the truly exceptional the books that i would recommend to anyone the books i would take to a deserted island i finally came down in favor of 5 stars i recommend this to anyone that wants to read a good book i do not limit my recommendation to historical fiction or women's fiction readers i anxiously await ms conklin's next novel

revolving around these issues 2 the relationship tensions i think lena and her father osacar's interactions conveyed this the best their communication always skirted some topics while others were pursued head on they provide a relatable portrayal of times when simple conversation never really is simple 3 there is an overarching question of the meaning of life many characters are in pursuit of finding themselves or seeking something greater discussions of god's role is sense of self something imposed on us by others or is it of our own design and the meaning of freedom what i didn't like 1 the narrative voice never seemed to change or vary this was most obvious when the narrative was coming from a historical document and suddenly letters were filled with gazes detailed looks and eloquent prose that are easily recognized as the narrators not every character needed to speak in such detail and because they did the definition of the characters is blurred 2 the extraneous details up where there was action the historical letters became very long winded and i groaned whenever another one started because not a single one was short and to the point the feel of lena's office space raw_text.2448: enjoyable historical fiction although conklin tries to do too much in such a short book there were two main storylines going with a third and fourth trying to be told too and i really think each could have been expanded into its own book the way the two main characters intertwined was pretty preposterous but it was still a good story i think if the book had been longer with each story fully developed the outcome wouldn't have seemed so far fetched this could have been a really good weighty historical fiction novel instead it's an entertaining quick read josephine a slave girl in 1852 and lina a young new york lawyer in 2013ish are the characters josephine wants to escape lina is working on a slavery reparations case lina's father is an artist her mother died when lina was 4 josephine is discovered in modern times to perhaps have been an artist did she leave any descendants was the art created by josephine or by her owner see too much to cover in a short book

raw_text.2450: the house girl is the story of love and family secrets the book is really split between following two characters there is josephine a young house slave who is trying to find her place with her artist owner lu anne in virginia in the 1800s there is also lina a young lawyer who is charged with figuring a huge case while trying to deal with some family secrets of her own books that are split between two times are sometimes not my favorite but in this case i really liked both stories there was tons of intrigue in both time periods with both characters did josephine really create lu ann's art will lina be able to figure out the case and what really happened to her mother both of these things kept me flipping the pages wanting to find out how things end up for both characters there were a couple spots where the narrative got bogged down a little bit but overall this book kept moving aside from the character stories there was a lot to think about with this book obviously there is the subject of slavery josephine is a slave in virginia which was one of the states that played a role as a slavery stronghold it was really interesting to see life through her eyes there were some really interesting details that i know my fellow historical fiction lovers are going to enjoy

raw_text.2464: josephine is a house girl who lives at a foundering plantation with the mister and missus and a few other slaves once josephine decides that she is going escape to freedom nothing diverts her from that goal and nothing can bring her back to the southern plantation where she was abused josephine has allowed herself to forget a devastating past that begins to resurface once she makes the final decision that she will run she can't help but remember the first time she ran and the subsequent consequences lina is on partner track at a prestigious law firm when she is placed on a big project for a very special client her personal and professional lives merge when she first hears about josephine bell a slave that might have been the true artist of paintings previously attributed to her white plantation owner already familiar with the art world dives into the mystery involving the long ago events while investigating josephine and her descendants lina stumbles upon a personal issue that rocks her world the chapters of this book alternate between josephine and lina's point of view at times we get to see through other characters but it is primarily josephine and lina telling the story this format worked because the titles were clear at the beginning of each chapter and the stories are quite separate they could have been separate books i am grateful that this wasn't a depressing read it can be uncomfortable reading about certain issues but this one doesn't focus on the physical cruelty of slavery but instead focuses on the issue of identity and the fact that the harm of slavery goes much further than manual labor and punishments friends and i have previously discussed this issue and i was quite satisfied with how well it was done here i wasn't quite connected to josephine bell but i felt moderately connected to lina i was enthralled with this book from beginning to end the writing is great though it is connected to a tough subject ms conklin does a great job weaving a story that is much bigger than the idea of slavery

raw_text.2525: as reviewed in localiez magazine by me the house girl is a wonderfully crafted debut novel that oscillates between 1850's virginia and modern day nyc in virginia we meet josephine the 17 year old slave to ailing lu ann bell with no children of her own lu ann relies on josephine to care for her and assist her with her art years later in nyc lina a lawyer and daughter of an artist discovers the works of lu ann bell and the controversy facing the art world lina delves into the issue and finds herself questioning her own family history as well the house girl is reminiscent of the help with a dash of grisham it is certain to be a top book club selection of 2013 it is engaging from the start and filled with some beautifully written passages e g porter's review of oscar's show quite simply one of the most remarkable novels of this year

raw_text.2530: i thought i would give this book 3 stars after finishing it but the more i think about it there was nothing really remarkable about this book the best part of it was josephine's story but the author gave her second billing under the lousy present day story of lina the justice seeking lawyer who bears a strong resemblance to the author's own story the house girl at its heart is lina's quest to prove josephine the house girl of the title is the true artist of some highly valuable although contested artworks it is a little convoluted how she gets on this case so i will try my best to explain it in a rational way lina is a superstar first year attorney at a top law firm in new york city the firm is hired to bring a reparations lawsuit against the federal government on behalf of all the descendants of former slaves in the united states in order to do this they need a lead plaintiff lina and another hotshot first year attorney are given this task to complete in a few days lina's father is a well known artist and he has a show opening in a few days what a coincidence lina becomes aware of the controversy surrounding the work of artist luann bell because some scholars now think the work was actually done by luann's house girl josephine lina latches onto this story right away and call it serendipity lina just happens to meet a supposed descendant of josephine bell jasper he claims to have some josephine's work at his apartment and would she like to see it and would jasper like to be the lead plaintiff in her reparations case everything just works out there were too many coincidences like this in the book for me to take it seriously there were too many storylines the reader was supposed to care about to really get the time to care about any of them at all there were also too many earth shattering revelations and reveals to be plausible and the characters' reactions were not very realistic josephine had the most compelling story but conklin ditched her narrative less than halfway through the book leaving the reader hanging until the very end the book is very discussable just not very enjoyable

raw_text.2597: the house girl follows a period in time of two very different accomplished young women carolina sparrow is a young lawyer at a big company who is assigned to a repaprations case in which if won or reached to a deal would attempt to repair the damage caused by slavery in the form of monuments and scholarships in order to strengthen her case with a plaintiff lina investigates the authorship of the splendid bell paintings only to find that the paitings were drawn by josephine the house girl not her mistress josephine is a house slave and nurse who runs away from the bell creek farm at the age of 15 but is denied help because she is pregnant she goes back to the farm where she gives birth to a child who is dead as she's falsely told josephine attempts another escape at the age of 17 she is captured and tortured but then amended by a doctor who helps her escape again secretly falls in love with her and eventually saves and raises her son josephine commits suicide when she thinks that her free days are over and that she's going to be captured and taken back to slavery josephine's actions would lead us to think that she is a heartless woman first when she leaves lu anne dying without anyone to tend to her second when she learns that her son is still alive and yet she chooses to run away to her personal freedom and leave him and last when she commits suicide i found excuses for all josephine's actions she is a caring and passionate person josephine leaves lu anne despite her illness and loneliness because she had already given her so many years of her life so much time and energy and sometimes we have to be a little selfish and brave to do what's best for us no matter how much others would suffer she takes the road the opposite direction of her son because she is uncertain of her fate she might come back for him later if she survives or raise enough money to purchase his freedom either way she wouldn't expose herself to the danger of being captured she wouldn't expose her son to the uncertainty of the road and she wouldn't leave him there forever josephine commits suicide to exert the last effort of having will and freedom to choose her own fate she wants her life as well as her death to be her free choice although the book leaves many questions unanswered what happens with lina where does she work what happens between her and jasper how does her mother explain herself and how does lina take it does joseph read caleb's letter and know about his mother her survival story her art for the first time i don't mind the open end i don't raw_text.2628: in 1852 virginia josephine is a 17 year old slave who plans to run away but needs to finish taking care of her sick mistress lu ann bell before putting her plan into action in 2004 new york city lina is a young attorney who hoping to become partner agrees to handle a class action lawsuit for slavery reparations meanwhile an art exhibition comes to town featuring works by lu ann bell but there's a continuing controversy over whether lu ann actually painted everything or whether much of it is the work of her slave josephine looking for a face for the lawsuit lina decides to track down josephine's descendants and see how josephine's life ended up the story jumped back and forth between 1852 and 2004 and i think the parallel storylines were used to good effect i felt more drawn into josephine's life than i was into lina's but perhaps this was because everything in the novel tied back to josephine somehow the world around josephine seemed to spring to life and the author obviously did research to get the setting correct i was curious to know what had happened to josephine after 1852 when she'd seemingly disappeared from public record and interested in knowing how lina would figure it out lina's story felt much less developed than josephine's the best parts of lina's story were when she was actively investigating josephine's history where she'd lived the family who'd owned her and possible offspring however some of her discoveries bordered on implausible because josephine had become a big name in the art world due to the controversy over whether she had actually painted the works attributed to her mistress it seemed like someone would have already done the same research as lina and made the same discoveries especially since lina only had a few days in which to actively conduct this research i liked the fact that lina was making discoveries but found it improbable that she'd been the first to put the pieces together other parts of lina's story and the novel in general were less interesting and felt like filler material the entire reparations lawsuit lina was involved in seemed contrived nothing more than an excuse for lina to start digging into josephine's story surrounding characters weren't developed either all the characters from 1852 felt much more real than the ones from 2004 for example there was a subplot involving lina and her artist father who's opening a new exhibit yet despite how many pages this plot took up it failed to hold my attention this story felt contrived as well a convenient way to show lina's family history her dad who lina still lived with for no apparent reason except to keep him in the story told her that her mother died when lina was four but refused to so much as mention her again now suddenly lina wanted to know answers about what really happened and what her mother was like this plot didn't seem realistic and was not particularly interesting i found myself skimming pages whenever her father appeared this also had no apparent connection to the josephine plot making it a wholly unnecessary subplot that just took up space without enhancing anything while there were certainly interesting parts to this novel the entire question of what happened to josephine for example it was uneven overall it felt like too many big ideas were crammed into here under the guise of telling one story with multiple subplots instead of being cohesive the subplots were not given enough attention to feel realistic and characters were underdeveloped i think the author had a great starting point but ultimately lost focus and tried to include too much extraneous material

raw_text.2646: it is always amazing to read about the influence of the past on the present especially when a talented writer tackles the issue in such a way that new light is shed on previous knowledge tara conklin does just that in her debut novel the house girl set in present day new york city and antebellum virginia the novel is an examination of the long lasting effects of slavery it is also an exploration of art family and myriad ways decisions can affect a life lina sparrow is an ambitious young lawyer participating in the early stages of an historic case seeking reparations for descendents of american slaves when her father a renowned artist himself gives her an article which questions the authenticity of the art produced by lu anne bell the mistress of a virginia tobacco farm in the mid 1800s lina sees a remarkable connection to her case there is speculation in the art world that bell's work might have been produced in part and in some case entirely by her house slave josephine when lina meets a young musician who has a few family heirlooms that may be produced by either bell or josephine her world is entirely turned upside down a breathtaking story of past and present the connections and the reverberations that continue to be felt and will influence and shape the future the house girl is a unique look into the past as well as a powerful assessment of truth and justice conklin proves herself an adept and thoughtful storyteller and is a writer to watch

raw_text.2690: although the story was an fresh spin on the slave narrative the delivery was slow and boring conklin describes literally every single detail for each aspect of the story in a way that is purely tedious and adds nothing to the story for instance if lena enters a room you know what the carpet is like which direction the windows face how many dust motes float in the air if she did or didn't turn on the light etc this led to two glaring continuity issues that i can't believe made it through edits in one section lena and her father are having a conversation that begins with them standing in the hallway a sentence later oscar leans closer on the bed and puts his arm around lena two sentences after that they both sit on the floor in the hall also a barn burns down at one point and all of the animals perish two paragraphs later the family hitches their horses to a wagon though these details were minor they really irked me and made me kind of hate the whole story if it had been better edited with a more concise flow to the main narrative threads it would have been a much more effective story however if you are a lover of slavery tales with a modern element or enjoy books about lawyers you might like this much more than i did as an audio it was as well done as could be expected with the story the narrator had to work with she did an admirable job doing the different voices for the wide array of characters especially since most of them were men
raw_text.2691: i received an advanced reader's copy of this book and i am fairly certain that no one will ever let me win a giveaway again after this review this book is very very bad in a book about slavery and reparations i do not think it would be out of line to expand descriptions of key characters beyond dark and pale one main character has dark eyes and black hair her mom has dark hair and pale skin and dark green eyes her dad has dark frazzled hair and blue eyes someone has dark eyebrows death is darkness and so on for the entire book from a single page we read these three descriptions within the blue a woman's body seemed to float small dark haired featureless drowning the woman still unmistakably grace her long dark hair parted on the left her lips full and swollen as though bitten the painted eyes loomed large dark as lina's own if the dark descriptions do not drive you to madness the commas and random listing of adjectives will the slave's eyes of shifting color a shadow of blue here green there hazel and brown and gray the colors fractured together and split i cannot even begin to review the plot instead i just want to say that the idea of a novel about reparations and slavery is really intriguing i hope someone with skill or a strong editor has a go at it

raw_text.2704: i don't know how many times i've repeated the same conversation with others it goes essentially like this it's so hard to pick a book for a book club that everyone can enjoy an otherwise well written insightful book is ruined by profanity or unnecessary sexual scenes it can be frustrating to find really good books so when i find one that i can recommend to everyone i am especially delighted the house girl by tara conklin is such a book well written with superb attention to detail and a wonderful ability to make scenes come to life the house girl tells the stories of two women josephina the artistically talented house slave in virginia and lina the ladder climbing young attorney in new york city their stories become intertwined when lina starts working on a retribution case for a big client looking for the perfect plaintiff lina discovers that josephina may actually be the true artist of the famous works of her owner to be honest the story began slowly and i struggled to stay involved i must admit that i only had quick moments of time to read lately and the house girl sat neglected on my night stand for a few weeks it was only the last few days that i was able to devote the time this book deserved i spent the last few evenings devouring the story and falling in love with the likable and rich characters part heartrending tales of the abuse of slaves part a genealogical mystery and part a story of individual healing the house girl won me over
