raw_text.2718: i'm struggling with this review the story was incredibly well researched and the timing of starting this novel the same time ta nehisi coates published his piece on reparations couldn't have been better conklin does a good job articulating how the successes of this country and its businesses were founded on the backs of slaves and that acknowledgment of this fact either by the government or its populace has been slow in coming she also does a good job speaking for josephine and not glossing over the cruelty of slavery or the peril to those escaping or attempting to assist in escaping she is a little too easy on slaveowners but this is a minor quibble compared to the bigger problem of the modern half of the perspective switching narrative this story would have been much stronger without trying to develop a story for lina delving into her personal and professional growth and the thing with her mother wasn't done very cohesively so the novel as a whole ended up being a little disjointed where i'm struggling is the fact that this sort of novel black perspective written by white was executed so much better than either the help frothy rage rising or the secret life of bees so out of spite i want to give it more stars to counterbalance all the high ratings on the other two novels sadly the lina narrative was too weak for me to be willing to squeeze out that fourth star the josephine narrative is totally worth the read though including the actual chart of names of slaves was a good humanizing touch

raw_text.2734: an attempt at paralleling the lives of a house slave and a budding lawyer the house girl follows josephine in the past and lina in the present in their efforts to create lives they are happy living josephine a house slave in antebellum virginia who has tried escape in the past battles with her love of art shared with her mistress and her desire to be a free woman at the ripe old age of sixteen josephine shows more determination class and strength than any child should ever be expected to possess lina a new lawyer for a top notch law firm in new york city strives to impress the unyielding partner she works under while still clinging onto the wispy concept of family lina is a more complex on the surface that josephine however this is purposeful as the present day character the reader is allowed to get to know her as she gets to know herself josephine the character surrounded by mystery and unattainable desires is more difficult to understand which mirrors the way she fits into the story when lina is tasked with working one of the firm's biggest cases a slave reparations lawsuit she is suddenly thrown back into the world of josephine the reader learns much about josephine before lina has the chance to however lina does catch up at a point in the book - which ultimately makes the reading more exciting rather than anticipating what lina will find the reader is waiting on baited breath as is lina to find the next clue as a lover of historical fiction and a recent graduate of law school i was very excited about this book unfortunately i found it to be a bit disappointing lina's character in particular had so many facets so many lines of story going on that they weren't all unveiled enough there were some pieces that were left unanswered others whose discussions felt shallow my biggest issue with the book was the fact that it was premised on two women finding themselves creating a live worth living thereby paralleling the two a slave who not only has attempted escape in the past but is taking steps towards making a better life for herself is in no way comparable to a lawyer in new york city yes both women had worthy struggles but to me it feels disingenuous to try to compare the struggles and even the victories encountered by slaves to those experienced by lawyers on a more positive note conklin does do a fabulous job making the characters seem relatable and likeable neither is perfect and to give heroines a dose of humanity is often difficult despite taking issue with the underlying purpose and premise of the book it was certainly written in a way that kept me wanting to read more

raw_text.2798: what can i say i loved this book the house girl is written in the new format that seems to be all the rage these days switching back and forth between historical fiction and a contemporary character story josephine is a mixed race slave living on a plantation in virginia and lina is an up and coming lawyer in new york who has been given a difficult case reparations for descendants of slavery the author tells each woman's story in such loving and beautiful detail she really is a gifted writer and in places her style of writing reminded me of donna tartt's the goldfinch which is the highest possible praise the author moves seamlessly between both stories and ties their lives together in a way that works and makes sense some of the writers who are using this style of going back and forth between characters make it almost impossible to follow both stories they wait too long between switching and then you forgot who the other character was and what was going on with them and then you spend most of the novel wondering how the two characters are even connected this author did a much better job of writing in this format i happen to think tara conklin has a lot of talent she came up with two great stories wrote both in fabulous detail threw in some wonderful references to art and the life of an artist talked about loss ambition family dysfunction deceit and slavery and made it all work kudos to her

mysterious house slave artist runaway the course of her life is altered this book was great i don't read a lot of slavery fiction something i am trying to remedy and this book was the perfect gateway drug i really enjoyed both of the main characters josephine and lina and found their voices equally engaging i absolutely love the split narrative trope in historical fiction and it worked brilliantly here at first i thought lina was going to end up being annoying but i warmed to her character and ended up really enjoying her throughout the book josephine's character was fascinating she was raw_text.2848: i did this as an audiobook and the narration was excellent focusing on two somewhat related stories of a young slave in virginia in 1852 and a young lawyer in the present this was a strong story about two very different women i enjoyed the focus on art woven throughout the story in some works it can be jarring to move back and forth between two stories but it worked well here conklin's strongest writing was in the small details and inner thoughts of the characters and developing their unique voices though there were a few clumsily done plot points there was a good amount of complexity with side stories about lina's parents lina's father's newest art show and some hints of not quite honest doings regarding the organization caretaking luanne bell's legacy and estate overall this was the best kind of book to do as an audiobook - totally engaging and one that easily allowed me to get lost in the story but slow enough paced that i could listen here and there during my commute without feeling tortured waiting to know what happened next
raw_text.2849: i had pretty high hopes for this book because i'm fascinated by pre and post civil war era history and it started out well enough enough to pass my three chapter rule if i finish three chapters and i don't care about the characters or what happens to them i walk away and don't finish reading it the storyline was interesting based on the premise of a lawsuit for slave reparations and rooted in a historical sequence of events taking place on a virginia plantation both of the main characters were interesting and i wanted to know what happened to them unfortunately about halfway through things become sort of predictable i knew exactly where the story was going and there were far too many easy giveaways hey this character has a middle name that's the same as someone who lived in days gone by i wonder if they're related somewhat more disappointing the story's final resolution was almost too neat look a letter that explains everything to be believable with the rich historical background available to draw upon and a main character who is supposed to be smart and savvy it seems like the wrap up deserved to be a little more complex than it was if you're looking for really deep literary fiction with a historical bent you'll be disappointed on the other hand if you want a quick read with likeable characters and strong historical research it's worth finishing i realize some people have loved this book and some have hated it but i feel somewhere in the middle it's got its weak points to be sure but still not a bad way to kill a couple of hours on the couch each night

of new york on the path to partnership she works the long and thankless hours for cases that don't seem to mean much that is until a very wealthy and powerful client offers the law firm the chance to handle a class action suit on behalf of the descendants of american slaves and lina is given the assignment to find the perfect plaintiff to be the figurehead for that very class action lawsuit josephine bell is a 17 year old black house girl on an old dying virginia farm as the companion to the white mistress lu anne bell she is given special privileges including learning to read and dabble in painting with lu anne but when lu anne always in poor health slowly fades away from tumors josephine begins to make plans to run away but before she dies lu anne has one secret that she has to tell josephine that causes josephine to make a hard choice the two stories merge when lina's father suggests the possibility that the acclaimed art work of lu anne bell was really done by the slave josephine bell lina begins to research that possibility and decides that if that story is true that one of josephine's descendants would be the perfect plaintiff but the art work that focuses on plantation life and is of high value is owned by a virginia foundation that doesn't want history changed a side story is about lina's parents there seems to be a mystery surrounding her mother's death when lina was young with which her father can't seem to come to terms when her father decides to do an art show that is filled with his interpretations of his wife lina finds she now must face her own history this book is basically a simple story of two women who must come to terms with their lives the life of a house girl and her plans to run away are interesting and seem quite believable what seems a bit improbable is how lina seems to be able to find josephine's possible ancestor even though josephine disappeared in 1852 to never be found again

teen gave birth to a child which unknown to her had been sold to another plantation she thought the child had died the lawyer lina is the daughter of a mildly but increasingly successful artist she raw_text.2867: tthe house girl is a fantastic and engrossing novel the dual storylines of carolina call me lina in the year 2004 and of the slave josephine bell in 1852 virginia was a story i could barely put down each woman is a strong well written character and in josephine's case the bulk of the novel is written about only one day in her life but though that pivotal day we gain so much insight into who josephine is as a person it is absolutely astonishing i enjoyed the historical part of the novel a bit more than the present day side though lina and the mystery of her mother is gripping i would like to know more maybe a novel from the mother's pov...but that is another aspect entirely tthe flow of the two narratives is smooth as butter each change over to the other character comes at just the right time i also loved loved the 'side' characters though which lina and we the reader gain insight into the past and what happened to josephine dorthea and caleb are great characters even though we only learn their part in the story through letters that they wrote to loved ones i thought it was a magnificent and unique way to tell the story i will most definitely be recommending this book and eagerly anticipating conkin's next novel

raw_text.2882: this was definitely a nice read for over winter vacation the book bops back and forth between the story of a slave named josephine in the mid 1800s planning her escape to the north and present day manhattan where a young lawyer named lina sparrow is working on a case about slavery reparations i enjoyed the intertwining of the two stories very much they were distinct in and of themselves the character josephine and her mistress are very dynamic the reader very much understands how even having a benevolent owner still could not possibly justify the idea that one human could own another exactly what lina the lawyer is researching for her case unfortunately i found the modern half of the book that follows the character lina somewhat contrived her father is an artist and her mother disappeared from her life when she was just a toddler the relationship between lina and her bosses family and partial love interests seems so much like a lifetime movie about a twenty something struggling with life but with no financial realities of any kind this aspect did not sour me on the house girl though like i mentioned at the beginning of this post it was nice light vacation reading

raw_text.2907: 3 5 5 the house girl marks tara conklin's debut novel the story is told in two narratives that of josephine a 17 yr old house slave in 1850's virginia and lina a class action lawyer in 2004 new york the opening chapter belonged to josephine and i was immediately captivated she is planning to run and it won't be the first time "mister hit josephine with the palm of his hand across her left cheek and it was then she knew she would run she heard the whistle of the blow felt the sting of skin against skin her head spun and she was looking back over her right shoulder down to the fields where the few men mister had left were working the tobacco " lina's law firm is looking for the perfect plaintiff to be the 'face' of a lawsuit being brought seeking reparations for descendants of american slaves she stumbles across josephine's name through her father's work he is an artist and there is great controversy concerning who really painted a series of paintings attributed to josephine's 'missus' lu anne bell was it lu anne or was it the slave josephine lina's narrative follows the search for the descendants and i found this part of the story extremely interesting lina is also going through her own personal difficulties she has her own family issues that have been left untended for many years i wanted to like lina more than i did although she is a high powered lawyer she is still a petulant child with her father and given that she is highly intelligent and quite adept at research i cannot believe that she never sought to confirm the details of her mother's life and death by the middle of the book i found myself speed reading through her sections it was josephine's story that grabbed my heart and wouldn't let go i know it's a fictionalization but conklin has based her novel on facts heartbreaking facts additional narrators are introduced through their letters that of a slave doctor and a young woman whose home was a stop on the underground railroad i enjoyed these sections very much as well i chose to listen to the house girl the reader was bahni turpin she was excellent her interpretation of josephine chillingly brought her story to life the cadence and tone she used for lina was completely different of course but i found it matched what i thought of lina a bit whiny the accents used for other characters especially that of lu anne bell were excellent and believable this one is poised to be the darling of book clubs everywhere there is a reading group guide i did enjoy this debut effort but there are other books dealing with slavery and in a deeper manner that i would recommend ahead of this title still it was an entertaining listen

raw_text.2941: the story is split into two narratives josephine the house slave in 1852 and lina sparrow in 2004 we go through a few weeks of lina's life as she learns secrets about her father mother her life in general and about josephine from various sources in contrast we see only a day in the life of josephine josephine's story also includes her memories of when she was younger letters between abolitionist sisters and a long letter from a man to a child i liked how the two stories were woven together i liked that lina was in her mid 20s and trying to find her way through a shifting world she's out of college and very good at her job she doesn't like what's unknown and unknowable she likes things that are familiar as her personal world is altered and as she learns about josephine lina changes in little ways with large effects how she handles things reacts to things sees things is different at the end of these few weeks of her life than they were before her story is very believable josephine's story was also lovely i liked how tara conklin included other people's opinions on the relationship between josephine and her mistress some seeing it as slave master others as daughter mother or student teacher josephine's emotions are easily felt and understood throughout her day the illness of her mistress and how josephine handles it her mistress and mister were subtle and nice josephine is 17 and had already seen and experienced so much that her story though spanning only a day and some memories was very dynamic and varied in its tale
raw_text.2942: the author weaves together the story of josephine an enslaved house girl from virginia before the civil war and lina sparrow young lawyer assigned to a class action suit claiming reparation for the descendants of slaves lina's search for a qualified slave descendant to be the plaintiff leads her to josephine who may have been the actual artist of famous paintings attributed to her plantation mistress josephine's heart rending and demoralizing story is slowly revealed through lina's search of historical records and letters written during josephine's time period i'm fascinated with anything about genealogy family trees and family history records so i really enjoyed this book there were two parallel storylines and both were most intriguing the story of josephine is richly told historical fiction and lina's account of her search for josephine's descendants made for a compelling whodunit

raw_text.2947: i am usually weary of antebellum stories about enslaved africans writer by writers of european ancestry the stories always seem to be lacking depth u0026amp human understanding to a large extent however that is not this case with the style prose and storytelling of tara conklin she wove an intricate tale of a house girl's quest for freedom and the legacy she unintentionally left behind via a sickly mistress who gave her liberties with paintbrushes and literacy then we have the short upwardly mobile litigator with an eccentric artist father and a trillion unanswered questions about her mother a mother whose missing presence has a haunting like quality in her life that is heightened by her fathers sudden decision to create an exhibit based on her image and the question of ancestry tied into the reparations case i won't spoil it for you by going into great detail like i want lets just sum it as this nail biting page turner who will read in a white heat emotional roller coaster a fine crafted set of stories great imagery syntax and diction

raw_text.2967: i thought this book was going to be better than it actually was i liked the idea of having the two narrators one from the present and the other from the mid 19th century but unfortunately the house girl was not written well it tells the story of lina a 24 year old lawyer who is put on a case of a class action suit to give reparations to the descendants of slaves she must find a lead plaintiff she becomes interested in the story of a slave girl josephine bell who is the house girl of lu anne bell who posthumously receives fame for her art the story was interesting as i am usually fascinated by historical fiction i was much more interested in josephine's story than lina's lina was a shallow stereotypical predictable character lacking depth also there were letters and descriptions which were uninteresting and unnecessary in all by the time i was about half way through the book i found myself wanting to finish it already so i could move on to other books i have been waiting to read i would recommend this book to people who are interested in historical fiction and to those interested in the antebellum south
raw_text.2968: i liked the mix of historic with current day characters tara conklin weaves her characters together and demonstrates that we are all part of history whether we are aware of that fact or not josephine the seventeen year old house slave on a virginia tobacco farm stole my heart with her plight and lina sparrow the lawyer researching slavery for a class action lawsuit had her own compelling story of loss and self discovery conklin keeps the reader focused on both of these characters by alternating her chapters between the antebellum south and current day new york sparrow is focused on finding a witness for her case and josephine is singularly focused on her freedom these two characters are on different paths that eventually cross bringing them together in surprising ways i would recommend this book to anyone is who interested in the antebellum south as a historical setting conklin's law background supports the story's legal elements in a believable way her inside look at the cut throat nature of a law office is totally believable

raw_text.2995: s lu ann bell is a recognized artist in the south however evidence surfaces that carolina lina sparrow is a young lawyer that mostly works corporate cases in the city of new york all that changes however when the firm she works for takes on a reparations suit on behalf of the people affected by slavery lina is put in charge of finding a plaintiff to be the face of their case her research leads her to josephine bell a house girl that worked for the bell family in virginia in the 1850's lu ann bell is a recognized artist in the south however evidence surfaces that suggest josephine not her mistress lu ann is the artist responsible for the paintings as lina tries to find a josephie bell descendant she uncovers a the truth about herself this book certainly had promise and by all accounts i should have loved it the concept is fantastic yet it was no quite up to par told in tandem from the perspectives of josephine and lina the story takes place in the modern city of new york and virginia in the old south josephine's story overpowered lina's no doubt lina's story was stale lacking character at times there were too many coincidences in lina's personal and professional life which seemed rather implausible the backstory for josephine was the complete opposite it had complexity it was a multi layered story that drew me in and actually surprised me this was the redeeming factor that makes this novel readable while i enjoyed the novel it was not as good as expected

raw_text.3032: the house girl is a novel by tara conklin that covers the stories of two women josephine bell a nurse slave and artist and lina sparrow a modern attorney assigned to find direct slave descendants for a suit that could make her career i very much enjoyed this novel however i do have to say that i had far more preference to the chapters about josephine it was in the telling of josephine's story that i feel tara really found her voice as a writer the passages were lyrical beautifully descriptive and drew you deeply into the lives and atmosphere of the slave owning deep south there are few writers who can immerse you so deeply into an alien landscape and show you the world through the lens of the characters through josephine's story she does just that the inner struggles with her owner who taught her to read and draw creating an almost daughterly loyalty with her desire for freedom and knowledge that the loyalty is but an illusion this did not in my opinion carry over so much in lina's portion of the story this may be due to the tara allowing too much of the attorney to infuse into it but she seemed to struggle more in the writing of these sections the characters didn't seem to have near the depth and complexity of those of josephine's world even so it was still a well told story and for the most part beautifully crafted i would highly recommend this book to anyone looking for a truly immersing read

raw_text.3041: this book is reasonably deft at handling its material and is an engaging read at its core though are a couple of problems the biggest problem is that in the process of weaving together the stories of two women one a modern lawyer and the other a slave in virginia before the civil war it becomes yet another narrative that turns the story of a black person into a device to help a white person become more self actualized the help by kathryn stockton falls prey to this at first chapters alternate between the two women but not long after the halfway mark we stop being privy to josephine's narrative she's the black slave woman and we hear the rest of the story through letters left behind by more white people further erasing her voice and her agency and pushing the character even further into just being a plot device the use of the letters is to help bring tension to the present time line but unfortunately dilutes the best part of this novel josephine's story and her voice and experiences are far more interesting and compelling so it's a shame that her presence in the story drops out the other problem with this is that the structure of two narrative plots one long past and one contemporary has been done a lot and this novel doesn't really bring much freshness to that structure also the plot line of child of artists becomes super uptight loses sight of her own emotions creativity also feels tired and stale i don't actually hate this book it was a pleasant enough read but it just didn't wow me either

raw_text.3059: i don't often review a book but i have to say something about this one i just have to wonder about all the 4 star and 5 star ratings here this book is readable certainly but not at all the page turner i expected from hearing others idolize it the present day character lina is a lawyer in a high powered ny firm looking for a plaintiff to represent a class action lawsuit on behalf of slaves brought to the united states who were obviously never compensated for their work the book moves between lina and josephine a house girl slave in the 1800s working for a mr and missus sic bell mr bell is not having good luck with his crops and feeling soured treats josephine cruelly while missus bell more or less seems to take a maternal interest in her at any rate the characters of the past seem far better developed than lina her bosses and co workers her father and the artsy crowd around them that's okay though and forgivable it's the absolutely ridiculous thread that runs throughout where lina feels she is not being told the truth about her mother's death in a car accident when lina was a small child and when she can't seem to get a straight answer from her father she just accepts it she is an attorney for pete's sake and is doing realms of research on this case if you want to know how someone died take a taxi to city hall and ask for the department of vital statistics as my relatives in scotland used to say they'll always tell you who's been hatched matched and dispatched anyway i couldn't let that little detail slip by that being said the idea that josephine was the real artist behind the priceless pictures painted and drawn by missus bell is an interesting one and the historical settings and information are interesting as well but the book is way too long and i find that i don't really care very much about lina or her disappeared mother too much going on i confess i skimmed at times i did make it through to the end

raw_text.3063: "the house girl" holds a lot of promise the story of a slave her hardships and her daring escape the story of a woman discovering the identity of this slave and doggedly tracing her lineage antebellum artwork and the nagging suspicion that the woman who was said to have painted them isn't the true artist on top of all that the discovery of a new and potentially spectacular writer and a book worthy of recommendations to friends and family there will be readers who enjoy and or find satisfaction in "the house girl" some will sing its praises me i feel relief rather than pleasure in finishing it i started reading it in early january and didn't finish it until mid march it rarely takes me that long to read a book and it wasn't because i was busy with other things it was because i never felt an urge to come back to it other than the need to finish it so i could write a review and move on to something else there were long periods where i wasn't reading out of sheer apathy i would even go so far as to say that it felt like a chore to read it i'm not saying tara conklin isn't a good writer she is but she failed to pull me in like other authors have done and i attribute it to the following 1 tunnecessary and or excessive detail which has the potential to bore a reader to death on page 73 conklin provides a list of names from slave interviews that goes on for a page and a half why it has little relevance and is a waste of print she follows this with a chart lina creates that few readers will be interested in interpreting another waste of print the letters of dorothea rounds begin on page 205 and continue on for 38 pages much of the backstory provided in them failing to further the plot the letter by caleb harper is insufferable in its own ways by this time i'd had it with the time wasting narratives when he wrote "...it is clear to me that i must go back i must re draw this narrative and begin long before the day i first saw josephine..." i found myself thinking "no...no...please don't " conklin wastes pages giving caleb a backstory that again does nothing to further the plot cutting most of this extraneous stuff out would've improved pacing and helped to keep my attention 2 tdetachment from her own creation great authors are emotionally involved with their characters a reader will recognize this and in turn become emotionally involved themselves it's what makes for an exciting and memorable read conklin's efforts feel flaccid and the consequence is one dimensional people which a reader has trouble connecting to or sympathizing with i become frustrated by books that are telling two stories simultaneously where one story is a character investigating a character s from the other story usually from a different time period the character doing the digging suffers from the author spending all their time writing about their sleuthing which in turns leaves them with almost no personality lina falls victim to this the backstory of her dead mother and the strained relationship with her father managing to bring her just a few notches above being totally flat yet even that didn't stir much curiosity or empathy from me i wasn't all that interested in josephine either and i think this is due to her chapters becoming briefer and smaller in number as the book moves on the kitchen house by kathleen grissom had similar problems the rest of conklin's characters lack depth it's disappointing when you spend over 350 pages with these people and leave feeling like you never learned anything about them much less felt something for them the book has its good points too conklin skillfully invokes setting awaking the senses with resonant description the minutiae and the momentous blending well the relationship between josephine and lu ann is touching there is an unspoken bond between them both of them having suffered through stillborn births this bond provides good conflict josephine warring with her desire to flee the bell farm and obtain the freedom she so desires and her obligation to stay and care for the ailing missus that has been the lone source of kindness in a world of cruelty jasper battle lends the book another good spark as a love interest for lina but i felt conklin held back too long in letting a potential romance blossom and there still ends up only being a hint of it at book's end it's a good first effort but it's not enough to get me to pass the word on conklin needs some refining and a little more style before i'll be moved to recommend her

raw_text.3073: i'd like to preface this review by saying i think tara conklin is a very intelligent and very capable author she's weaving quite a bit here and for the most part that works but when i really think about this book something in me breaks and it makes me not care for it very much by the end hear me out first off there is a huge flaw with the major character lina we are meant to believe that she is this bull dog who'd make an excellent private detective but and this is a huge but she doesn't figure out her father's lies and vagaries regarding her deceased mother right because if you had a monstrous gaping hole in your heart where your mother used to be you'd totally never even think to research your mother at all especially when your father won't talk about her and you hear differing reports about her cause of death i mean let me get this straight you can trace down the living descendants of a former run away slave who disappeared off everyone else's radar and eluded discovery for decades but you can't even google your own mother it's 2004 we had the internet back then so yeah that really wasn't working for me secondly there should be a cap on how many times an author can use the word verdant in a novel that's not an every day word unless you're martha stewart got it good i'm just so mad because i wanted to like this book so much do you know understand i hope so there were other much more serious off putting aspects of the novel for me bigger cultural issues that end up feeling shamefully hollow the premise of a slavery reparations case at her law firm the fact that josephine and her living descendant are reduced to saving or helping the white people who happen to find them the jasper being too white and the indignation we're meant to feel on his behalf etc it all reads very uncomfortably and reinforces the notion that this book is specifically marketed to middle aged white women which i am but if i can tell that it's probably not helping anybody's cause race is clearly still an issue in our country it's a sensitive topic and conklin works very hard to respect the lengthy and painful history there but in doing so she creates an impressionist painting of slavery when she craves realism instead of feeling uplifted or improved i ended up feeling like melly clayton checking under the rugs for the real dirt what i mean i guess is that the shades and tones are right in the traditional fictional dialogue of slavery but the picture never comes into resounding focus and the work suffers for it josephine is too young too beautiful to free even in her oppression and suffering she is a degas ballerina trapped in the 1850s south a wry renoir girl giving a mona lisa smile to the reader but she is not real not the flesh and bones we need her to be in order for her to sufficiently be lina's muse and thus ours and since artistic creation is the thread that pulls these two narratives together initially you'll forgive my metaphor in some ways lina hangs on to her romantic ideal of josephine much like missus lu uses her as a surrogate child josephine fills the void of the other mother who ran away it's not from a place of love or genuine care but from filling a need in lina's own life for a mother for a role model for a warrior but again that sat poorly with me josephine was used and abused her entire life while the novel's last thoughts are her own they fall flat because we all know the unhappy punchline regarding her personal narrative words given to a white man who loves her i don't know this one should have been my bread and butter some mystery some potential romance some history but it was a victim to the privilege with which it was written and that's the biggest shame of all
raw_text.3074: although i normally do not like books that switch between characters and or time frames this author did an excellent job of it because i actually looked forward to finding out what was happening in each person's life the idea of trying to win a case for the long ago relatives of slaves seems wrong to me but liked the thinking that there should be more done to remember the efforts of people wanting to help slaves get a better life this makes you think of present day versions of slave work as the lawyer lina realized her life both at work and at home was more similar to josephine the house slave
raw_text.3075: this was the first book i've ever listened to using our newest technology a download from the local library it was a gift to be read to i was the audience of one here is what this book stirred in me 1 could there really be a successful reparations class action suit would this bring justice would it narrow the divide 2 why is the perceived stigma of a mother leaving a child behind greater and more intense than a father doing the same did the character's childhood experience improve when her mother left 3 the disconnect when you study something with passion and gusto in school and then go and practice it in the real world why is that 4 the frequent and profound small world experiences of nyc i lived them they are remarkable heartwarming and often will bring goosebumps a decade later 5 if i had to track my time in 6 minute increments would i live more in the present 6 why don't we know more about the underground railroad and the people who were stops along it 7 i never thought about the ancillary economies of a slave society the capture reward return vs re sell the hired hands to prepare the slaves for the aforementioned the brokering of the sales themselves it was profoundly deeper and more vast than simply being a slave owner and not having to pay wages insurance taxes etc on your employees 8 how many businesses whose inception occurred during and also profited from the use of slavery are still in existence today that was a very poor sentence i know 9 what did it mean to be free if you could be retrieved and returned at any time 10 have there been any reparations law suits were they successful

raw_text.3084: enjoyed this a lot 1 the structure of the book is engaging slipping as it does between current day nyc and antebellum south i was drawn into both narratives happy to return to each chapter to chapter and admiring of the threads weaving them together 2 the book is realist chick lit for my demographic and i liked the fact that the narrative arcs included questions of creative and professional integrity romance coming of age all key bildungsroman aspects for the late modern yuppie female 3 what sets it apart and elevates it for me is the author's willingness to tread into much more substantial territory the legacy of slavery in the south and elsewhere the provenance of art and authorship the choices available to women whether how these are mitigated by race then and now the potentially soul deadening work of cutthroat big city law firms these issues are hard to treat deeply in this particular genre but overall i found the book engaging and thought provoking

raw_text.3112: review of the house girl by tara conklinin tara conklin's the house girl lawyer lina sparrow is tasked with finding someone to be the face for a class action suit her manhattan law firm is handling that seeks reparations for descendants of american slaves lina is drawn to the story of josephine a slave in the home of now famous artist lu anne bell there are those in the art world who are disputing the bell family's claim that the paintings were done by lu anne but instead were the work of her house slave josephine lina convinces her boss to let her track down what happened to josephine's possible descendants lina is also dealing with the death of her mother which happened several years ago but which she and her father never talked about i really enjoyed author conklin's the house girl especially josephine's story and learning what the life of a slave had been like conklin's chapters switched between lina in the current day and the ways of a corporate law firm back in time to the 1850s and josephine's story of runaway slaves i highly recommend it
raw_text.3113: the house girl by tara conklin is a debut novel it seemly is a story about a lawyer lisa sparrow in a large corporation with drive toward becoming a partner however it is the story she uncovers that changes the book lisa is asked to help find a person who is a good fit for a lawsuit over slavery we are introduced to a controversy in the art world about lu anne bell and her slave josephine which one is the artist the slave or the master this forms the second line of the story the stories while over 100 years apart are twisted together together they are a powerful tale that leads toward a an interesting conclusion i enjoyed reading the house girl in a style similar to jodi picoult or chris bohjalian the stories continue to meander in an out of the past and present the house girl also allows us to view our reaction to slavery and the modern day interpretation of racial stereotypes the book is well written and well paced allowing us views of the story to come

raw_text.3115: this book combines a modern fiction story with a historical one lina sparrow is a lawyer who is asked to find someone who descends from a slave to take on an class action lawsuit in which the descendants of slaves would be repaid for all the labor and hardship their ancestors had to suffer with her father an artist lina comes across the paintings of a female slave owner there is some suggestion that the paintings were actually made by her slave maid josephine as this would make for a great story in the media as well as in the court case lina goes about trying to find out whether the paintings really were made by josephine and whether she can find a descendant intermixed with lina's research are chapters about josephine her story takes place all in one day a day in which she has decided to finally run away from her "owners" a farmer and his terminally ill wife she thinks back on a previous occasion that she tried to run away as the day goes on she prepares to leave but circumstances don't make it easy for her to do so this book started really very good and i thoroughly enjoyed reading it it was well written and the historical and modern parts contrasted beautifully the story about josephine was a sad one but also one of languid days fresh air and fields all around the modern city life is all about making money and standing out from amongst your colleagues i was a little disappointed with a story development near the end of the book also the idea of a class action law suit in which all descendants of slaves would be compensated was rather unlikely and practically impossible too but overall this was a very good read

raw_text.3155: amazing story with a very unique premise you know an author has created something great when filled with emotion and anticipation you find yourself thinking about the characters throughout the day i was sad when the book ended tara conklin's writing style is vivid and emotional but not over the top and she makes the reader really care about the characters or intensely hate them as the case may be i had the sense that she had really researched her topics which i really appreciate as a reader also i know one should not judge a book by its cover but the cover on the house girl is so lovely it would be a nice framed addition to a home library wall the only reason i gave 4 stars instead of 5 is because of the coarse language peppered throughout the book an element that really bothers me especially when it really adds nothing to the story other than that i recommend the house girl to anyone interested in the antebellum period art history slavery issues or those who just want to read a moving story

raw_text.3171: i have to preface this review by noting that i read this book for my book club and it is not a book i would have picked up on my own as a result i can't say i enjoyed reading it i felt satisfied by the ending thank goodness but i basically had to force myself to read it this however is more a symptom of not being a preferred story type for me than actual quality of the book or writing having said all that there were a few things that i think even outside my general dislike of depressing fiction are worth mention and critique first while i understand josephine is was an artist and sees saw things through an artists eye the overly descriptive writing got on my nerves even in people's hand written letters to one another they were describing refracted light and how the moon shimmered etc it was just too much for me secondly the interminable lists there are soooo many lists of things in the book some of them very long yes some of this served a purpose but god so boring to read third there are a number of unbelievable coincidences that occur yes some of them could be that information wasn't hidden so much as no one had thought to look for it but still lina's investigation was too easy fourth why did lina have to romantically consider almost every man she encountered you don't see this with male characters fifth the resolution of the mother just no that's all i'll say on that i did very much appreciate that there was no apology for dressing up or hiding the horrors of slavery nor was it ever gratuitously shown we didn't need to see a man whipped to death or a woman raped to know those things were happening the inhumanity of the establishment came through quite clearly as did some people's blindness to it and other's struggles with living with it but feeling helpless to change it even when they wanted to my final assessment is that this is what it is a thought provoking 'book club' sort of book does anyone read these just for enjoyment no one i know

raw_text.3196: i enjoyed this book and was torn between giving it three or four stars the book is two stories told in parallel one is the story of the house slave josephine and her efforts to free herself josephine is the house slave and maid to mistrus luanne bell a woman whose children are stillborn or die shortly after birth a woman who is losing her mind and her health and a woman who wants to be a good artist josephine is a gifted artist who has been taught to read and write and who wants to be free she escapes once but is forced back to the bell family because she is about to give birth to mister's child josephine thinks the child is dead not knowing that mister has given the child to a neighboring plantation owner what's the other story lina sparrow a newly minted manhattan lawyer is given a tough assignment find a descendant of josephine to represent all the slaves who are owed reparations for their years of slave labor a rich client sees this as a groung breaking case all lina has to do is find a descendant who is willing and able to be black enough oh and she has to prove that all the art work done by luanne bell was actually the product of josephine the house girl a foundation owns most of the art work and relevant documentation lina is a good candidate for this assignment because both her late mother and her living father were are artists but lina learns her mother is still alive and josephine's descendant doesn't want to get mixed up in a lawsuit i enjoyed the premise of the lawsuit and the research lina had to do on josephine lina's family story is not nearly as interesting as the chapters on josephine and the chapters that deal strictly with lina's assignment the end makes sense and it just figures came right out of my mouth but it is still an interesting read better than beach read but not earth shattering

raw_text.3205: this is the story of a house slave josephine living in pre civil war virginia luanne belle is josephine's mistress we find out that there is a controversy brewing in the present day art world for years people have assumed that luaanne belle was the artist who painted a number of beautiful paintings depicting life on a southern plantation her art has been celebrated around the world however art authenticators who have examined the paintings are thinking that it was not luanne belle who made those beautiful paintings but josephine the house girl this is also the story of carolina sparrow a first year associate for a big law firm in new york city carolina's boss decides to take on a new case a case on slavery reparations carolina's assignment find a worthy plaintiff a descendant of a slave who can show the immense harm that was done an impossible task it may seem however carolina comes across the story of the house girl and seeks to find if josephine has any living descendants the book travels back and forth in time between josephine and lina's point of view a lot of other people who read this book thought the author's descriptions were too long and unnecessary however i really liked tara conklin's writing style i enjoyed the descriptions and how it allowed the reader to really envision one was in lena's small office at clifton u0026amp harp or on the belle creek plantation in virginia with that said i did find the ending to be a little predictable but overall i enjoyed the house girl and would recommend it
raw_text.3207: once i got past the first few chapters which were a bit slow the story was quite engaging and became a quick read it is about josephine a 17 year old slave in virginia and lina a lawyer working in new york josephine is contemplating running away while lina is involved in developing a legal case involving reparations for slavery she is searching for descendants of josephine to be involved in the case but first she must find out what happened to her the author loses me a bit with lina's complicated life she lives with her artist father in brooklyn and has been told that her mother died in a car crash despite all her time searching on line when she is given other information about her mother's death she doesn't even bother googling it or doing any research whatsoever about her mother for someone who is so determined and thorough in her investigation about the life of this other woman she seems oddly complacent about finding anything out about her mother but overall a good read

raw_text.3218: the house girl is a novel with two parallel stories the first about a 19 year old slave girl josephine bell living on a plantation in 1852 and the second follows lina sparrow an ambitious first year lawyer who has been assigned to a class action suit involving reparations for the descendants of american slaves it might seem that a new author would struggle with recreating a believable narrative for a plantation slave but this was not the case josephine's story was heartfelt and filled with vivid descriptions i loved this portion of the book i definitely got a real sense of the horrific conditions and treatment of the slaves and although it is unrealistic it made me really want the modern day class action suit to result in something even if it was an official government apology for the wrongs inflicted on the slaves but i struggled with the modern day story it almost felt like this book was written by two different people as much as the historic part was rich with description and the characters were complex the modern day story was flat there were several coincidences and subplots that made what could have been a deep and powerful book seem trite and more of a 'chick lit' read promising but not good enough

anne bell there's dorothea a 1 i'm guilty for judging a book by its cover however the raving reviews of the house girl also snagged my interest in this novel we actually meet three women despite the cover's description josephine lina and dorthea we meet josephine bell a 17 year old house girl shackled to a life of slavery on a failing tobacco farm in antebellum virginia she finds peace and escape through art an avenue of expression enabled by the farm's mistress an aspiring artist lu anne bell there's dorothea a 19th century abolitionist who briefly met yet was profoundly impacted by josephine then there's modern day litigation attorney lina sparrow in the bustling and sleepless city of new york lina is assigned a unique slavery reparations case through a series of events lina finds herself eagerly searching for a direct decedent of josephine bell throughout the book the plot alternates from late 19th century virginia to modern day new york city the author has a beautiful talent for illustrating the scene she wishes the reader to envision i did experience a degree of frustration as i spent more time trying to envision the scene which interfered with retaining what i just read perhaps that's my own problem but in the age of massive adhd diagnoses i'm pretty certain i'm not the only one there were so many individual stories to keep up with between josephine lu anne lina dorothea i really contemplated drawing a family tree to keep track of everyone and their family members and their family members' stories my brain almost almost melted i can't even begin to tell you how incredibly frustrating it is to read a story with such a string of impossible coincidences only for the ending to just end so abruptly and so poorly i realize every story has to end i realize this is historical fiction but the ending left me with a furrowed brow and disappointment i read the last six pages twice to unpiss myself off to make sure i read it correctly because it was just so unreasonable i'm not a huge jerk so i'll give the house girl three out of five stars because conklin's style of toggling between stories is wonderfully done but i'll have to dock two stars for nearly frying my brain

raw_text.3227: the plot was very interesting but i did not quite enjoy the author's style of writing there were moments when i could not wait to turn the page and sometimes i felt impatient at the slow pace of the story line i gave it a 4 star because josephine bell's character was made very plausible and real lina sparrow remained in the pages of the book and never climbed out to claim me i generally love plots and subplots and eventually when the different strains merge to make the story complete i marvel at that 'aha' moment i anticipate it get excited for it the multiple subplots in this book were difficult to keep track of but to be fair it could have been that my sleep deprived brain wasn't up to the task this book's 'aha' moment was perhaps just a whimper and not satisfying enough having said that it was the juxtaposition of modern new york life of carolina sparrow and the life of house girl josephine bell in 1852 lynnhurst virginia that made us even more conscious of the horrors of slavery and the treatment meted out to millions of men women and children that was well done and made reading this book worthwhile

raw_text.3233: i actually would give this book 4 1 2 stars this is a dual story one about a so called house girl in the years leading up the civil war the story also has another story that takes place in 2004 in which an attorney is assigned the job of finding a suitable heir of a slave to file a suit for reparations the reason i didn't give the book 5 stars was because it wasn't a page turner but in the last quarter of the book i realized why the author did a great job of unspooling the story of these two women especially the story of the slave josephine so that by the end you truly care and her what happens to her and whether she did in fact have any heirs this was a wonderful book and i look forward to more by this author historical fiction at its best

raw_text.3237: i think this is bound to be on my favorite reads for 2014 list a fantastic story that asks many questions about the human condition does our modern society create its own form of slavery seemingly it is the case for lina and what does it take to free a mind to rise above bondage does religious belief suffice or does it help keep the oppressed in bondage can one escape through religion and how do some manage to break out with no such belief this book not only leads you back into the days of slavery but also forces you to evaluate our current society and how far we have or have not developed beyond those horrendous times i particularly appreciated the study of family as presented by conklin i myself had a quite unique family especially for the rural midwestern us where i was raised though i was so fortunate to have had a very secure base of love as provided by my grandmother first and foremost i can empathize with lina and the fact she has not truly met her mother and often wonder so much how my life might have been altered if my biological father had been involved in it or even if i had just had the opportunity to at least have met him our book club consensus was that a book to follow up on lina's life would be wonderfully appreciated we'd love to know what she does now and in the future blog post to come

raw_text.3251: this is probably more of a 3 5 there were parts that i just wanted to skim through to get to the story the story is told in two narratives that of josephine a 17 yr old house slave in 1850's virginia and lina a class action lawyer in 2004 new york the opening chapter belonged to josephine she is planning to run and it won't be the first time lina's law firm is looking for the perfect plaintiff to be the 'face' of a lawsuit being brought seeking reparations for descendants of american slaves she stumbles across josephine's name through her father's work he is an artist and there is great controversy concerning who really painted a series of paintings attributed to josephine's 'missus' lu anne bell was it lu anne or was it the slave josephine lina's narrative follows the search for the descendants and i found this part of the story extremely interesting lina is also going through her own personal difficulties she has her own family issues that have been left untended for many years i wanted to like lina more than i did although she is a high powered lawyer she is still a petulant child with her father and given that she is highly intelligent and quite adept at research i cannot believe that she never sought to confirm the details of her mother's life and death by the middle of the book i found myself speed reading through her sections it was josephine's story that moved me

raw_text.3254: carolina sparrow is a first year lawyer working in new york city she is great at her job and her boss dan has told her that she is on track to become an excellent lawyer josephine bell is a slave at the bell plantation in southern virginia it is the mid 1800's and she is ready to leave the slave life for something better when a company contacts lina's law firm to collect reparations for the slaves lina is given the task of finding a plaintiff who is a direct descendant of a slave when luann bell's artwork comes into question at a local art exhibit claiming the work could have been done by her house girl josephine lina uses this opening to find the plaintiff she may need the book takes us back and forth between lina and josephine lina trying to find a direct descendant of josephine bell and josephine trying to escape the bell plantation i'm torn between giving this book 3 4 stars i was thoroughly intrigued by the subject matter but didn't find myself running to read listen to this book i think part of this was due to the fact that for a few weeks reading wasn't appealing to me and everything i picked up i didn't find interesting enough to keep reading one really interesting aspect to this book was the racial divide lina is a white girl from new york looking for descendants for a slave who escaped in 1852 shortly after the lady of the house passed away this discovery takes lina on a journey through virginia that she never anticipated she will uncover things that will turn history on end this book has been on my tbr list for a while i wasn't sure what to expect but i was thoroughly surprised i recommend this book for anyone who is interested in this subject matter or for a good book with a deep historical message i look forward to reading more books by tara conklin

raw_text.3277: 3 5 starsthis story is told in dual narration with letters from the past read by the contemporary protagonist carolina sparrow a successful young lawyer researching the background of josephine bell lu anne and robert bell lived on a tobacco farm in charlotte county virginia in the mid 1800s josephine was their house slave lu anne bell's paintings have long been renown in the art world however controversy now surrounds the true identity of the artist responsible for the work some believe it was the house slave josephine bell and not lu anne who beautifully captured the images of the slaves her husband owned the timing is perfect for lina and her firm to take advantage of the publicity surrounding the art work carolina lina is doing research for a class action lawsuit seeking reparations for the loss of income to the slaves she's looking for a living plaintiff who is a descendant of slaves so her firm will be able to make a claim against several private companies that benefited from slave labor lina begins to research josephine bell and feels she can find a living descendent for her case as someone who has researched their family tree i enjoyed reading about lina's path to discover what happened to josephine bell but her research yields a bit too much in a very short period of time for it to be completely realistic josephine bell decides to make a run for freedom on the very first page of her story she shares the details of her daily life as the house slave to lu anne bell a woman who took her from the slave quarters into her home and taught josephine her letters and how to read several other stories intersect with josephine's and we learn a little about dorothea round's her efforts to assist runaway slaves and her brother in law's failings as a doctor there are so many interesting stories that intersect in this book that i eagerly kept reading so i could find out how they ended i liked the characters and found myself equally interested in the contemporary storyline which usually isn't the case for me i generally prefer the historical storyline i think this book could generate some good discussion with the right book group and i did enjoy it i really liked all of the different threads and the way the author connected the individuals but as i said before there were far too many coincidences and research that yields too much too soon in order for this to be considered a realistic story however it is a compelling story with interesting characters and many mysteries unfolding within the various story lines and i think readers who are good at the suspension of disbelief may just love it

raw_text.3307: black history month is wrapping up and i just finished a novel that fits in well with that celebration tara conklin's debut novel the house girl first beckons to you with a stunningly beautiful cover a silhouette of young woman against a serene green background of what looks like wallpaper with birds and flowers while the cover pulls you in it is the beautiful writing that urges you to keep reading the story takes place in two time frames 1852 where we meet josephine a 17 year old house slave who cares for the ailing mistress of the house luann bell luann is a painter and from time to time she allows josephine to paint as well luann also taught josephine how to read josephine yearns for freedom and we discover throughout the story that she once tried to escape but was returned to her owners in 2004 lina sparrow is a corporate lawyer the daughter of oscar a famous artist lina's mother died when she was a child and she has very few memories of her mother lina is chosen by one of the partners at her law firm to work on finding a plaintiff for a big case a slave reparations lawsuit that a big client wishes to bring against corporations that made lots of money off the labor of slaves lina attends a show of luann bell's paintings and hears about a controversy surrounding the show some people believe that josephine is the actual artist and the controversy has made headlines lina believes that descendants of josephine would make the perfect plaintiffs for her case so she travels to virginia in search of them the story alternates between josephine and lina's point of view but the most interesting parts of the novel for me were the letters written by dorothea rounds an abolitionist who helped her undertaker father as a stop on the underground railroad to her sister kate and a twenty page letter written by caleb harper a disgraced medical student and brother in law to dorothea dorothea's letters to her sister explain in great detail how she and her father cleverly hid slaves in coffins destined for shipment up north as someone who grew up in auburn ny the last home of harriet tubman and a stop on the underground railroad i found this so fascinating how their scheme ends is a sad tale and the author tells it in such a compelling manner i found myself on the edge of my seat as i read it caleb's story is a sad one too he has a alcohol problem and after he is blamed for a family tragedy he completely falls apart he ends up working for a slave catcher medically treating the slaves so that they can be resold further south when caleb meets up with josephine he sees a chance at redemption i raced through caleb's 20 page letter because his story was so interesting and he is such a well written character many other reviews have mentioned that josephine's story is more compelling than lina's and i think it is partly because of these two primary sources that lina uncovers they are quite well done the house girl is one of those books that slowly pulls you in and once you are in you can hardly come up for air josephine's story and her yearning for basic human dignity and what she is willing to endure to find that are inspirational and heartbreaking if you are a fan of historical fiction i highly recommend this irresistible debut novel and i look forward to more to come from tara conklin rating 4 of 5

raw_text.3320: tara conklin's novel about a young slave girl in the 1850s and a young new york city lawyer in the present day is an engrossing tale that weaves the stories of these two women together in an unexpected way lina is working on a case that aims to give reparations to the descendants of american slaves she is the daughter of a famous artist and a mother that she doesn't remember and her father refuses to speak about josephine is a teenage slave who longs to be free to paint all of the beautiful pictures and colors that she sees all around her everything she describes from the flowerbeds around the main house to the slave woman she loves like a mother is bright and vivid once in a while her mistress lu ann bell gives her the opportunity to paint alongside her but josephine dreams of more and wants to run away what josephine doesn't realize is that 150 years later her mistress will be considered one of the great american female artists who sympathetically painted scenes from the lives of slaves but do these paintings come from the hand of lu ann bell or her house girl conklin's characters and their worlds are filled with bright and colorful descriptions not only of art but of their surroundings she writes kindly and sympathetically about the slaves and those who struggle to help them her main characters are both strong women with good hearts and i enjoyed getting to know both of them

raw_text.3327: this book review as well as many more can also be found on my blog the baking bookworm www thebakingbookworm blogspot ca my review from the description of this book i should have loved it it deals with the era of slavery and it got great ratings from other readers unfortunately the raw emotional element that i've come to expect from books that deal with slavery that showcases the worst of human kind and the hope and resilience of the human spirit was missing in this book after reading books like roots by alex haley one of my all time favourite books that i read before i started the blog hence no review the kitchen house by kathleen grissom or lawrence hill's the book of negroes i've come to expect that raw emotional connection with the main character s and i just didn't get that here perhaps it was because the story flips back and forth between two eras modern day and the mid 1800's or perhaps the dual narration between lina a modern day lawyer and josephine a slave from antebellum virginia was what didn't click with me whatever it was i found myself skimming paragraphs in the hopes that the plot would pick up unfortunately not a lot of detail was given to life on the plantation besides josephine's life in the house and i was a little surprised by that the secondary characters namely the other slaves were vastly underused and were only in the periphery of the story which was a shame because it would have given the reader a better understanding of what life was like back then i think that the lack of emotional element in this book also stems from the fact that the story seems to meander along and doesn't give the reader time to really get to know lina or josephine so that we can get emotionally attached to them josephine was mildly interesting but i didn't click with lina at all she was bland wasn't all that likeable and i suspect will be quite forgettable for a successful lawyer she felt very meek and i had no interest in her family issues she is a successful lawyer and yet she never once thought to use her resources to learn more about her mother's death or even ask her father about it it just seemed odd and out of character there were also a lot of coincidences involving lina's storyline especially stumbling upon the extremely long letters that shed light into josephine's life as well as meeting someone connected to josephine's story in such a random place it felt very implausible and that kind of thing really irks me i need for storylines and characters to be believable and the way the author told the story by using these letters felt like a short cut i'd much rather see how the character dealt with situations than read about it in a letter and while the idea of the reparations legal suit was an interesting premise reparations for the modern day relatives of the victims of slavery the thought that this was a highly unlikely situation kept niggling at the back of my mind what law firm would want to undertake such a huge and volatile case this was a decent read but not nearly as wonderful or emotional as i was hoping for i'd highly suggest reading roots the kitchen house or the book of negroes if you're looking for an in depth emotional read about this very disturbing era in american history my rating 2 5 5 stars

raw_text.3334: audiobook performed by bahni turpinin contemporary new york city attorney carolina sparrow is working on an historic class action lawsuit seeking reparations for the descendants of american slaves in 1852 josephine is a house slave who tends to the mistress of a virginia tobacco plantation her mistress is the artist lu anne bell the two stories converge when lina hears of a controversy rocking the art world art historians now suspect that the paintings ascribed to lu anne bell may really have been painted by her slave girl josephine a descendant of josephine would be the perfect "face" for the lawsuit - if lina can find one i enjoy reading historical fiction set during this period in america i almost always learn some interesting tidbit of information and this book was no exception i loved the sections of the book dealing with josephine and her struggles but conklin alternates chapters and keeps coming back to lina sparrow and her efforts to come to grips with her mother's death and her father's refusal to talk about her mother i thought the present day story weakened the impact of josephine's story added to that was the fact the despite drawing the reader into the story it ends rather abruptly with no clear conclusion yes i understand that is the reality of many such personal histories but this is fiction and i wanted a better ending bahni turpin does a fine job narrating the audio book she has good pacing and i had no trouble differentiating the characters despite the many shifts in perspective

raw_text.3338: i found this book very thought provoking and interesting a little slow to start and sometimes the narrative feels a little inconsistent i took me a little while to get used to her voice but there are moments where there is really beautiful writing the narrative switches viewpoints several times and i think there are some weaknesses in each viewpoint being distinct and consistent so it is not a perfect book but a good book that i will recommend to others i loved how lina's research into the past so deeply impacted her that it gave her the impetus to change what she needed to in her own life as an important idea the theme of freedom and what makes us free is not just part of the slave narrative but a part of every narrative in the story a good book club selection
raw_text.3339: i'm a history nerd which is what initially attracted me to this book when i read i have on both the reader's hat and to a lesser extent the editor's hat this is tara conklin's debut and it's a very strong one at that the story centers around a slavery reparations case where there is some question surrounding the authenticity of lu anne bell's artwork conklin does not write a story to reveal the answer to this she reveals this pretty early on the story is more about discovery about how insidious slavery really was josephine the house girl was the real artist but because she was black and a slave she did not get credit instead all the credit went to luanne bell josephine's invalid mistress lina sparrow is a young attorney assigned to work on the slavery reparations case and her task is to find a living descendent of josephine bell the house girl artist to be the lead plaintiff in the case lina also discovers things about herself and her mother conklin travels back and forth between antebellum virginia 1852 and 2004 new york between josephine the house girl and lina sparrow the young hot shot attorney to tell the story conklin employs the use of found letters between dorothea rounds and her sister kate and the recollections of caleb harper conklin manages to use all of these devices to tie in the stories and she handles them well in a writer of lesser ability employing these forms of narrative could end up becoming a huge confusing mess i was glad that the character of lina was not the typical young female new yorker stock chick lit character the author focused more on lina's abilities her intellect and her work ethic rather than the tropes that appear in many so called chick lit books i adore female characters who are strong intelligent human and are allowed to be all of those things in a book the house girl is one of the best books i've read in a long time i'm definitely interested in any future novels from this author
raw_text.3340: tara conklin has chosen a dual narrative style with alternating sections telling the modern story set against the historical slave story it's a good choice as it serves to heighten the readers' anticipation in getting to the climax of both stories i think and it helps to have each heroine work as a foil for the other however sometimes the women aren't so much foils as they are spiritual twins the lawyer is in need of freedom too the slave josephine's story is well written extremely poignant compelling and tragic the modern lawyer's story is not as well written but still interesting more compelling as it goes along and ultimately resolves well while coincidence played a strong part in several sections of the book all the coincidences were okay for me i think the reason is that there was no easy answer in the end for both stories and so the coincidences were mitigated the problem for me with this book was that the lawyer lina was flawed in ways that weren't explained nor explainable given her backstory i had trouble figuring out what motivated her she seemed like someone frozen or in suspended animation and unable to do anything she really cared about until near the end and i wasn't convinced by the things that released her from her suspended animation that she would go on and be all right there was one important thread left dangling i didn't like the stereotypes in the law firm all heartless greedy cut throats not a single one with a redeeming quality among the attorneys or the support staff with the exception of lina i don't know the legal world well i do have a good friend and a niece in firms somewhat like the one in the novel but i cannot believe this is realistic all that said i'm still going to recommend this book to my friends i would love to discuss it further

raw_text.3342: there was no way i was going to put this book down until i finished it which i finally did at 1 30 a m there were at least three riveting storylines that i needed to see to completion tara conklin writes in alternating chapters of points of view first the story of a young slave girl josephine who is desperate to find the rumored local link to the underground railroad so that she may finally have a chance at freedom and secondly is the modern day story of lina a lawyer who seeks to advance her career by accepting the challenge of finding a descendent of josephine so that she will be able to present a plaintiff in a suit for a client seeking reparations for slavery lina's sense of justice follows her every step of the way her relationship with her father is a strong thread in this book as well lina at a very young age lost her mother and she knows her father has been less than forthcoming about that loss i loved and empathized with josephine i rooted for lina i never quite trusted her father wonderfully intertwined stories and relationships
