raw_text.3364: check out http www infinitereads com for other reviews and sundry thoughts the house girl is an intricate debut novel that blends historical and contemporary fiction former attorney tara conklin uses art as a common thread intricately to connect the lives of two very different women separated by more than a century in 1852 virginia 17 year old house slave josephine looks after her dying mistress lu anne bell while trying to dodge her master's fists although her last escape attempt ended in recapture abuse and the stillbirth of her child josephine is ready to run away again waiting for her chance she soothes half mad lu anne by putting finishing touches on the paintings lu anne is no longer able to complete a naturally gifted artist josephine's talent far surpasses lu anne's but her world has no place for a slave with her talents in 2004 ambitious young attorney lina sparrow is assigned to a landmark slavery reparations case if she succeeds in building a credible case she could become a partner at her firm but her supervisor's indifference and a backstabbing co worker hamper her efforts then through friends of her artist father lina learns of rumors that the celebrated southern artist lu anne bell's paintings may have been the work of a house slave if lina can find a descendant of josephine to act as plaintiff their case will have the perfect public face but first she must solve the mystery of what happened to josephine more than 150 years ago complicating matters lina's father suddenly wants to talk about her deceased mother after long years of silence and lina fears what she might learn about her brilliant stifled mother alternating between josephine and lina's points of view the house girl draws two distinct portraits that intersect in surprising ways conklin's former life as a litigator for a major corporate law firm shows in her depiction of a young lawyer trying to break through her firm's glass ceiling without sacrificing her ethics skillfully executed and packed with surprises this novel of the ways in which art saves our humanity is an engrossing do not miss adventure this review originally appeared in shelf awareness raw_text.3386: the house girl" is a tale about provenance the dual stories of a negro slave in the 19th century and her need to escape juxtaposed with that of a woman discovering her own identity in a search for the first antebellum artwork and the mystery of its provenance everyone in this novel is searching for a place to be tara conklin writes well but there was just something missing in this novel for me at least i don't feel that i come away from it with any real sense of the women involved they were all just too sketchily drawn and that for me is a shame the provenancing of the women is central to the development of the plot and i just didn't get enough out of the characterisation to attach myself to any of them i didn't know them and i couldn't get any real sense of who they were or why they behaved the way they did just not enough emotional attachment or story development the rest of conklin's characters lack depth it's disappointing when you spend over 350 pages with these people and leave feeling like you never learned anything about them much less felt something for them added to this is a series of long long passages devoted to names of slaves and statistics on their lives and circumstances unnecessary some short vignettes might have conveyed the stories so much better it took me ages to complete this novel i really wanted to like it but it just didn't get me where i thought it would thank you to the publisher and netgalley for the chance to review the novel as an advance reader copy

raw_text.3390: tara conklin's novel links two stories from two centuries first is the story of josephine a house slave in virginia in 1852 her missus is an amateur painter but josephine has real artistic talent and often improves the missus' work as well as creating paintings of her own the second story belongs to lina the lawyer daughter of a couple of artists who is tasked with finding a lead plaintiff for a slavery reparations case the novel begins with a chapter about josephine and i was terribly disappointed when the narrative switched to lina's point of view but then i got caught up in her story and was sad to leave it behind for another josephine story though i sometimes felt like i was getting jerked from story to story overall i think the alternating point of view device is effective conklin carefully finesses the way the two storylines come together she keeps the level of suspense high and the reader definitely wants to know how the stories end this novel does not romanticize slavery even though it's obvious that for a slave josephine has it pretty good she has enough to eat and the missus seems to care about her but conklin doesn't skimp on the horrors either josephine is raped by the master painting is a pursuit she can follow only when the missus feels like it josephine cannot choose the relationships she forms the call to freedom is strong although i think i prefer josephine's storyline lina's is also compelling she is experiencing something of an identity crisis even though she has managed to reach her goal of becoming an associate in a large and prestigious law firm her relationship with her father has become strained and she becomes unsure of where she belongs and if she has what it takes to survive in her career a fast and interesting read and if this is indeed her first novel it's an exciting debut and i hope to read more from tara conklin
raw_text.3391: this was an interesting weaving of past and present as a modern day attorney works to find descendants of a house slave who may or may not have been the creator of a series of artworks credited to her mistress the novel moves from past to present and it makes for an interesting read there's no real literary depth that i noticed but it's an intriguing story

raw_text.3393: this book tells the story of two young women one an attorney in modern day new york the other a slave in 1852 living on a plantation in virginia lina sparrow the attorney encounters the story of josephine bell the young slave "house girl" while working on an assignment the paintings and other art works of josephine bell have long been attributed to her owner's wife luanne bell while telling the stories of these two women the author introduces many themes girls who lost their mothers at an early age as both did the role of art in society slavery and it's many horrors and many others the stories of both women are engaging and i was totally immersed in both while reading this novel which is written in beautiful and lyrical language i enjoy the technique that is being employed by many authors of historical fiction these days of juxtaposing characters in alternating chapters one set in one era often in current day times and the other in the past this author does this even more skillfully than most with an even flow from one to another while telling the stories of the two central characters she creates a sense of them being pulled toward each other even across time and many generations for most of the way through this book i felt it was a 5 star read for me however the ending left me with that hanging feeling for the remarkable writing talent that this author displayed throughout most of the book i think she could have done a better job of bringing closure to both stories even so i would highly recommend this book to most of my reading friends

raw_text.3406: de paperback|isbn 978 1 44341 353 4virginia 1852 seventeen year old josephine bell decides to run from the failing tobacco farm where she is a slave and nurse to her ailing mistress the aspiring artist lu anne bell new york city 2004 lina sparrow an ambitious first year associate in an elite law firm is given a difficult highly sensitive assignment that could make her career she must find the perfect plaintiff to lead a historic class action lawsuit worth trillions of dollars in reparations for descendants of american slaves it is through her father the renowned artist oscar sparrow that lina discovers josephine bell and a controversy roiling the art world are the iconic paintings long ascribed to lu anne bell really the work of her house slave josephine a descendant of josephine's would be the perfect face for the reparations lawsuit if lina can find one while following the runaway girl's faint trail through old letters and plantation records lina finds herself questioning her own family history and the secrets that her father has never revealed how did lina's mother die and why will he never speak about her moving between antebellum virginia and modern day new york this searing suspenseful and heartbreaking tale of art and history love and secrets explores what it means to repair a wrong and asks whether truth is sometimes more important than justice a gripping tale if i ever did read one a page turner at it's best

raw_text.3425: at a time when i am struggling to find ethnic us authors for a reading project this book which deals with the very issue i am confronted with on my reading project the legacy of slavery could not have come at a better time with gentle strokes conklin paints thought provoking pictures of the anonymity of slaves their uncredited contributions to culture of art of the arbitrariness of race and of the low state from which the african american population has had to rise the house girl is masterfully structured bringing josephina an artist slave girl whose paintings were credited to her white missus into the present via lina sparrow a young new york lawyer who is working to find a plaintiff for a reparations lawsuit for the descendants of american slaves conklin is not heavy handed in her rendering of the story and in fact does as beautiful a job portraying the importance of art as she does showing the still rippling effects of the us slave trade i particularly loved her explorations of skin tone and how subjective the distinction is between black and white caucasian and african american after all these years of intermingling bloodlines i took a break from my andrea reads america reading project to read this for book club so i read for pleasure and did not take notes i think this will be one to return to to underline and star to record favorite quotes and to keep on my shelf when i want a well told story full of issues and points of view that are important to me

raw_text.3451: this book tells alternate stories of josephine a slave in 1852 virginia and lina sparrow a lawyer in 2004 new york city lina begins the search for information to support a lawsuit that will seek reparation for the descendants of african american slaves and in her research she uncovers josephine's story josephine's story is definitely the stronger of the two but as lina learns about josephine and the courage and strength it took for her to run away and seek freedom lina seems to gain a personal strength of her own that allows her to look at her own life with a new perspective it is a tale of many things including slavery and freedom loss the value of art the importance of self and of self discovery i found it interesting to speculate that there were slaves who would have been allowed the freedom given to josephine but even with those freedoms her life was not an easy or happy one and she was willing to risk it all to be really free then we look at lina's life in modern times and see that she is really not a free or happy person either in spite of the plethora of coincidental occurrences i liked how conklin meshed the lives of these two characters from the two different time periods

raw_text.3460: maybe 1 2 spoilers just as a warning where do i begin this book grabbed me from the beginning with not only the good writing but the characters themselves both josephine and lina were dealing with turmoil in their lives with respect to loved ones and discovering how to proceed with their life both of these women were extremely independent strong and full of courage obviously josephine's struggles were far more strenuous than lina's as her choices up until her decision to leave were not her's she did not have the ability given to her to alter how she was treated or how to fill her days however once she decided to run away her choices from then on were full of determination and ownership of how she would live and die i had such respect for her character and wanted to see her live forever one would say that she did live on forever through her art i felt for lina as she didn't really know where she came from who really was her mom what happened to her i was pulled into her story of wanting to find out more about her mom's story even if her dad wasn't open about it the fact that she got so entrenched into finding out whether josephine was the true artist of the bell pictures vs lu ann excited me i loved that she continued pressing on to see if her descendents might be alive today as well as finding out the truth of the artwork all of this determination even when her own boss wasn't necessarily on board yes it might have started out due to the reparations case but i felt that it turned into more i felt that she was discovering more about herself and the fact that she wanted to help others and not think about life in the terms of billable hours through her work she was able to bring closure to a new friend that she made she was able to give him understanding of where he came from how exciting is that finally caleb's written words on what happened on the journey that brought him to josephine that fateful day his words that described their brief time together and how he came to find joseph and ultimately free joseph was so endearing while it was such a brief part of the book it explained so much about not only how joseph lived but how josephine ultimately decided on how she would leave this world additionally it provided the undeniable proof that josephine was the truly gifted artist of the works of art everyone loved over the years i can't say enough about this book while i might not understand what either of these characters went through especially josephine this story made me feel like i glimpsed into their world they captured my heart i would recommend this story to anyone that loves historical fiction and i do not think you would be dissatisfied

raw_text.3508: reviewed on words in a teacupwhen i read the premise i thought i'd love this book when i read the first chapters i realized i wouldn't the house girl is an extremely dull book there's no way around it the idea is intriguing two parallel plot lines a slave girl in 19th century virginia and a present day lawyer working on a class action lawsuit for descendants of slaves i've no doubt that the right writer could spin a compelling tale with that having the narratives complement each other until they're joined at the end when lina finally finds out what happened to josephine unfortunately tara conklin is not that writer the prose is needlessly meandering the reader is subjected to endless descriptions of well everything until each scene is so bogged down with the description of the settee's brass buttons and you've quite forgotten what's even going on i admit i started skimming about halfway through but i don't think i missed anything because everything is repeated several times in fact if the author really wishes to hit you over the head with it for example the book will often make the point that gasp slavery is bad the problem is that despite all the flowery descriptions i don't know anything about the characters they're flat a caricature of themselves take the character of dorothea for example a third pov that appears halfway through the book because josephine's narration was the only one even remotely interesting and so had to be suppressed dorothea lives with her father and mother she writes letters to her married sister talking about how they help fugitive slaves there's pages and pages of fake letters from dorothea and from those i have learned absolutely nothing about dorothea's personality about what she's like her dreams and hopes yeah she helps slaves she wants to be an abolitionist but if you take that away she is nothing her family is equally unsubstantial it feels as if the author had a story to tell and everyone and everything is a prop that must help the story along no matter how implausible some bits will be in hindsight josephine says that the first time she ran she came back because of a pain in her side later we find out that it's not true she reached dorothea's family but decided to go back it makes no sense for josephine to be an unreliable narrator so why would her memories be wrong yes but we couldn't mention dorothea the first time around because she only appears halfway through the book and dorothea had to have met josephine at some point because she had to write about her in her letter that lina would read a hundred years later instead of having the characters shape the plot it's the plot that orders the characters along making everything happen by means of contrived coincidences i'm sorry about giving this book one star only because i still think that with a shorter page count perhaps as a novella the plot might have been salvageable but the big revelation at the end about lina's mother yeah view spoiler i'm pretty sure that nowadays especially if we're talking about someone moderately famous that the papers might write about you can't fake someone's death you'd think with her 17 6 billable hours of research per day and mad google skills maybe lina would have looked up her mother and found out she never died maybe she took after her father who forgot he'd given different causes of death to different people hide spoiler saw that coming

raw_text.3512: i was not sure what to expect out of this book but i thoroughly enjoyed it the author keeps the story moving and the way the present day protagonist connects the story of the woman in slavery to her work on a legal case involving reparations is interesting and intriguing i was disappointed that the modern day protagonist carolina is not as well developed as josephine the house girl i'm a lawyer and i had a similar sort of experience at my first job out of law school but i had a hard time connecting with carolina i also thought the relationship between her and her fellow lawyers was not realistically developed her relationship with her father was well done though he hides the real relationship he had with carolina's mother causing her to develop a myth of their relationship that has sustained her throughout her life the climax occurs when she learns the truth which is revealed in bits over the course of the book and i won't spoil that here what i will say is that carolina's struggle to reconcile the real relationship between her parents as it is revealed over time with the myth she developed in the absence of any information from her father is well written and captures the universal human tendency to hold on to a story for comfort

raw_text.3547: the house girl is a novel in the historical fiction genre that follows the formula of a present day story alternating chapters with a historical back story it's not a bad book it's just not breaking any new ground the back story is pretty basic with a young house slave named josephine who dreams of running away to freedom it's fine it's readable it's heartfelt the present day story centers on a young lawyer who is given the opportunity to work on a potentially enormous and explosive class action lawsuit against the government and private corporations seeking reparations for slavery she must find a lead plaintiff on who's behalf to bring the lawsuit she begins to search for the descendants of the josephine the problem with the house girl is that the present day story is ridiculous bringing a lawsuit seeking reparations not a bad idea the premise is really interesting and opens the doors to a lot of ways to legitimately research the history and discover the back story but in this case the execution of the plot just had me rolling my eyes at all of the contrivances and coincidences i think it could have been a really good book in the hands of a better author

raw_text.3561: honestly i initially shied away from reading this one despite all of the good reviews i don't really like books about the south or slavery or books with multiple narrators or books about lawyers i do really judge my books and have a lot of rules about which ones i don't like and won't read but i am so glad i picked it up anyway tara conklin's the house girl is classy and enthralling i tore through it from the jacket blurb 2004 lina sparrow is an ambitious young lawyer working on a historic class action lawsuit seeking reparations for the descendents of american slaves 1852 josephine is a seventeen year old house slave who tends to the mistress of a virginia tobacco farm an aspiring artist named luanne bell a descendent of josephine's would be the perfect face for the lawsuit if lina can find one but nothing is known about josephine's fate following lu anne bell's death in 1852 in piecing together josephine's story lina embarks on a journey that will lead her to question her own life including the full story of her mother's mysterious death twenty years before that sums it up much better than i could lina's search made me want to find josephine's relatives too i was engrossed until the end the end was perfect while i felt it didn't answer all of the questions i wanted it to sometimes that is the best i wanted the story to continue but now i can imagine what happened next
raw_text.3562: tara conklin's first novel "the house girl " arrives in the middle of black history month boasting all the qualities of a very earnest bestseller like kathryn stockett's "the help " which has sold millions of copies "the house girl" depicts privileged white women and oppressed black women in a familiar unchallenging way that strokes our liberal sensibilities and lets us feel again the sweet pleasure of racial enlightenment not that there's anything wrong with that but conklin's novel gives the impression that it has been genetically engineered for women's book clubs miscarriages missing children alienated fathers lost mothers dating troubles trying to have it all in a man's world the requisite issues snap into place with the kind of predictability that will make readers suspect they're being manipulated what's particularly unfortunate is that there's a fine story chopped up and sprinkled within the pages of this book with a nod to a s byatt's "possession " "the house girl" comes to us in two alternating strands a mystery in the past and a search for answers in the present josephine is a restless young slave in 1852 the once prosperous virginia farm where she lives is failing under the mismanagement of a master who has neither the funds nor the skill to maintain the plantation his wife the dying mistress of bell creek fancies herself a painter but josephine is the real artist of the affecting portraits that will someday be regarded as masterpieces of 19th century american art in the novel's alternating chapters we follow the detective work of lina sparrow in 2004 a new associate with a prestigious new york law firm she and another young lawyer are charged with preparing the largest legal case in the history of the world a class action lawsuit demanding $6 2 trillion from the u s government and 22 corporations on behalf of millions of descendants of african american slaves because "this is a biggie " as her boss puts it that relies on a "new legal theory " lina is given two weeks to prepare such are the demands on young lawyers hoping to make partner next month she might sue the asteroid that killed the dinosaurs the legal and moral arguments for paying reparations to the descendants of african american slaves would be a rich and fascinating subject but the cringing absurdities of this plot multiply like a senior partner's billable hours it isn't enough for lina to sue the u s government for an amount equal to a sizable percentage of the gdp she decides that she must first solve a 150 year old mystery of art history involving josephine's paintings and given the millions of aggrieved descendants of slaves who might make powerful lead plaintiffs in the reparations case why not insist on recruiting only an extremely reluctant mixed race hunk who might or might not be related to josephine these would seem to be formidable challenges for any new lawyer and amateur sleuth but fortunately every time lina cracks open an old notebook out falls some revelatory clue that has eluded generations of scholars reparations for slavery may be a long shot but lina should have a strong case against any english teacher who still advises "write what you know " conklin actually worked as a lawyer at a new york law firm and yet these familiar parts of her novel display the glib artificiality of someone who learned about office life by watching tv this silly legal drama has been bred with an engrossing slave story in a tragic act of literary miscegenation far too many flags are raised to mark significant parallels between josephine's situation and lina's a bolder editor would have sliced away these modern bits and published "the house girl" as a good historical novel every chapter about josephine is infused with ominous atmosphere and evocative detail as bell creek falls into ruin conklin explores the shifting responsibilities of slave and master student and teacher patient and nurse while she never reaches the psychological depth of toni morrison or edward p jones she does convey the impossibly bizarre relationships that slavery created spared from the crushing labor of farm work josephine finds that she is "not of one world or the other neither the house nor the fields " she and her dying mistress care for each other within a system of institutionalized brutality that neither of them openly acknowledges if josephine can't enjoy actual freedom she still manages to feel a kind of triumphant pity for this sickly white woman lashed in matrimony to a genteel pedophile and rapist who enjoys all the unquestioned privileges of southern culture "it was missus' face stricken even in sleep sallow even by lamplight the scabbed gash like a bristling insect on her cheek that stopped josephine her face no longer young or beautiful her wasted face and it seemed josephine's heart pulsed with the skittering movement of missus' eyes that the two of them lay prostrate together before the same cruel god the two of them not so different after all josephine realized all this time these long hungry years each of them alone beside the other "that lush gothic tone simmers throughout these 1852 chapters enriched periodically by letters from two white people who tried to help josephine it's a dramatic montage of narrative and personal testimonies that depicts the grotesque routines of the slave trade the deadly risks of the underground railroad and the impossible choices that slaves and abolitionists faced if only josephine's stirring tale had been emancipated from the story of her modern day defender "the house girl" might have run free

raw_text.3590: this was tara conklin's first novel and it reads as such while many authors have incorporated flashbacks and epistles to weave together the narratives of two separate characters conklin's two storylines and characters felt cobbled together contrived to help her reach her ultimate goal in fact in reading her q and a at the end of the text she explained that she started with one of the minor characters then built in the main character from the past which reinforces my sense that the narrative frame from the present tense was more of an afterthought and yet this narrative frame overwhelmed the novel and detracted from some of the best writing the novel shifts from the detective work of carolina sparrow who is sleuthing about the history of a remarkable slave house girl josephine who may or may not have painted and drawn what are now deemed to be works of art that represent humanity and compassion about plantation life josephine may or may not have direct descendants one of the descendants may or may not be a salt of the earth rock band member who supports himself by working at a library lina may or may not be falling in love with him all the while grappling with her famous artist father's possible love affairs and the memory of who her dead mother may or may not have been you get my point the best part of the book is when conklin lets josephine take over and live in the moment this is when her imagery and storytelling takes on a poetic magical quality featuring careful purposeful imagery this is when conklin is at her finest

raw_text.3609: the basic story in the house girl deeply moved me but i found the book flawed by too many back story letters and author pontificating i don't want to spoil the experience for anyone so i won't give too many specifics i found the character of josephine bell the young 'house girl' slave artist tragic and arresting and by far tara conklin's best creation on the other hand i found lina sparrow the modern day lawyer whiny and tedious grace lina's absent mother was actually a more compelling character than lina i saw more ground for comparison between josephine and grace than between josephine and lina tara conklin's writing suffers from an excess of character pontificating to reveal lina's thoughts instead of allowing her to develop naturally here's a prime example from p 284 who could tell her those things were untrue truth was multilayered shifting it was different for everyone each personal history carved unique from the same weighty block of time and flesh give me a break conklin also wastes a lot of space providing amateurish description like this passage from pp 364 5 she stood and breathed in the smell of spring here the quad's lush lawn seemed to produce a different quality of air better than sidewalks or subways or corporate law firms had i been conklin's editor i would have made her cut a lot of this dreck and focus on josephine and grace conklin's basic plot the search for an appropriate face for a massive class action reparations lawsuit and its connection to the provenance and authentication of a southern antebellum artist's work is solid and heartbreaking conklin didn't need to explain to us peasants the deeper meanings of the story we are capable of putting 2 and 2 together and coming up with our own understandings

raw_text.3638: i loved this book it's my favorite book so far of 2013 and i've read some good ones this year the house girl tells the story of josephine bell a slave in the mid 1800s it's also the story of 21st century lina sparrow an ambitious young lawyer in a prestigious manhattan law firm the stories come together when lina is assigned to research a controversial reparations case for her firm and to find a plaintiff ideally one who is a descendant of the slave josephine bell history reveals little of josephine other than that she was an orphaned slave a house servant on a virginia plantation and owned by her mistress lu anne bell lu anne was an artist whose works are highly prized today for their empathetic and caring portrayals of slaves on her plantation critics and collectors rave over lu anne bell's moving works of art and her ability to capture the very spirit of the slaves and others who were her subjects now comes the controversy according to some sources in the art world there's reason to believe the art was not the work of lu anne bell at all but that of josephine her slave we meet josephine in 1852 on the very day she decides to run her decision is prompted by an unwarranted slap in the face by mister husband of josephine's owner much more than the slap though has brought josephine to this as the memories that haunt her on this day of decision reveal her mistress has been unusually kind to josephine raising her from a child teaching her to read and write sometimes even allowing josephine to paint in her art studio but miss lu anne has also been strangely indifferent to unspeakable cruelties that the girl has suffered now her mistress is dying and josephine knows she must go but hours before the planned escape miss lu ann makes a stunning confession one that shakes josephine to her soul and almost makes her decide to stay she has no other choice though so josephine runs and is never heard of never mentioned in historical records again now in the 21st century world of big business and litigation lina sparrow must somehow discover the rest of josephine's story with virtually nothing to go on lina sets out and through perseverance and luck discovers long buried secrets about the runaway slave girl at the same time lina learns shocking secrets about her own life those secrets will force her to question who she is and what she really wants from life tara conklin evokes life for slaves in the american south with a heartbreaking authenticity and sheds light on the complicated relationships between owners and the owned with results that continue to reverberate even today this memorable book is a must read

raw_text.3649: since i was young i have been attracted to anything fiction or non fiction related to the underground railroad and its history the house girl is made up of two intertwined stories the first is of lina sparrow an eager young lawyer looking to prove herself the second is of josephine a house girl to missus lu who lives on the bell creek plantation in virginia during the 1800s the two stories intersect when lina is given the assignment of finding the perfect plaintiff for a lawsuit worth trillions of dollars in reparations for descendants of american slaves through an unexpected lead from her artist father lina pieces together the story of josephine and what happened to her i found this story intriguing and enjoyed alternating between modern day new york and antebellum virginia not only is it a story of history and art but it is also a story of love and whether truth or justice is ultimately more important
raw_text.3650: an enjoyable enough read but i think it could have been better chapters alternate between the present where lina a 24 year old lawyer gets put on a big case seeking reparations for slavery and 1852 where josephine a house slave tries to escape her situation the stories are pulled together by works of art that josephine is the author of but that her missus luanne bell gets the credit for lina is not a strong character i just didn't find her very believable while josephine is a great character full of insight i liked the premise of the art world being set on it's ear by arguments that these famous works of art were really done by a slave but i thought there were far too many coincidences and that the climax when the full story of what happened in 1852 came out was a little weak

raw_text.3652: on reading the summary of this book i thought it would be a different story it started out with a lot of promise and i thought that the exploration of the reparation idea would make for an exciting emotional read however i don't feel it delivered in the end view spoiler i could never really see the main character lina as an attorney she just didn't seem aggressive enough but then i guess that turns out to be the point when she realizes this herself at the end the connection between the lawsuit for reparations and the researching of josephine bell seemed a little far fetched for me it's like there were too many investigations going on did josephine make the artwork does josephine have any living descendants two separate investigations that almost don't relate to each other the whole lawsuit for the reparations in the first place didn't make sense to me for the same reasons that end up getting the lawsuit postponed cancelled in the end so there ends up being no point to all the research done aside from a genealogical discovery for jasper who wanted nothing to do with the lawsuit in the first place not even thinking he had black ancestors and a potential book deal for a local professor i also wished for less of lina's personal story and more research in looking for josephine's descendants the mystery was essentially solved by letters that explained what happened granted only about two letters directly mentioned josephine hide spoiler there was too much of lina's personal story which i found distracting and not really adding to the story and there was no story for garrison who i thought would play a bigger role in the book being that he was assigned to the same case as lina well written but there was a lot added to the book that was unnecessary and there were missed opportunities for some character development
raw_text.3653: literary fiction is as much a genre as any other to that end it is possible to get bored tired of the same old lush setting descriptions and journey of self discovery just as it is to get bored of a romance's hyperbolic sex and meet cute moment been there done that the house girl is very much literary fiction and it is interesting enough but still married to its genre not only does the narrator present sweeping visual landscapes and atmosphere but so do secondary characters in their own words reading the drunken doctor's tale of the slave boy one can't help but wonder if maybe he should have tried being author if he's going to spend so much of an explanatory letter on his feelings thoughts enchantment with the scenery in the same way conklin does try to convey the sense that the slaves are truly seen as property instead of people spoiler yet she has the white slaveholders give not sell the house girl's baby to a neighboring plantation because that fits the narrative arc better that undermines not only the verisimilitude but also its precarious credentials of a white author writing from the slave's pov
raw_text.3654: i liked both story lines in this book and it was very clean it just seemed like the author wrapped it all up too quickly i was hoping for a little more on the underground railroad
raw_text.3655: tonight now it did not shake her what nathan had said freedom was a curious thing were the chickens free running their fool heads off in the yard the horse that still must fit the bit between its teeth was missus free but what else to dream for there was no dream of josephine's that did not contain a place where she might sit and look upon a field or a bird in flight or a person and ponder the lines of that thing to capture them in pencil or charcoal or ink or pigment just to sit for a moment herself no one claiming her time or her thoughts or the product of her mind and hands what other word to call that if not freedom not a one is free nathan had said but josephine did not believe that could be true as i finally got around to reading this fabulous book i couldn't believe that it had been sitting around for years years unread on my kindle i wonder how many other treasures are hanging out on my bookshelves real and virtual the book's plot involves two story lines what my gr friend cathrine cleverly calls a two fer the historical tale of slave and house girl josephine bell and the modern day story of young lawyer lina sparrow whose work on a new case leads her to research the life of josephine bell the two stories are evenly written which is a testament to the talent of the author some books with historical modern splits can end up with one story being significantly better than the other i particularly enjoyed the the author's treatment of the historical aspect of the novel much time is spent with josephine's thoughts rather than just relying on dialogue these were beautiful passages that conveyed her humanity and the universality of a desire for freedom in addition to the two fer readers also get to enjoy a variety of styles in this book not only is the story told in prose but the plot is also revealed via letters and art critiques so readers get to enjoy all sorts in genres in one package 4 solid stars
raw_text.3656: i absolutely love novels with a story within a story the house girl is one of those books it is the story of lina a corporate ny attorney involved in a slavery reparation case and of a slave named josephine living in virginia lina's story is a modern one she is a hard working career oriented young woman with a loving but scattered artist dad josephine's tale is compelling although she is also hard working she has no known family for josephine is owned by a family lina's chapters are integral to the plot but it is josephine's narrative that will stay with you since this is the hundredth year anniversary of the emancipation proclaimation the house girl has fostered my interest to read more about this period in our history

raw_text.3667: i enjoyed this book very much i really liked the historical parts of this book better than the modern portions even though the two parts were blended together i always felt a disconnect between the two storylines i thought that the lawsuit seemed daunting and impossible but really enjoyed the plantation and josephine's plan to escape there were so many characters to keep up with in this story that it became a little overwhelming trying to keep all the different people and storylines straight i like descriptive writing and being able to really visualize the settings but sometimes this felt overdone in this book the descriptions were so detailed that i found myself wanting to skim over paragraphs describing the offices or the house because of all the details it became sort of a i can't see the forest for the trees kind of description i don't really need to know what kind of pens they write with or the color of the coffee mug and every single thing she sees while walking down the hallway at work i was a little disappointed in the ending it wrapped up a little too well and perfect but overall it was a very enjoyable read there were some funny moments even in the midst of a somewhat sad story and there were some lighthearted scenes to balance it out this is a fast easy book to read and is the whole reason i love to go to book club because i would probably have never read this book on my own but i am so glad i did
